PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Alston (from 77 citizens), Senator Archer (from 50 citizens), Senator Michael Baume (from 110 citizens), Senator Burns (from 48 citizens), Senator Calvert (from 31 citizens), Senator Colston (from 34 citizens), Senator Durack (from 45 citizens), Senator Herron (from 50 citizens), Senator Kemp (from 55 citizens), Senator Knowles (from 50 citizens), Senator MacGibbon (from 48 citizens), Senator McMullan (from 237 citizens), Senator Panizza (from 49 citizens), Senator Parer (from 44 citizens), Senator Patterson (from 72 citizens), Senator Powell (from 150 citizens), Senator Reid (from 156 citizens), Senator Teague (from 50 citizens), Senator West (from 104 citizens) and Senator Zakharov (from 130 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
* That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
* That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
* That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
* That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
* That in 1987-88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
* That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australia Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Honourable Senators to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator MacGibbon (from 9 citizens) and Senator Parer (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Port Hedland-Marble Bar Road
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
* The Port Hedland/Marble Bar road is in terrible condition;
* As far back as the early 1950s the people of Marble Bar were promised an all weather road;
* The poor state of the gravel road is deterring tourists from seeing the many attractions in the Marble Bar area and causing untold damage to the town's economy.
Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure that funds are made available for the essential upgrading of this important road.
As in duty bound your petitions will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.6 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate should:
. . . . request the Australian Government-
to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish-
* the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
* the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
* the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
* That every abortion kills an unborn baby.
* That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
* That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
* That in 1989-90 alone Medicare subsidised 69,587 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to subsidise abortions through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

(ii) call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (IACO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by IACO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing legislation, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Inquiry into Australia's
Anti-Dumping and Countervailing Legislation
On 7 November 1990 the Senate resolved that the following matter be referred to the Committee for inquiry and report by 31 March 1991:
The operation of revised procedures for implementation of anti-dumping and countervailing actions and the need for legislative changes to the Customs Act 1901.

The key elements of the revised procedures which were introduced into Parliament were the establishment of an Anti-Dumping Authority and the introduction of sunset provisions and statutory time limits. The revised procedures followed the review by Professor Gruen of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975.

Because of the level of public interest and concern the Committee sought an extension of time to report on this reference from 31 March to 21 June 1991 in order to undertake a program of public hearings and inspections around Australia. It was essential that Australian industry represented by industry associations, grower councils and organisations, individual producers and companies had an opportunity to put forward its views to the Committee.

Today's Australian industry confronts a complex, cumbersome and confusing body of Australian legislation and practice which seeks to promote fair trade. The principal Act concerned with ensuring fair trade is the Customs Act 1901. Other legislation includes the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 and the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988.

The complexity and confusion stems from a number of sources. Although all three Acts deal with imports which are unfairly traded in the Australian market, they are administered by two independent bodies which are responsible to separate persons. Part XVB of the Customs Act is administered by the Comptroller-General of Customs while the Anti-Dumping Authority, a statutory body, is responsible to the Minister. Another cause of complexity and confusion is that although the two bodies require evidence of injury to an industry before a positive finding can be made, the nature of the findings differ between them. Findings of the Australian Customs Service can be reversed by the Anti-Dumping Authority.

Added to this is Australia's move towards lower tariffs and the current economic recession. Australian industry's concerns and anxieties were further raised with the Government's recent announcement of phased tariff reductions. The Committee's approach to the inquiry was to draw a clear distinction between tariff protection and anti-dumping protection and to resist replacing one method of protection with another as a substitute for lower tariff levels. The Committee also resisted the approach which ignored our international obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the Codes adopted by the GATT. The Committee's Report describes in detail the GATT Agreements, Australian legislation and the practice of the Australian authorities which are designed to conform with these Agreements. The Committee's aim was to ensure that Australia's anti-dumping system operated for the purpose for which it was intended as a mechanism by which Australian companies and primary producers can seek relief from unfairly traded imports which are causing injury to their industry.

Critical to the Committee's thinking was the complaint by Australian industry that the current anti-dumping system was complex, time consuming, confusing and costly. The evidence of most, if not all, witnesses representing Australian industry emphasised that the legislation discouraged industry from mounting a dumping case. As Mr K. Stubbs, Co-ordinator of the National Industry Associations Anti-Dumping Task Force, stated to the Committee:

We are finding that a number of companies just do not have the resources, either internally or financially, to pursue a dumping case. Estimates of the cost of a case vary dramatically from $5,000 to $25,000 to $40,000 depending on the complexity and the number of countries that are investigated. We are finding that there is a lot of interest in mounting a dumping case, but, when the complexities confront these companies, many just do not pursue the issues; and adjustments are made within the organisations concerned.

The Committee examined the legislation and in particular section 269 of the Customs Act and found that it imposed a stricter requirement for a dumping application to be exhaustively documented than that required by the GATT Codes. This has led to an undue burden being placed on an industry's resources to comply with the legislation.

In addition there was a widespread perception that the anti-dumping system concealed a broader economic agenda. The National Industry Associations Anti-Dumping Task Force which represents a large number of companies and peak industry bodies perceived the Authority as an arm of the government's industry policy. For the Task Force the Authority was a policy instrument of industry structural adjustment. This perception was supported by the ACTU. As Mr W. Mansfield, Assistant Secretary of the ACTU stated to the Committee:

. . . it is our view that the anti-dumping arrangements and arrangements which are designed to counter the dumping of goods in Australia should not be used as a mechanism by government to seek to restructure industry or to bring about changes in manufacturing industry in this country that would not have otherwise taken place through the normal operation of the market . . . there is that perception amongst industry generally, and it is also held by ourselves, that the Anti-Dumping Authority is really seeking to implement more than simply the principles that underlie the issue of dumping which go to the determination of whether or not goods are being brought into this country at less than the cost of manufacture. Rather, the ADA is seeking to pursue a broader economic agenda which may align itself with notions of what sort of industry we should have in this country, what size that industry ought to be, how efficient it ought to be and issues of that kind.

This perception stems from the convergence of a variety of industry and trade policies pursued by Government not all of which are consistent with each other. These policies include the need to lower tariffs, the need to restructure manufacturing industry, rationalising government assistance to industry and the need to protect industry against unfair trade practices. The Committee concluded that the industry's perception whether real or otherwise was detrimental to the promotion of an effective and non-discretionary anti-dumping policy.

Australian industry also expressed concern about the introduction of sunset provisions. The legislation currently prescribes that anti-dumping and countervailing duties lapse after three years. This provision has created great anxiety within industry because the termination of duties is automatic and final. At the end of this period industry must lodge a new application and re-prove injury. The Committee compared overseas practices in the US, Canada and EC and found that the Australian legislation went beyond what is required under the GATT Codes and the practices of other countries in requiring a complete re-testing before duties are reimposed.

The revised procedures introduced in 1988 also prescribed statutory maximum time limits as is the case in the US, Canada and New Zealand. A reduction of 40 days in the time taken to reach a preliminary finding, 135 days in lieu of 175 days, was announced by the Prime Minister in his 12 March 1991 Industry Statement. Following these changes only New Zealand has a shorter statutory time period within which a preliminary finding will be made compared to Australia. Australian industry welcomed this reduction although it favoured a 55 day time limit. While the Committee concluded that it was not feasible for the Australian Customs Service to make a preliminary finding at 55 days there was scope for improvement in the administrative processes. Statutory time limits commence from the date a dumping complaint is lodged. The time limits do not reflect the actual time taken to prepare a dumping application which may take up to six to twelve months.

In its Report the Committee has sought to dispel the complexity and confusion engendered by the legislation. The Committee has approached resolving industry's complaint in a number of ways. The Committee believes that the decision to establish an Anti-Dumping Authority as a separate statutory body to advise the Minister was not the only way to achieve a ``speedy and effective application of necessary measures to promote fair trade'' as recommended in the Gruen Report. This could have been achieved within the Australian Customs Service by establishing a Tribunal to review preliminary findings and appeals against negative findings. The Committee believes that a single body incorporating the specialised skills currently within both organisations should improve the processing and examination of a dumping complaint and reduce the current duplication. This matter should be addressed directly in the Government's review of the Authority.

The Committee was concerned that the injury suffered by a company or producer as a result of dumping or subsidisation should not be exacerbated by the high financial cost of mounting a dumping case. Differences between the Australian legislation and the GATT regarding the grounds for initiating a dumping investigation are examined in the Report. The Committee has made a number of recommendations to simplify the application requirements. The major recommendation is that applicants should only be required to provide information which is reasonably available to them. The Committee also recommended that a formal industry liaison service should be set up within the Australian Service Customs to ensure that dumping complaints are prepared and processed in as short a time as possible.

The introduction of sunset provisions has caused great anxiety within industry for the reason that an industry will be required to suffer injury before duties can be reimposed. The re-testing of an industry's application in this way is not required under the GATT Codes. More significant though is the Committee's finding that unlike the approach taken in Canada and the EC, the Australian legislation does not provide for a review prior to the termination of duties. To overcome this anomaly the Committee has recommended that the authorities undertake a review six months prior to the cessation of duties. The Committee has also recommended that the sunset period should be extended from three to five years. Acceptance of the changes to the sunset provisions will give Australian industry greater security and medium term anti-dumping protection at a time when general tariffs will be phased down over the next four years.

In addition to examining the operation of the revised procedures the Committee has addressed other concerns raised by industry during the inquiry. The more significant concerns related to the assessment of injury to producers of raw agricultural products, the collection and availability of import data and the threat to regional industry. These and other issues are discussed in the Report.
The Committee's responses to these matters are too detailed to summarise here. I would urge all Senators to study the Report and its findings and recommendations.
I trust the Government will give careful consideration to the Report and to the evidence the Committee received.
I want to thank my colleagues for their support and for the unanimity of view which the Committee was able to achieve.
I commend the Report to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Amendment Bill 1991 now before us gives effect to quite a number of changes to the Migration Act, some of them small adjustments and other significant alterations to policy. The Opposition is in agreement with much of the Bill. In the committee stage I will be moving the four amendments that were moved by my Opposition colleagues in the other House. That is not to say that we are happy with the Government's handling of Australia's immigration program-quite the contrary. This Government has been guilty of confusion, contradiction and uncertainty in its administration of this area throughout its eight years in office. However, this Bill does not arouse much criticism from the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill can be divided fairly readily into three areas. One is the introduction of new procedures for the handling of persons who arrive in Australia unexpectedly and without documentation, such as those who are sometimes called `boat people'. A significant series of amendments relate to them, including the late amendments which I will refer to at the end of my speech. A second area is some reform of the provisions for merit review. Thirdly, the remainder of the Bill covers other changes intended to improve in various ways the efficiency of the immigration program. In the interests of keeping my remarks brief, I will not run through the various clauses of the Bill with which the Opposition is in agreement. Rather I will refer only to those clauses where we have some criticism or comment to offer.

I refer firstly to clause 3(d) under `Interpretation' which adds to who can be an authorised officer under the Act. The Bill as originally introduced by the Government into the other place provided for `any person authorised by the Minister in writing for the purposes of this paragraph'. This caused some concern to the Opposition and the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, Mr Philip Ruddock, and he sought clarification from the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) as to what was intended. As well, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills expressed a concern. Its report stated:
The Committee generally does not approve of provisions which allow powers to be given to `a person', as it is preferable that there are limits on the person to whom such powers can be delegated.

I understand that the Government has in mind with this provision to allow for staff who might be engaged to deal with data processing arrangements. The Minister was willing to respond to the Opposition's concern by introducing an amendment in the other place that ensures that such authorisations may only proceed by notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and the Opposition welcomes that.

I next refer to the Government's proposals for character clearances. There are, in some cases, difficulties for people obtaining character clearances because the authorities in their countries of origin cannot, or will not, provide the necessary documentation. Times of war or civil strife may be the cause of this. The Government included in the Bill a clause that would allow a person in prescribed circumstances to make a declaration as to character or conduct. The Opposition was concerned that the clause as it stood could open up new areas for abuse and confusion in this important matter of character checking, and it seemed to us better that the Act should more precisely set out what should happen rather than leaving the detail to be prescribed in regulations.

The Minister, in his letter to the shadow Minister, admitted the possibility of confusion and that people may come to the view that character checking may not be done in some circumstances. The Minister then introduced amendments, which were passed in the other place, to insert new clauses so that now all applicants who are not Australian citizens will be required to make declarations about character or conduct. This should prove to be a wiser approach. Again, the Opposition welcomes the Minister's willingness to respond to the Opposition's concern in this regard.

The most significant new provisions in the Bill are for processing people who arrive here unexpectedly and without documentation. I use the term `processing people' while slipping into the use of too much bureaucratic language. We in the Opposition are very concerned to observe-and I am sure the Government is too-that those who emigrate to this country or consider doing so are real people with real concerns and real rights in their country of origin. When we talk about processing people, we are saying that we are processing the application for them to migrate to this country.

One Opposition concern about the Bill is the length of time for which people may be held in an unprocessed state. The Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee also expressed itself on this matter. The Minister's letter to the shadow Minister dealt with this and I think it may be helpful to the Senate if I quote the relevant sections of what the Minister said:

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee was concerned about the absence of a specific mechanism in the Act to allow a person to challenge being designated an unprocessed person. However, a decision to designate a person an unprocessed person would be a decision which could be challenged under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 on the basis that an error of law had been made in arriving at that designation.
That Act would allow for a declaration to be made as to whether a person is an unprocessed person. Proceedings under that Act are relatively easy to initiate and conduct. The Minister continued:

However, apart from relief of a declaratory kind from the Federal Court, it is not intended that there would be a mechanism in the Migration Act which would provide for the release of a person from a processing centre other than in compelling circumstances such as the need for medical treatment. It must be borne in mind that `unprocessed persons' will be persons who have arrived in Australia without permission, seeking to enter Australia in circumstances in which they would become illegal entrants and in which proper immigration, health, customs and quarantine clearance procedures have not been carried out. For the purposes of the Act, these persons have not entered Australia and are potentially prohibited persons. While clearance procedures are being conducted after the persons' arrival, the policy to be expressed in the legislation is that they be restrained from entering the broader Australian community.

Those last words, which I emphasise- `these persons have not entered Australia and are potentially prohibited persons'-are stated in an entirely bipartisan manner, in fact a nonpartisan manner, in this Parliament. We are not taking away one jot or iota from the principle that we have a sovereign government, an elected government, in this country and that government is determining the basis on which anyone will enter the country. The decisions of the Government as expressed by law in the immigration program are to stand. Persons who do not meet the criteria for immigration to this country and who seek to evade, or who have in any way evaded those procedures, remain as not having entered Australia and are potentially prohibited persons. The Opposition is concerned that some courts will still seek to buy into the sovereignty of parliamentary decision. It is a non-partisan principle-certainly it is bipartisan-and we want to reinforce the fact that the government of the day determines the immigration program.

The Opposition has strong views about maintaining the integrity of our immigration program and for that reason we will not offer any amendment to this part of the Bill. We would only want to strengthen it. Australia should not in any way send signals overseas, by seeking to accord specific rights to unprocessed persons, that might lead people to believe that those trying to get around our immigration requirements will be rewarded by being allowed to stay here by the use of any legal procedure, particularly those that would appeal to a court, to change their status.

There is one matter on which I will be moving some amendments when we reach the committee stage-that is, the question of the number of days permitted under the review procedure within which a review of certain decisions may be made at both the first and second tiers of review. The Government proposes in this Bill a substantial increase in the number of days so allowed. The Opposition believes that the new provision increases the number of days too greatly and is not balanced in its effect. I will address the matter in more detail at the committee stage, but I indicate now that this is one portion of the Bill with which the Opposition is not happy. That is the only area where we will be seeking to amend the Bill.

I have already stated the Opposition's concern for the integrity of the immigration program. We very much regret that at times over the past eight years the Government has made decisions that undermine that integrity and cause confusion and doubt about the direction of Australia's immigration policies. We recall the erratic nature of decision-making by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) personally. I have in mind in particular his pronouncements about certain Chinese nationals present in this country, a decision apparently made at an emotional time and without proper references. I believe the consequences are only now being grappled with by the Government and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

Apparently, Mr Hawke's decision was taken without the knowledge or consent of the Minister and without reference to the Department at the time. The Government displayed a very different approach to certain Cambodian boat people at about the same time. It is little wonder that people observe inconsistency and confusion in the immigration program. The Opposition wants to see a law which is clear, which restores public confidence in immigration, and which gives proper, compassionate flexibility and discretion to the Minister, on advice from the Department, in the way we have argued many times over the last two years.

Nevertheless, the whole principle that claims for Australian residence should be dealt with on an individual case by case basis has sometimes been lost sight of by this Government. The Government needs to show a willingness to provide sufficient resources for the processing of applications on an individual basis.

The most recent statement from the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs concerning illegal entrants in Australia was made recently, on 4 June, when he announced that the number of illegal overstayers as at 30 April was significantly down compared with the figure for the same day a year earlier. The whole tone of his press release was rather self-congratulatory, in fact. He told us what a wonderful job he was doing in this regard. Of course, any genuine fall in the number of illegal entrants is to be welcomed, but the matter is put in clearer perspective by the comments of the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Dundas, when he stated on 4 June:

The announcement by the Minister for Immigration, Mr Hand, that the number of illegal entrants in Australia has been significantly reduced assumes that the Minister is comparing like with like. On face value, of course, a reduction of 12 per cent in the number of illegals is welcome news. The Minister, however, provides us with a clue that statistics in this area are notoriously unreliable. He admits that the reduction in numbers is, in part, a result of overstayers regularising their status. This correlates with the significant increase in the processing backlog for change of status applications. Until recently, the number of on-shore claimants for change of status on refugee grounds were being processed at the rate of around 500 a year.
That is a very small number-500 a year. Mr Ruddock continued:

However, there are now 14,000 claims in the system and this number is increasing at the rate of 1,000 per month and expected to peak at 20,000 by the end of the year. The total number of people applying for grant of residence status in Australia, in all categories, has increased dramatically since the early 1980s, from around 7,000 in 1980-81 to over 36,000 in 1989-90. It would be interesting to see how the figures in this area have changed in the past 12 months. Added to this are the 20,000 Peoples Republic of China nationals in Australia prior to the Tiananmen Square incident who are eligible-
by the Government's announcement-
for four year temporary entry permits.

Without wishing to reflect on the integrity of the Minister, the statistics would be more meaningful if he could state quite categorically the number of illegals who had in fact left, or been forced to leave, the country, rather than being shifted from one category to another.

As I say, I have not spoken about the other particulars of the Bill to which the Opposition agrees. Those matters are understood, and there has been a great deal of constructive working together between Opposition and Government representatives. Actually, I commend the Minister and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs for the way they have approached this matter. The Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations continues to do very useful work, and it ought to continue in that work. This mode of non-partisan consultation and approach to this important area of migration ought to continue in this Parliament.

But for my reference to the late additional amendments, I conclude the main part of my speech by urging the Government to take seriously the criticisms of its policy and administration that the Opposition levels. We make our comments because of our very real concern for the fairness and integrity of Australia's immigration program. With the exception of the provisions to which I will be moving amendments, we welcome this Bill, and hope that the changes it makes will enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of the Migration Act.

In the final few minutes I have left, I wish to refer to the amendments that the Government has determined in the past couple of days to meet a particular situation. In many ways, that determination arises from a decision of the Singapore Government to put additional pressures on persons whose status is undefined or is in doubt in Singapore and who could be forced back to Australia. Recent reports that the Singapore Government has introduced new regulations restricting the movement of our international airlines have significant implications which need to be addressed urgently by the Australian Government.

The new regulations are said to give the Singapore Government the right to stop an aircraft leaving if its captain refuses to take on board a prohibited immigrant whom his airline has brought to Singapore. Thus, the Singapore Government can now issue an order to any Qantas Airways Ltd captain arriving in Singapore to carry out a prohibited person. The law says that the authorities may take such action or use such force as may be necessary to ensure compliance. They can order that the plane may not move until the immigrant is on board, and if the pilot refuses, he faces up to six months imprisonment.

I recently visited the Singapore Parliament and was happy to be welcomed there to see the very rational debate that was occurring in that chamber. The Parliament of Singapore is very aware of, and very committed to, maximising Singapore's own rights in any matter. This law passed in that Parliament has been introduced quite clearly to get Singapore off the hook in relation to Mr Francisco Vasquez, the Cuban immigrant whom Australia deported on criminal grounds and who has chosen to remain in Changi Airport rather than return home to Cuba. This action by the Singapore Government puts Australia's deportation laws at grave risk.

There is a provision in our law for criminal deportation for those who are found guilty of serious offences committed here in Australia. If we are forced by other countries to accept them back into Australia, our whole system of control is jeopardised. This move will affect not only criminal deportees but all undocumented arrivals, illegal entrants and refugee claimants as well. So, this issue has serious implications in international law and for Australian migration law, and in human rights terms, of course. It must be addressed as a matter of utmost urgency.

The one page of amendments to be moved by the Government in addressing this situation this week has the effect of safeguarding any person so forced back upon Australia to be out of the reach of litigation that might be commenced, to then have a change of status or seek the courts to intervene to order a change of status. That would be most unfortunate. If other countries force upon this country a person whom we have consciously deported, particularly on criminal grounds-but on any grounds-or if any other country forces to travel to Australia a person who does not meet the completed requirements to be a visitor or migrant to this country, then such an unprocessed person should not be able to be forced upon Australia, and by being in Australia physically have an appeal to the courts to evade the normal migration program.

I conclude by accepting the outline of the importance of these amendments proposed by the Government. I refer to just two clauses of the Opposition's immigration policy. The Liberal and National parties assert without qualification that it must be the role of the elected Government, acting on behalf of and with the support of the whole community, to make the final and absolute decisions on who will or will not be granted entry to Australia on a temporary or permanent basis. The first principle set out in our policy states:
No person other than an Australian citizen or a permanent resident of the Australian community has a basic right to enter Australia.

We are entirely supportive of what the Government is doing by these very late amendments to this Bill. We do not wish to see a culture continue in the Australian courts that makes operative in any way an appeal to the court over such principles as I have just stated. The Opposition commends the Bill and will very briefly move the amendments that I have indicated.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a correction to the explanatory memorandum relating to the Migration Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Amendment Bill 1991 was introduced into the House of Representatives on 17 April and passed by that House on 3 June. At that point, seven amendments were moved by the Government and agreed to, and four amendments moved by the Opposition were defeated. To quote the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), in his second reading speech, this Bill `reflects the Government's commitment to the continuing process of finetuning the migration legislation.'

SPEECH.PARA: The term `finetuning' is something of a euphemism. Whilst the Australian Democrats recognise the Government's good intentions in introducing fair and equitable migration legislation, the 1989 amendments to the 1958 Migration Act have required numerous further amendments, as have its original accompanying migration regulations, in order to redress its over-bureaucratic philosophy and many unworkable clauses. At the time of the 1989 amendments, it was described by the Australian Democrats as `legislation designed for bureaucrats by bureaucrats'. Subsequent amendments to the legislation and to the migration regulations have removed their over-bureaucratic tinge and brought them to a position of actually being pertinent to the needs of real people. The Democrats welcome this trend because, after all, that is what migration is all about: the movement from one country to another of real, living and breathing people.

The Australian Democrats would never want to see the interests of Australia set aside but, equally, we would never want to see the basic humanity of our fellow human beings set aside to fit in with the neat and tidy whims of bureaucrats who may make marvellous neat and tidy plans in their offices which may have little bearing on the realities and the needs of human beings.

At the time of the introduction of the new legislation in June 1989, the Australian Democrats brought forward more than 40 amendments introduced by then Senator Jenkins. All were defeated by the combined forces of the Government and the Opposition at that time. Since then, the Senate has passed many amendments brought forward by the Government very similar to those introduced two years ago by the Democrats, and we are about to do so yet again with this Bill.

The main provision of this Bill is the introduction of a new regime for the immigration processing of undocumented and unexpected arrivals, such as the boat people. Other provisions in the Bill introduce positive changes in the review process, improvements in the streamlining of immigration procedures and some further minor and technical amendments.

I refer, first, to the main provision that will affect the boat people and others who arrive without papers and due process from their country of exit. The original boat people in significant numbers were, of course, Vietnamese; now they are Cambodians. It is an obvious fact that Australia cannot provide a home for every person in the world who is persecuted, starving and dispossessed. It is equally obvious that basic humanitarian compassion demands that people who have risked drowning, piracy and being lost on the high seas, and who are fortunate enough to find themselves on our shores, cannot be turned back to certain torture, persecution or death.

Cambodia is painfully short of essential medicines and equipment in its hospitals. There is serious malnutrition amongst its children. Many children die each year from haemorrhagic fever, which causes severe haemorrhaging from all their orifices and causes death because of the lack of antibiotics and medicines to treat them. Desperate to leave this environment, Cambodians risk theft, rape, murder and piracy on the high seas. If they land in the northern parts of Australia-mostly in Western Australia or the Northern Territory-they will now become `unprocessed persons', which is a new expression in the Migration Act. These amendments provide an authorised officer with the power to remove an unprocessed person to a `processing area', which is also a new expression under the Act, where reasonable investigations and inquiries can be made about that person.

It is important that such people be treated sensitively. It is also important that orderly migration procedures be carried out. In the past, these tired, hungry, thirsty, frightened and desperate people were processed on, or close to, their boats. The amendments contained in this Bill make it possible for such people to be transferred in their family groups to more suitable processing areas where they can be examined in humanitarian conditions over a period.

It is obvious that identities and claims for entry into Australia should be thoroughly investigated. It is equally important that this should be done in a non-threatening environment. The investigations must be such that impostors and con people be discovered. However, this cannot be at the expense of decent humanitarian considerations for genuine refugees and asylum seekers.

It is significant that we debate this Bill this week as it is Refugee Week. This year marks the fortieth anniversary of the adoption by the United Nations General Assembly of the Convention on the Status of Refugees and the establishment of the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

Who is a refugee? The United Nations convention defines a refugee as `a person who is outside his or her country of origin and is unable to return home because of a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, social group or political opinion'. Only a small proportion of people who are of concern to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees are refugees in the sense of the convention. Many more have been displaced from their countries by war, famine and civil strife. Although they are not persecuted by the state in which they live, often their own government is unable in a practical sense to protect them against such threats. These people are equally deserving of our humanitarian support.

Australia is a signatory to the United Nations Convention and Protocol on Refugees. Our intake of refugees is approximately 10,000 to 12,000 per annum. The Democrats believe that this figure should be raised to about 20,000. It would be untenable for us not to continue to play our role in the acceptance of refugees. A hardening of attitude in countries of destination for refugees, such as Indonesia and Malaysia, means that boat people will continue to arrive in Australia.
Immigration lawyer, Adrian Joel, is very critical of government policy in this regard. In the Australian Law News of October last year Mr Joel said:

My view is that recent policy can be characterised by vacillation which will significantly limit an effective and speedy response to sudden arrivals . . . immigration policy, formulated on the premise of short-term political expediency, is imposed on the department.
He goes on to describe the debacle of asylum seekers and others wishing to migrate to Australia who use the overseas student program to suit their ends. Mr Joel states further:

. . . policies stupidly premised on an extraordinary level of naivety prevail. The result of such contradictory, ever-changing policy is that a broad signal has been sent to Asia that Australia is a destination where it is worth `trying your luck' by arriving in a boat . . .
There is also the saga of Chinese students and the confusing changes of policy by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Department of Immigration.

Refugees and asylum seekers often arrive in a traumatised state because of a history of terror and persecution. I refer to a report entitled Refugee Women-Still at Risk in Australia, which is a study of the first two years of resettlement in the Sydney metropolitan area and is authored by Eileen Pittaway, the Australian National Consultative Committee on Refugee Women, Refugee Council of Australia. From a report that contains many disturbing stories, the story of Mrs Consuelo Salinas stands out. In a report in the Australian of 3 June this year, it was pointed out that every day Mrs Salinas weeps for the years between 1979 and 1990 in El Salvador during which she lost a daughter who was pregnant, her father, five brothers, a sister, an uncle and nephews. She was also raped, tortured and shot. All of this at the hands of government agents.

I commend that story and this report to colleagues in an attempt to sharpen our picture of the sorts of lives that so many of the people coming to these shores have had and the sorts of suffering that they continue to undergo, even after reaching the haven of Australia.

There was a lot of public disquiet at media reports of 24 Cambodians being transported from Sydney to Darwin in May of this year. These people are still in the state of being regarded as `unprocessed persons'. Technically they are regarded as not having entered Australia. This legislation, by expanding the definition, and therefore the geographical location, of a processing centre, makes the necessary procedures more humane. How does the system work, and precisely where in the system are the Cambodians who arrived recently and were shifted in May?

On 26 October 1990, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) announced the introduction of the new system for determining claims for refugee status and humanitarian stay in Australia, which came into effect on 10 December last. The primary stage for applications to be assessed allows for quick decisions to be made on refugee status in some cases. Where it is deemed that not enough information has been provided to address concerns of natural justice, the applicant has a further seven days to provide additional material.

The second stage of the process, which follows where there is a negative assessment from the primary stage, or where it has not been possible to make a positive assessment, is in the form of a review. The review panel includes representatives from the Refugee Council, and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees can have an observer in attendance. The Australian Democrats applaud this move which will seek to deal with asylum seekers in a more compassionate and humane way.

I should add here that had either the Government or the Opposition agreed to amendments put forward two years ago by my former colleague, Senator Jenkins, when she pleaded for a more compassionate system for refugee procedures, this could have been addressed long ago. There has been criticism that an internal government committee will be making confidential recommendations to the Minister. It is argued that these matters should be determined openly by the Immigration Review Tribunal. Because of the sensitivity which is often present in claims for refugee status, which can place relatives and friends in the home country in danger, I do not believe that this is a practical proposal.

The Bill also deals with issues surrounding entry visas which can also now act as travel-only visas. The Bill deals with circumstances in which permanent residents may become illegal entrants; the requirements for a declaration about character or conduct, or both; the deportation of illegal entrants; and custody of prohibited entrants during the stay of aircraft in Australia. It provides for increased penalties for the carrying of undocumented persons to Australia. The Bill amends the review provisions, giving more generous periods of time for applicants in Australia and overseas. It provides for a review of remuneration to members of the Immigration Review Tribunal. It also makes minor and technical amendments.

As I said, amendments were made in the House of Representatives. I would like to mention some of the comments that the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills made on this Bill. The first area of criticism, which was addressed by the Government by way of an amendment in the House of Representatives, related to `the delegation of power to an officer'. The Committee had indicated that it generally does not approve of provisions which allow powers to be given to `a person', as it is preferable that there are limits on the persons to whom such powers can be delegated.

In the context of this Bill, the Committee noted that proposed new sections would, if enacted, allow an officer to respectively detain `an unprocessed person'-as defined by the Bill-or arrest that person without warrant. The Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee indicated that this is a significant power and one that should not be open to delegation without any restriction as to the persons or classes of persons to whom it should be delegated. The clause, therefore, was considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. The Minister subsequently moved a Government amendment to require that a person may only be authorised to be an officer by notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. This will permit greater public scrutiny of such authorisations than the requirement for merely written approval, as originally proposed in the Bill.

The second matter raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills is that classification as an `unprocessed' person carries with it certain significant consequences, including the liability to be detained or arrested without warrant. However, the Committee noted that there did not appear to be any provision within the legislation to allow a person to challenge his designation as an unprocessed person. The Committee suggested that if this was the case, it appeared that the only recourse for a person who disputes his designation as such would be a writ of habeas corpus or an action in trespass.
The Minister replied, in a letter to the Committee:

. . . apart from relief of a declaratory kind from the Federal Court, it is not intended that there be a mechanism in the Migration Act which would provide for the release of a person from a processing centre other than in compelling circumstances such as the need for medical treatment. It must be borne in mind that unprocessed persons will be persons who have arrived in Australia without permission, seeking to enter Australia in circumstances in which they would become illegal entrants and in which proper immigration, health, customs, and quarantine clearance procedures have not been carried out. For the purposes of the Act, these persons have not entered Australia and are potentially prohibited persons. While clearance procedures are being conducted after the persons' arrival, the policy to be expressed in the legislation is that they be restrained from entering the broader Australian community.

The Australian Democrats appreciate the concern expressed by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and note the Minister's answer. However, I would want to ask the Minister whether this issue can be further scrutinised by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, which now also scrutinises legislation.

I want to make a final general point. There has been a lot of debate in recent months on the cost of the immigration program and on the number of migrants who enter Australia each year. Post-World War II, the catchcry was `Populate or Perish'. Migrants were expected to do the dirty, unhealthy jobs that Australians preferred not to do. Australia continues to solicit for migrants on a skills basis, when our unemployment rates are at their present high level. The Australian Democrats believe that this is not appropriate for a `clever country'.

Former migrants now see their adult children out of work. It would make for better sense, in our view, to spend the money and effort on training and skilling, and re-training and re-skilling, of the population currently in Australia. The Australian Democrats would like to see the skills and, in particular, the business migration programs severely restricted and our continuing migration program emphasising family reunion programs, refugees and special humanitarian categories.

A further aspect of the debate on immigration policy is the question of population pressures on the environment. Particular emphasis, especially in recent months, has been on those pressures in the context of urban Australia-the continuing sprawl, particularly of our major capital cities. The challenge before us is to establish sustainable population for Australia and to frame our immigration policy within that framework, always giving due consideration, of course, to our humanitarian responsibilities as global citizens.

This legislation is supported by the Australian Democrats. It is proof of the positive part played by the Migration Regulations Committee in moving the Government away from a former immigration Minister's policy of trial and error-and there have been some errors since 1989.

In the area of migration legislation, a good idea by a bureaucrat, comfortable behind his desk, which leads to a trial full of errors, can result in devastation to people's lives. I have already referred to the awful traumas experienced by many refugees. All migrants and potential migrants suffer some sort of trauma to a greater or lesser degree. It is not an easy thing to leave the surroundings, culture and language that someone knows to settle in, what are for many, strange surroundings, with an alien culture and an unknown language. The hard, arrogant, overly-bureaucratic and often downright silly direction taken in the 1989 legislation is gradually being moved to a more rational, sensible, sensitive and workable one.
I would like to conclude in this, Refugee Week, with a quote from Mrs Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, who recently said:

. . . we must realise that the fundamental solution to the problem of refugees is to remove the root cause of their flight. The current situation may not be drastically improved overnight, since we live in a world made by human beings. But the fact is that we are all members of the global community, and it is our duty to make that world a better place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are only two points that really need to be responded to after this morning's debate which is, I think, overwhelmingly supportive of the Bill before the Senate. Senator Powell raised one point that needs a response; that is, whether the amendments can be considered by the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations. The Government draws attention to the fact that that Committee already has the capacity within its charter to look at the Act and the Act as amended. It would be up to the Committee to decide whether to pursue any further scrutiny of these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other point I make at this stage, given the fact that it is the last day of the session, and also recognising the support that the Bill has had despite some political points here and there, is in response to the amendments moved by the Opposition. We have circulated some of our amendments and I will address them in the committee stage.

At this stage we have considered the Opposition amendments. We do not support them essentially for two reasons. The first reason is that it should be taken into consideration that the Government's proposed amendment simply provides for a maximum period for the lodgment of an application at each level of review. It is open for the Minister to make regulations prescribing a lesser period. Given that sort of context, and the flexibility that is provided under the Government's approach, we would rather have the flexibility of an extra week. As a consequence we will oppose the Opposition's amendment.

The second reason is two-pronged: on the one hand there is already an awareness in the community of the 28 to 70 day concepts. We want to stick to that because to do otherwise, to do as the Opposition would request, would work against the applicants. I do not think anything more needs to be said at this particular stage and we can now move to the committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 17-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 18.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 18, page 11, before paragraph (a) insert the following paragraphs:

(aa) by omitting from subsection (1) `to be seeking to enter Australia in circumstances in which the person would become an illegal entrant' and substituting `would become an illegal entrant if the person were to enter Australia (whether or not the person is seeking to enter Australia)';
(ab) by inserting in subsections (1) and (2) `or until the person is granted an entry permit' before `or until';''.

At this stage I will not only speak to the Government's amendment on this particular clause, but I will speak also to all the Government amendments. The Government has introduced some amendments to the Bill which will strengthen the operation of section 88 and section 89 custody provisions of the Migration Act. The amendments are not extensive, but they do serve to underline the Government's intention to maintain effective control of Australia's borders under the Migration Act. The explanatory memorandum, which I will circulate in a few seconds, gives full details of the amendments.

The Government is concerned that the courts have been releasing from custody under the Migration Act people who have no legal entitlement to enter Australia. The amendments reinforce the existing custody provisions of the Act to make clear that custody ceases only in the circumstances as set out in the Act.

The amendments will also authorise migration officers to detain people who were deported from Australia and who have been returned to Australia by the authorities of another country. These persons should be capable of being taken into custody and not released by the courts, unless the courts do so in the circumstances set out in the Migration Act. As the explanatory memorandum notes, the Government believes that it must have the power to determine who can and who cannot enter the broader Australian community.
I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government's amendments and new clauses to be moved to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports all the Government's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also support the Government's amendments in recognition of the need for the Government to be in control of the question of who does or does not enter this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 19.
Amendment (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
(2) Clause 19, page 11, lines 25 and 26, omit paragraph (a), substitute the following paragraphs:

(a) by omitting from subsections (1) and (2) `to be seeking to enter Australia in circumstances in which the person would become an illegal entrant' and substituting `would become an illegal entrant if the person were to enter Australia (whether or not the person is seeking to enter Australia)';
(aa) by omitting from subsections (1), (2) and (3) all the words after `removed from Australia' and substituting `or the person is granted an entry permit';''.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 20 agreed to.
Clause 21.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

The speech read as follows-
MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL
COMMITTEE STAGE
SPEECH BY SENATOR BADEN TEAGUE

On behalf of the Opposition, I move the four amendments circulated in my name. In doing so, I am drawing attention to the amount of time provided within which people who wish to have a review made of a reviewable immigration decision can in fact seek that review.

The background to this matter is that when the Migration Act was being so substantially revised and brought into its present form, one of the issues that was the subject of discussion between the Government and the Opposition was this matter of the length of time to be provided within which people would be allowed to seek a review of a decision. There are two tiers to the review process, with the second tier being the Immigration Review Tribunal. What Senator Ray put into the Act at the time of that discussion between the Government and Opposition was something of a compromise, and was for a period of 28 days for people within Australia and 70 days for people outside Australia, and those periods were for people to exercise their review rights for both review stages within the time limit. What the Government is now seeking under this bill is to significantly liberalise the provision. It seeks to provide separate times for making applications for the two different levels of review. The Opposition does not object to that. It does seem reasonable to us to separate them out in this way.

However, we do not approve of the length of time that will now be given. In effect, the Government is seeking to double the time allowed, with two stages each of 28 days or 70 days. In other words, the total period allowed moves from 28 days to 56 days, or from 70 days to 140 days. The Opposition believes that this is too long. It is our view that such long periods compromise the immigration review process in an unreasonable way. They would allow people not to be expeditious in pursuing their rights. So much of our consideration of migration policy involves judgements about the best balance of the various factors involved, and this matter of the time for seeking review is one where we need to get the balance right between an adequate opportunity to appeal and the need for appeals to be made without undue delay.

It is our contention that the Government has judged the balance wrongly, and that is why I move these amendments. Our amendments would still be more generous than what is presently in the Act, but would cut back the undue extension of time the Government now wants to provide. Thus, we want to reduce the 28 and 70 days to 21 and 50 respectively at each review stage. In effect, that means in total 42 days for those within Australia and 100 days for those outside the country. This still compares generously with the present Act's provision of 28 days and 70 days. But it will better balance the review process and still require people to press their claims expeditiously. For those reasons, I commend my amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some brief remarks on behalf of the Opposition in relation to the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill, which seeks to amend the corporations law. Honourable senators would remember that the last time we debated the corporations law-which established the Australian Securities Commission (ASC)-it was to put into effect an agreement between the States and the Commonwealth to set up a new national corporations scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: At that time, we were in a similar predicament to the one we are in today. The legislation was rushed through the House of Representatives. It was one of the most complicated pieces of legislation put through in the history of the Australian Parliament yet it was given a very short time for debate and consideration by professional groups and corporations generally. Honourable senators would remember that at that time I suggested we would see a number of these amending Bills because it was impossible to create a corporations law in such a complex area of legislation in such a short time that did not require serious amendment. This Bill is already before us and another three or four amending Bills will be coming before the Parliament during the balance of this calendar year.

Late last year when the corporations law package came before this place there was considerable uncertainty because, unfortunately, in the Western Australian upper House, which is controlled by the Nationals and the Liberal Party, legislative councillors had some very severe and serious concerns about the setting up of the new centralised and national scheme. There was uncertainty among the business community as to what the effect would be. As I suggested to the Senate at that time, the uncertainty and the problems caused, particularly in Western Australia, were a consequence of the Government's legislative program and its inability to communicate that program effectively-particularly in the distant States such as Western Australia.

The need for the amendments contained in the Bill before us today are recognised and supported by the Opposition. I will go into the substantive issues shortly, but I want to spend a few moments talking about the transition to the new national scheme, because this is the first opportunity that we have had to debate this matter since its establishment on 1 January. During January and February, it was recognised by all people concerned with the establishment that there would be some teething problems, but the decision to move forward as quickly as possible with grim determination had bipartisan support. The old scheme was obviously tumbling away. It was becoming ineffective and it was a matter of getting the Australian Securities Commission structure set up as quickly as possible and, it is fair to say, solving the teething problems on the run-and there have been many.

I must say, as someone who was involved with the Western Australian opposition group-which was set up to oppose the national scheme law-and who had taken up a number of constituents inquiries in relation to the establishment of the new Australian Securities Commission and become a bit of an ombudsman on the scheme, that the problems we have experienced in the last six months have been solved very quickly and efficiently. It is certainly a credit to the personnel of the Australian Securities Commission in the way they have handled these matters. Indeed, there have been no major problems. There were some queue problems and some teething problems in relation to getting information and so forth. I think that, particularly in Western Australia, that could be blamed on the uncertainty caused in the upper House at that stage. It would have been unfair to have expected the Australian Securities Commission to get off to a very good start in Western Australia with those problems.

Because of the speed with which the Australian Securities Commission and the new laws have been implemented, in the last six months there has been uncertainty in relation to prospectus matters and in relation to the Australian company number provisions and how they should apply. All of these matters are being sorted out. One of the problems I have noticed-and I believe it is one of the concerns of the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr Hartnell-is that the corporations law establishes a number of bodies and committees to deal with the various matters under the jurisdiction of the Australian Securities Commission. There is the ASC Advisory Committee, which is already established and functioning, and the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities, of which I am a member and which has had a number of meetings and briefings. It is basically trying to come to grips with the new structure and is proceeding very well under the chairmanship of Senator Beahan and the deputy chairmanship of my colleague Senator Austin Lewis.

There is also the Corporations and Securities Panel, which is to comprise not fewer than five members-at least one of whom has to be nominated by a State or Territory Minister. The Australian Securities Commission advises that, to the best of its knowledge, these appointments have yet to be made. It is a matter of some concern that six months down the track the panel is not in place. I certainly urge those responsible to move towards making those appointments as quickly as possible. Another body is the Companies, Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board, which is to have three members-one nominated by the Minister and two selected by the Minister from a panel proposed by the accountancy profession. The Australian Securities Commission advises that no appointments have been finalised yet. I understand from information I have received recently that there are a number of matters that the ASC wanted to refer to that board for disciplinary action but is unable to do so because it is not in existence. Again, I urge those people responsible to move as quickly as possible to make those appointments.

Another body is the Australian Accounting Standards Board, which has an unspecified number of members to be appointed by the Minister. Apparently, some appointments have been made, but the advice I received from the Australian Securities Commission yesterday was that the board was, as yet, not fully operational. It must be of some concern that six months down the track-six months into the new national scheme-some very important parts of the structure have yet to be established. Obviously, it is fairly extraordinary to move into a new, vigorous and national corporate regulatory structure while we are rushing legislation through and the Government is not allowing adequate time for the professions and people affected by the law to be consulted. The Bill before us today was not given the three months exposure which was required by the Heads of Agreement, signed in Alice Springs. It was, I admit, given exposure for one month with the consent of the Ministers in the States. Even though it is not an ideal situation and the professions have not had time to analyse this amending Bill, there has been agreement by the Ministers in the various States.

Quite frankly, I would say that the success of the Australian Securities Commission and the corporations law in the past six months has been due mostly to the goodwill of all the people involved in establishing this structure-and that includes members of this Parliament, the Chairman and the Board of the ASC, the staff of the ASC, and the professions and the companies that are affected by the law. I also suggest that, to a large extent, it has been based on the grim determination of the Chairman, Tony Hartnell, to ensure that the Australian Securities Commission and the corporations law work and are effective.

To conclude, I shall run briefly through the substantive issues that the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 covers. It partially fixes some of the jurisdictional problems that were omitted in the initial corporations law. Those changes are welcome. Again, they are matters which to some extent were overlooked in the initial law. The Bill deals with a proposed new section 68a, which provides for certain exemptions in relation to Western Australia. Again, because of time constraints this matter could not be properly dealt with in the initial corporations law which passed through this chamber late last year.

The Bill also addresses some matters in relation to the Australian company number, which has caused concerns for a wide variety of corporations. The Australian company number was to be applied virtually to every public document or to every document that a company has or has to deal with on a day-to-day basis, including receipts, letters, cheques and so forth. This has caused a lot of concern for the many companies in Australia that would have to reprint all those documents. The Government, quite correctly, introduced a moratorium on that application of the company number, initially for six months and, owing to the complexities of the matter, it has now extended that moratorium to cover the first full year.

Those of us who have been involved in this issue have had many representations, particularly from real estate associations around Australia. We are aware that they are very concerned that, in doing things like placing classified advertisements, they would be required to place the company number on every single advertisement. I do not need to go into this, because the Australian Securities Commission is well versed in the concerns of the community in that respect. I have been assured that it is taking action to ensure that, when the Australian company number provisions do commence on 1 January, most of these problems will have been solved. To that extent, the moratorium has been a welcome concession and it has allowed time for all of those concerns to be discussed openly and to be addressed accordingly.

The other substantive issue that is covered in the Bill is the requirement for companies to comply with covenants in deeds and the ability of the Australian Securities Commission to use civil enforcement to enforce trust deeds. That, of course, is a very welcome amendment. There are also requirements for consolidated profit and loss and consolidated balance sheets for economic entities-another welcome amendment. Also, there is the obligation to comply with established accounting standards, and that is very welcome.

The substantial change, which I believe Senator Spindler will spend some time on, concerns the insider trading provisions. These provisions were brought forward late last year in an exposure draft, but the final provisions in the Bill are a lot narrower. I do not intend to concentrate on that matter today, because of the time constraints that are upon us all, and, as I said, Senator Spindler will probably deal with that matter in more detail. Suffice to say that the regulators and the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission are not happy with the provisions in the Bill. Of course, there is a very fine balance between onus of proof and proving insider trading practices, and prosecutions are very hard to achieve.

I commend the Bill to the Senate. It has the support of the Opposition-as does the whole aim of trying to improve Australia's corporate image, an image that was very badly tarnished during the 1980s. I think it is fair to say that, under the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities, there is strong and non-partisan support to ensure that the Australian Securities Commission and the new corporations law are successful and that we achieve all our aims in relation to lifting Australia's image both nationally and internationally in the corporations regulation area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 amends the Corporations Act 1989 and the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989. The Bill addresses the following matters: the winding-up of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC); the consolidation of the accounts of companies and subsidiaries for financial reporting purposes; reform of the insider trading regulations; conferral of jurisdiction on Family Courts in relation to civil matters arising under the corporations law; allowing the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) to regulate compliance with trust deeds; a statutory moratorium on the requirement for companies to include the Australian company number on business documents and negotiable instruments; and the requirement that retiring directors must notify a change in ownership of a company.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, in relation to the Australian company number moratorium, I welcome this proposal, although I must say that, as Senator Campbell noted, we have received numerous submissions on this matter and occasionally I could not entirely resist the faint glimmer of a suspicion that the objective was to delay the effective introduction of the legislation rather than be concerned about real difficulties with this matter. Nevertheless, I share Senator Campbell's view that this legislation is extremely important and that it would not have got off to a constructive and positive start without all parties cooperating, and in that sense I certainly welcome the Government's action in granting a moratorium on this requirement.

Broadly speaking, the Bill deals with a number of problems discovered in the original corporations legislation, including some of the jurisdictional questions only partially addressed in the Act. I note that further outstanding matters will have to be dealt with in another Bill, and I urge the Government to proceed with that as expeditiously as possible. I also note that it is proposed to involve the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities in assessing further legislation, and I welcome that. I feel constrained to mention that the initial contact of the Committee with the ASC and its Chairman, Mr Tony Hartnell, was extremely positive. The outline of the corporate aims of the Commission and the resources and personnel that are being marshalled to deal with the challenges ahead fills one with confidence that at long last we have reached a position where companies legislation in Australia will be effective and will raise Australia's image in the business world internationally.

There are some concerns relating to the provisions in the Bill. While I am not taking any of these concerns to the level of proposing an amendment, I believe that they warrant careful study by the Minister and action in the not too distant future. The consolidation of accounts of companies and subsidiaries will go a long way towards remedying the abuses of the 1980s, whereby the true financial position of a group of companies could be hidden by off balance sheet reporting. This amendment will mean that misleading investors in this way will no longer be possible.

Some concerns about these provisions were raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which objected to the so-called Henry VIII clauses, which enable some of the legislation to be effected by regulation. The Minister, in his answer to the Committee's concerns, states:

After due consideration it was considered important to allow this degree of flexibility to prevent technical evasion of the provisions of the legislation and to keep pace with evolving business practices.
