I believe that the Minister's answer is an adequate one to the concerns expressed by the Committee. I also note that these regulations may be disallowed by the Parliament in accordance with the normal procedure, so there is still a safety net which the Senate may use.

Insider trading has also been a matter of longstanding concern, and an attempt to deal with the problem is made in this Bill. As we know, the Griffiths Committee report on insider trading suggested major legislative and administrative reforms in this area. I believe that we are not yet at a level where we can say that we are satisfied with the legislation as it stands. In the exposure draft the onus of proof on two important matters was reversed and the defendant had to prove that the information he or she handed on or used was not generally available; secondly, that if it were generally available it might have a material effect on the price or value of those securities.

The result of the legislation as it stood before the reversal of onus of proof was found to be difficult to cope with by the prosecution, with the result that in most insider cases which so far have come before the court a conviction has not been obtained. I note the views expressed in the media by Mr Tony Hartnell that, unless some solution is found, it will not be possible, and indeed hardly worth while, to instigate successful prosecutions. It seems to me that it would be reasonable to ask the defendant to prove that information is generally available. That would be relatively easy to do, and I do not think it would be too onerous. I suspect, too, that that is a matter the prosecution could easily prove, so it does not get us very much further.

I would be a little concerned that legislation required the defendant to prove that, if that information were generally available, it would not have a material effect on the price or value of those securities. I am not prepared at this stage, without the support of either the Opposition or the Government, to move an amendment to reverse the onus of proof in this matter. I believe that we may perhaps consider in future tackling this problem from a different angle by establishing a number of criteria based on examples of past activity in this area as to how we judge whether the information could have had, or would have had, a material effect on the price or value of those securities. If we were to attempt to adjust legislation in this direction, I believe that the prosecution and the Australian Securities Commission may well find that it is not necessary to reverse the onus of proof; that the procedures and criteria established for proving these matters may be such that the legal process will bring to justice people who indulge in insider trading which damages our security system, our community and, last but not least, our reputation overseas.

The next matter I would like to deal with relates to the provision for the winding up of the NCSC. Another concern was raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, noting that there were no fixed dates for the legislation to come into effect. The answer provided by the Minister to the concerns of that Committee pointed out that the timing depended on the actions of other entities, in particular State governments, and that therefore it was extremely difficult to put in a firm date as to when this legislation could take effect. I believe that the answer is realistic in that it takes account of practical difficulties. I note the Minister's undertaking in his answer to the Committee that he will do everything he can to ensure that the Bill's provisions come into effect in less than 12 months.

An additional matter of concern to the Australian Securities Commission relates to use indemnities and derivative use indemnities. I note that this Bill does not deal with those concerns. However, I understand that a joint submission from the ASC and the Director of Public Prosecutions is now before the Attorney-General and that there is some prospect of getting some action in the near future.
I conclude by confirming that the Australian Democrats support the Bill, with the concerns expressed, on which we expect the Government to take the necessary expeditious action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some brief remarks on the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill and, to save the time of the Senate, I will ask a few questions of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins). If I gain a response from the Minister at the end of this debate, I will not need to raise these matters in committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular provision of the Bill in which I am interested relates to the requirement for companies to consolidate their accounts in accordance with the relevant accounting standard and the legislative provisions that seek to enforce that compliance. My concerns relate to the definitions on control and parent entities and the other definitions, which are referred to as being contained in the standard; but there is an additional clause which allows the Attorney-General by regulation to vary those definitions. It is a complicated way of ascertaining exactly what definition applies from time to time.

I understand that in regard to a number of accounting standards enforced by law a good deal of the material is referred to in the legislation as being definitions which are in the standard from time to time. That is not perceived as too vague in a legislative sense, because accountants who will have to apply the legislation obviously will be aware of accounting standards, the definitions therein and changes to them from time to time.

I am interested to find out whether the provision in this Bill that allows the Minister by regulation to make some sort of variation in that respect is found in all other legislative objects that apply other accounting standards. It seems to be a dual capacity for vagueness. The first capacity for vagueness is that people may not know from time to time what the accounting standard definitions are. I think we can accept that on the basis that the people to whom this legislation applies will know what those definitions are. If the Minister has this additional capacity-which I understand he does have-to vary that by regulation, then that is a matter of serious concern.

I would appreciate some indication from the Minister as to when the Government decided it would do this. Having made a speech in the last hour of the last day of the last sitting of 1990, I was somewhat surprised to read in the daily newspapers in early January-a time when Government announcements are not usually made-that the Government had finally decided to proceed and apply this accounting standard by law. I am very pleased the Government has chosen to do that.

I was even more surprised, only a couple of days after receiving a completed draft of a private member's Bill to achieve the same purpose, that is, to apply the international accounting standard in relation to consolidation of accounts, when Senator Schacht asked a question in this chamber of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, as to when the Government was going to proceed. It seems to be the quickest action the Government has taken. It announced in January that it was going to do something, and then when we came back in February of this year-if not then, it was in the March sittings-we found that the Government meant it and was going to proceed and legislation would be introduced in this session.

I know Canberra is a very small place and accidents do happen and that things sometimes come together at the same time. They say that great minds think alike, but I have not always given the accolade of a great mind to the Government. I am hesitant to say that that is the reason why I came to the same conclusion the Government came to at exactly the same time and had a Bill drafted at the same time as the Government. That run of events is quite extraordinary: someone can raise something in December; the Government says in January it will do it; the person has a private member's Bill drafted, the wording of which is complete in February; and then a few days later a senator in this chamber says to the Government, `Well, when are you going to do this?', and the Government announces that it is going to do it very soon. A few weeks after that, I must admit, the Government, finally produced its legislation, which, it is fair to say, is not dissimilar to that which was drafted for me.

Will the Minister in his response be kind enough to answer the question I have raised in relation to the ministerial capacity to vary the definitions, other than the variable capacity that the Accounting Standards Review Board would have? I think it is the appropriate body to apply the standard. If he would also make some remarks on exactly why it was and when it was that the Government decided to pursue this path, I would be grateful.

In South Australia we have had a number of problems with off-balance sheet companies. This Bill seeks in part-and that is the part I am talking about-to address the problem of those companies remaining off-balance sheet. I am particularly pleased to see that the Government has finally seen the error of its tardiness and is doing something about this. The capacity of companies to park very substantial amounts of debt that do not need to be put on their balance sheets has been a problem for shareholders who rely on the annual report to see what the company they have invested in is doing. For shareholders who might want to invest in a company it has been a problem.

It has particularly been a problem for super fund investors, who want to ascertain what to invest the assets of many millions of workers in on behalf of those workers. If the financial statements produced by companies do not give a true and fair view, and there is a clear case for saying that when consolidation is not required they do not always-plenty of examples indicate that they have not-it is a difficult matter for super fund investors particularly, because of the very large amount of workers' money they have, to see exactly what is going on. There is an additional problem for banks and their obligations in relation to their debt levels and asset levels. I am not sure of the extent to which the banks have been able to bypass those prudential requirements as a consequence of the availability of this off-balance sheet mechanism.

I raise two situations in my State that would be good examples of why South Australians might think this is particularly relevant legislation. One is Adsteam, where people were trying to work out for many months just exactly what this entity did contain. What had people invested in, what assets were there and what obligations or liabilities were there? It was a very difficult task. People at the lower salary level of the industrial order are entitled to look at those at the very top level of our industrial scene and wonder why those people are not as careful with the management of the assets entrusted to them by shareholders as the people at the lower salary echelons are with their own money and would be if you and I, Madam Deputy President, lent them $100. It seems an extraordinary situation, and Adsteam is one example of that.

The other example is the State Bank. We know that for some time South Australians were told that there was nothing wrong with the State Bank, everything was okay. We have been told that its problems have only recently developed, primarily as a function of a decrease in property prices and high interest rates. We were originally told about one off-balance sheet company. We finally found out that there was a pyramid of these companies in which the problems of the bank had been, to put it colloquially, parked. It is not worth taking up any more time. I am sure the Minister understands the problems that this part of the Bill is trying to address. I will be grateful if he can give me an answer to the two particular questions I raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address Senator Vanstone's questions before responding to the points made by other speakers during the debate. In respect of the timing of the Government's proposals, the Minister did announce in June last year that this approach would be taken by the Government. To get to the detail of it, Senator Vanstone's Bill was released on 19 April 1991. At that point the Government's Bill had already been drafted; the drafting had been completed. Despite that, Senator Vanstone's Bill was examined by both the Attorney-General's Department and the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel prior to the finalisation of the Government's Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question about differences between Senator Vanstone's approach in her Bill and the Government's in relation to accounting standards, Senator Vanstone's Bill approached the consolidation of financial statements by expressly saying that the proposed consolidation standard-the Bill refers to it as accounting standard ASRB.1024 consolidated financial statements-has effect by force of the Bill. The Government's Bill does not do that. It is capable of interpretation and enforcement in the absence, for whatever reason, of an accounting standard for consolidation of financial statements. This is not the case with the approach taken by Senator Vanstone.

The response to the specific question that Senator Vanstone asked about this approach of tackling accounting standards is that there is a very general agreement that the way to tackle the abuses which have occurred in this area is to move away from the formal, technical and, therefore, easily evaded touchstone of subsidiary and focus on the issue of control. There is also very general agreement that any new rules must catch unincorporated entities.

The proposed accounting standard for consolidation of financial statements contains detailed and carefully articulated definitions of the key concepts of control and entity. That standard has been developed by the accounting profession over a period of some years. The exposure draft was, in fact, issued in September 1987. As such, it has had the advantage of a lengthy deliberation and public comment in the process of refining the proposed standard.

It is appropriate to draw on that process of consultation by adopting these definitions. An advantage of this approach is that any further refinements to those definitions that are made by the Australian Accounting Standards Board to meet, for example, evolving Australian business practices, will apply automatically without the need to amend the corporations law.

Further, the amendments provide for regulations to be made, should the need arise, to add to or clarify the scope of definitions used in the standard. At some stage it may be necessary to adjust the scope of the accounting standard to take account of, for example, as I have said before, a change in the way that business is conducted in Australia. This could be done by the amendment of the standard by the Australian Accounting Standards Board or, alternately, by making regulations.

In respect of the matter that was raised during debate of the speed with which the new national scheme was established on 1 January, the Government had to take urgent action because the cooperative scheme had fundamental deficiencies and was, by the end of 1990, in a state of near collapse. It was acknowledged by all parties and governments that the new scheme had to be established quickly. This Bill seeks to clarify and resolve some technical difficulties which have been identified in the first six months of the scheme.

The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has foreshadowed that further clarification of the fundraising provisions and the Australian company number provisions will be included in a Bill to be exposed shortly for a period of three months in order to receive public comments.

Because of the urgency of reforms, the ministerial council agreed to limited consultation arrangements. However, the new policy in this Bill, namely the reform of insider trading regulations and the consolidation of accounts, has been called for over a number of years by the responsible sectors of the business community and the professions under the former cooperative scheme. This is the first opportunity the Commonwealth has had to proceed with these much needed reforms under the new national scheme.

All State Ministers on the ministerial council, the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee and its various subcommittees, have been consulted on the Bill and their comments have been considered and, where appropriate, taken into account in revising the Bill. The ministerial council has voted to approve the Bill under the new national scheme arrangements.

In respect of Senator Spindler's comments on the reversal of the onus of proof, given the increased resources provided to the ASC for law enforcement and the reported improvements in market surveillance by the Australian Stock Exchange, it was considered that a more cautious approach should be adopted at this time. Thus, the exposure draft provisions have been modified to restore the onus of proof in respect to this element of the offence to the prosecution and now accord with the recommendations of the Committee in this regard.

The insider trading provisions will, however, continue to be monitored to see whether they are effective in preventing insider trading and restoring investor confidence in the securities market. In particular, the issue of the onus of proof under the new law will be kept under close review.

In respect of the concern that Senator Campbell raised regarding the timing of the establishment of bodies under the ASC Act, the Commonwealth had to undertake consultation. The Companies Orders and Liquidators Disciplinary Board was appointed on 24 May this year. The Australian Accounting Standards Board was appointed in February this year and four further members were appointed on 14 May this year. I would like to conclude by thanking honourable senators for their contributions to the debate and their support for the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1991 substantially seeks to amend the Training Guarantee Act which passed through the Parliament last year. I will be brief because there is little in the Bill that needs to be discussed. It is very tempting, of course, to redebate the original issue and go through all the reasons why we opposed and still oppose the original legislation which we regard as being totally inadequate in terms of providing training for those who need it. I am tempted to spend half an hour telling anecdotes that all of us have heard from firms about the administration of the Act and the way it is operating, the hardship that it is imposing and the additional costs that are being inflicted upon so many firms, especially those which have a good training record. But there is little point in spending the time today to do that when we have such a heavy program before us. I shall limit myself to speaking about the issues.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth looking at the explanatory memorandum which discloses what is in the Bill. We are told in the first paragraph that the Bill gives effect to the undertakings made by the Government in relation to outstanding trainers-a matter that has been raised by the Opposition; that it clarifies the intentions of the original legislation; and that it makes provision for recognition of alternative training levy schemes. These are all matters that we were talking about before. The explanatory memorandum states that `the Bill rectifies an earlier anomaly and gives effect to the Government's undertaking'. Again, we are told that `the Bill rectifies an unintentional limitation'. Further on, the explanatory memorandum states that `the provisions relating to the definition of eligible training are altered' and `the Bill makes provision for alternative training', et cetera.

The explanatory memorandum highlights the deficiencies of the original Bill. It highlights the reason why the House of Representatives should not rush through, and not give adequate consideration to, legislation in the way that it does. These matters were raised in the Senate but the Government was not interested in hearing about them at the time. Unfortunately, we were not able to make the amendments then which really ought to have been made.

I reiterate that we are totally opposed to the concept. Even though we recognise that as the legislation is on the books, it needs to operate much better than it does at present. However, we are supporting these amendments. Many firms which have a very good training record have incurred incredible expense in order to comply with the provisions of this Act. They have to keep a paper record of all the things that they do. This means that either they then have less money to spend on training or incur greater cost in providing their service, whatever it might be. In the end, of course, it is the consumer who always pays.

We hope that this Bill will make some changes to the way in which the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Act is operating, and that people will be able to comply with it more readily. It still does not adequately deal with those companies and firms which have a lot of itinerant workers and it still does not adequately deal with those who have a lot of part time workers. It does provide for exemption for those who have a proven record in training, although even now that is not clearly defined.

I have a letter from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) in which he recognises there may be further changes required to this legislation, and I will seek leave to incorporate that letter shortly. What a pity the Government did not get it right the first time and save so many businesses and firms the cost and the anguish of trying to comply and find out from the Taxation Office what it all means, because they are under self-assessment. They can be caught up with for seven years as if they were criminals if they get it wrong, even with the best motives.

I wish also to refer to the private member's Bill-the Training Guarantee (Guidelines) Bill 1991-which I introduced on 17 April 1991 to clear up other anomalies in relation to professions that are small in the States in which they operate-the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and Tasmania, and there may even be some in the other States-which really were disadvantaged by the way the Act was worded originally. I introduced a private member's Bill when previously the Government did not seem to understand what I was talking about. I asked the Government whether it would allow that Bill to be dealt with simultaneously with this Bill. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training was not disposed to do that, and actually quite reasonably pointed out in his letter to me that what I wanted to achieve should be done by the guidelines. I agree with that, except that the Minister would not do it by the guidelines before. Thus I had no choice but to introduce a private member's Bill. In his letter, the Minister, in part, says:
I believe that, if further changes to the guidelines are necessary, it is more appropriate to make a further guideline, rather than introduce a Bill on the matter.
Of course, he has to accept that I cannot introduce a guideline; I can only introduce a Bill. He further states:
For these reasons, I believe there is merit in your proposal to remove the size restrictions.
It is always nice to hear that there is merit in one's proposal. The letter continues:
However, it would be more timely to further consider your proposal along with a possible further amendment to the guidelines in the Budget sittings 1991.

For that reason, I have elected not to proceed today with my private member's Bill because, if we allowed the Minister to bring in his guidelines but the Government took a stubborn approach and it were not passed by the House of Representatives, we still would not have achieved anything other than perhaps a warm inner glow for having the matter pass through this chamber. I know that it would pass this chamber because Senator Bell agreed that what I was proposing was reasonable, he being a Tasmanian senator and encountering the same representations as I was.

I shall not go into the matter further other than to say that we support the Bill but still totally oppose the underlying philosophy. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter to me from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, dated 6 June 1991, in which he deals with the Bill that I introduced in April this year, so what he has said is on the public record. In other respects, I wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Employment, Education and Training
Parliament House, Canberra, ACT, 2600
6 JUNE 1991
Senator Margaret Reid
Senator for the ACT
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Reid

I refer to your letter of 6 May 1991 to Senator the Hon Nick Bolkus, Minister representing me in the Senate, proposing Government support to your Private Senator's Bill which would amend Industry Training Agents' Guidelines No 1 of 1990 under the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990. Senator Bolkus has passed the matter to me for reply.

Industry Training Agents Guidelines No 1 of 1991 is about to be tabled for consideration by the Parliament. This instrument will give effect to my undertaking to the Opposition that TAFE colleges and higher education institutions would be included among the categories eligible for registration as an industry training agent. This would be subject to the responsible Minister in the State or Territory concerned giving approval to a TAFE college to apply for registration. Provision is also being made for a number of technical changes to the guidelines, in line with my undertaking to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

I believe that, if further changes to the guidelines are necessary, it is more appropriate to make a further guideline, rather than introduce a Bill on the matter. The Act specifically provides for such guidelines to be made by the Minister, as disallowable instruments, subject to any relevant recommendations from the National Training Board (NTB). Further, in view of the already pressing legislative program, it would be a more efficient and effective use of Members' and Senators' time to handle the matter in this way.

As I understand your proposal, the intention is to remove the size limits of certain categories of industry, professional and trade associations which are currently part of the eligibility criteria to be registered as an industry training agent. Instead, you propose that the association concerned would be required to satisfy the criteria that it is generally recognised as representing the interests of the relevant industry, profession or trade.

The size limits in the guidelines were determined after extensive consultations with State and Territory governments and industry. The States and Territories were concerned that the authority and expertise of the training authorities and the tripartite industry training advisory boards should be maintained by limiting the eligibility to tripartite bodies.

For its part, industry considered that industry training agents should be appointed if they had sufficient representation and expertise in their particular industries. For similar reasons, professional and trade associations felt that they could provide a particular service to their membership. The NTB took the view that the number of industry training agents should be contained, taking account of industry needs, NTB workload and quality control requirements.

I take your point that smaller associations in Tasmania, Northern Territory and the ACT might not be as readily able to register as their counterparts in larger States. This is because the larger organisations would meet the size criteria under Categories B or D, whereas the smaller organisations would be subject to later consideration under Categories C or E, having regard to the registration outcomes under the other Categories.

For these reasons, I believe there is merit in your proposal to remove the size restrictions. However, it would be more timely to further consider your proposal along with a possible further amendment to the guidelines in the Budget Sittings 1991. There is insufficient time in the current Sittings to obtain the necessary advice from the NTB about your proposed changes, to consult States and Territories, and to arrange the drafting and tabling of suitable amendments.

In the meantime, I would encourage applications from smaller organisations as they are not necessarily excluded by the registration of larger organisations, and the NTB must consider all applicants under the guidelines as they presently stand.
I thank you for your constructive proposal, and assure you that I intend to address it in time for resolution in the Budget Sittings 1991.
Yours sincerely
John Dawkins

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also support the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill. Whilst not sharing opposition to the basic underlying philosophy as just expressed by Senator Reid, we do also acknowledge Senator Reid's persistence in that, if we are to have this, we are to have it right. Like the Australian Democrats, she has insisted that there are many anomalies in the original legislation which could and should be addressed. I am pleased to say it appears that a considerable number of them are being addressed by this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill includes important amendments relating to outstanding trainers and to fees charged by industry training agents-changes which were originally proposed by the Australian Democrats. It also provides for the establishment of alternative industry training schemes, without the risk of a double set of training obligations.

Dealing first with fees charged by registered industry training agents (RITAs), the Democrats are pleased to see that the Government has taken up our suggestions regarding the fees charged by the RITAs. However, that begs the question: if this alteration is good enough now, why was it not good enough in the original legislation? The amendments mean that, instead of a fixed fee of $200 for the issue of a training advisory certificate, the RITAs will be able to charge a maximum fee of $500 on the application for a certificate. That means that the RITAs will not have any pressure placed upon them to actually issue a certificate before they receive the money for the services rendered. In other words, they receive the money for the time spent on it, as soon as the application is made, whether or not a successful certificate is issued.

Only 54 certificates have been issued by RITAs to this date, although the Tax Office reports that RITAs have effectively filtered a considerable number of other queries without necessarily being asked to issue a certificate. That indicates that their advice is being sought. This amendment provides that that advice can be charged for, and that is a much more equitable position, because the RITAs can and do serve a most useful function.

The Bill gives effect to undertakings given by the Government with regard to outstanding trainers. The concept of outstanding or exemplary trainers was originally proposed by the Democrats. Its purpose is to recognise the consistently high level of training that is already conducted by some Australian companies. Under clause 8, employers with exemplary training records may be accorded outstanding trainer status. Thus they are exempted from the requirements under the Act for a three-year period.

In his March economic statement, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced that, in order to achieve outstanding trainer status, employers will need to spend at least 5 per cent of payroll on quality structured training. I know that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, also endorse the concept of quality training. Measures must be implemented to ensure that, when talking about training, we are not talking about charlatanism or activities posing as training, such as trips. There must be quality structured training to qualify in this regard. We endorse the amendment that brings about that situation.

However, it is most unfortunate that, with the end of the financial year upon us, we are yet to see the regulations for outstanding trainers. In other words, they will only exist after this provision is passed today-a little late, we believe, especially considering that the concept was raised some months ago. Whilst we have not yet seen the draft regulations, we have faith to expect not only quantity but separate quality tests which are independently audited and verified. Because this sounds so good, it means that the delay is even more regrettable.

With regard to alternative training schemes, the current Bill also contains important amendments relating to alternative training schemes. Again, the Democrats lobbied strongly on behalf of some industries for a broad basis for exemption of alternative industry schemes. Many of these have been tried in the past, and some are operating successfully now. The provisions which exempt the building and construction industry, something about which I know a little, include the training provisions which I believe were initiated through very good intentions and, in fact, were established in a very sensible and equitable manner. That building and construction industry now has provision for exemption contained in the Training Guarantee (Administration) Regulations. They had been seen as too industry specific.

Instead of an exclusive exemption for just one industry, the Democrats argued that a general broader basis for setting up alternative schemes needed to be made. In all fairness, any industry should at least have the opportunity to try to devise a more suitable scheme for its own purposes. Apart from the building and construction industry, other industries are interested in trying to develop their own training schemes. Obviously, where we find a more suitable alternative, the concern is not to impose a double set of obligations, especially if the industry has been able to initiate it without the sort of coerciveness that is implicit in this scheme. The coerciveness implied in the scheme is perhaps the fundamental reason for the coalition's objection to its underlying philosophy. It is most unjust to have something else applied over the top of an industry which has initiated its own training scheme.

The Democrats recognise that this Bill proposes to make fairly substantial amendments to a piece of legislation which came into force on 1 July 1990. This point was noted by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which expressed concern in its report that persons upon whom this legislation imposes significant obligations will have to refer to at least two separate pieces of legislation, if this Bill is enacted, in order to understand those obligations. That is a considerable problem for the industry. There is an understanding that something has to be done and that there are some rules applying to it, but there is, and there has been for some months, considerable misunderstanding or uncertainty about exactly what those obligations are.

The Minister's response to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee was that a reprint incorporating both pieces of legislation, the principal Act and this amending Bill, will become available if and when this Bill is enacted. That is a most admirable process. On this point, I simply urge the Minister to ensure that any reprint is produced and made available to employers, trainers and others in the community at the earliest opportunity-right at this moment, the end of this month-because there is a great deal of interest in exactly what the obligations of industry are.

I will be seeking some explanations at the committee stage about some concerns expressed to me by members of the industry. As I have already mentioned, the scheme does have its detractors. I suppose there is some degree of credibility in the argument that it should have been postponed until everything was clarified. We cannot do much about that now. Given the depths of the recession that we are just climbing out of, apparently, it is probably just as well that this training guarantee scheme is already in place because the argument about whether it should be in existence has already been run and won.

It has been suggested that during a recession training is the often first thing that is cut. That is not obvious to all people, but it is contended that that is the wrong decision to make: training is the very last thing that should be cut. At least I think we are doing the right thing by following this requirement through now. When re-emerging from any recession it is important to develop people's skills. The first thing that is needed is a new set of skills to deal with the expansion of industry which will occur.

I take this opportunity to look briefly at the operation and effect of the training guarantee scheme in its first year of operation. Under the scheme, employers with payroll tax obligations of $200,000 or more are required to spend one per cent of their payroll on training. In the first quarter after the scheme's introduction, 24 per cent of employers reported spending some money on training. That was an increase from the previous year where 22 per cent of employers reported spending some money on training. These figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics relate to all employers in the category of employers with a payroll of over $200,000-who are therefore subject to the training guarantee scheme-which comprise between 5 and 10 per cent of employers. They employ between 85 and 90 per cent of the work force.

The Australian Taxation Office reports that, in the first quarter, the proportion of affected employers whose expenditure was under one per cent dropped from 75 per cent to 56 per cent. That is a significant indication that those employers in that category were being pushed towards meeting the sorts of obligations which were put on them by this scheme. According to a report in the Australian of 19 June 1991, a recent survey by Price Waterhouse Urwick Management Consultants found that most public and private sector organisations spend between 5 and 20 per cent of their payroll on training. Most organisations were also found to have either completely unstructured or ad hoc training and they have had to modify existing training programs to comply with the Act. That is the other element that I am sure also entertains you, Mr Acting Deputy President.

The other effect of this Act has been to create a structured approach which leads to quality training. Training is one of those aspects of industrial activity which is not solved merely by throwing money at it. In a structured way it is much more successful. Training must be providing, maintaining or improving an area of skill, knowledge or competence for use in employment, present or future, or in carrying on a business, profession, trade or occupation.

Eligible expenditure on work-related training is not restricted to a company's employees. It may also consist of monetary donations to universities and technical and further education colleges or to registered charities that operate training schemes. According to the Australian Taxation Office, affected employers are spending 2 : 1 in-house on internal training rather than shopping it out to colleges or whatever.

The Assistant Commissioner of the Training Guarantee Branch at the Australian Taxation Office, Mr Chris Hood, also said that qualitative research shows that employers are being extremely fussy about what they will spend their money on externally, which is bad news for the carpetbaggers and good news for quality training. Mr Hood said that, by and large, employers were not interested in trying to get disguised holidays. In one case there was a suggestion that employers should buy into Gold Coast time-share apartments, but Mr Hood said that none were sold. So the carpetbaggers have had a lean time in this area. Again, that is good news for quality trainers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time will tell.

—Senator Watson suggests that time will tell. The indication is there already that quality training is being endorsed and picked up in this regard. The initial indications are that the fears we might have had, and fears which are being addressed by this amending legislation, may not be all that well founded and that, in fact, it is good news.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than industry forfeiting its training money and having to pay a tax straight away, the Democrats suggest another option which allows employers to keep their training money for their own benefit or for the benefit of the industry. That involves industry groups establishing their own training fund to receive donations from employers. Those payments would be eligible training expenditure and tax deductible, and employers could build up credit for training within their own industry. That is slightly different from where the industry groups have established their own training programs.

We would encourage employers to recognise their obligations, which by and large we believe are theirs, wherever possible. Now that the obligation is there, they should meet the challenge-again, I believe they are-with the improvements that we see before us with this Bill. After a most uncertain beginning, we can have some improvement in this area and at least reach a situation where we can say that the employers of Australia are able to spend money wisely and look forward to the training opportunities that arise in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1991 contains four main amendments relating to alternative training schemes, the treatment of partnerships and unincorporated associations, and the exemption of outstanding trainers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is opposed to this type of legislation. which is yet another example of government interference distorting the marketplace. The Opposition was concerned about this legislation when it was introduced almost a year ago. It saw the legislation as a tax on the employer that would add to operating costs. The Opposition saw it also as legislation that would operate in a very uneven fashion. It was legislation which adopted the mechanism of the sledgehammer in circumstances where alternative mechanisms were more desirable.

The Opposition will support this amending legislation because the amendments will make the legislation less objectionable than it is currently; it makes bad legislation slightly more bearable. However, the Opposition still has reservations about the training guarantee system, as the legislation is one of those meddling interventionist measures that we should not have.

We have an urgent need in this country for a more highly skilled and better trained work force. The number of training hours invested per employee indicates that, compared with our overseas competitors, Australia invests the lowest number per new employee on an internationally competitive scale.

The Deveson report claims that Australia is `now arguably at the back of the pack in skill formation relative to other OECD countries . . . '. Successful countries, such as West Germany and Japan, have long surpassed Australia in the provision of training skills for young people. In a culture which rewards and admires achievement and the attainment of excellence, such as Germany's, there are clear, well-resourced, well-funded and industry recognised training schemes and a great diversity of training opportunities.

In West Germany today, almost 80 per cent of teenagers, virtually all of those not attending university or college, are undertaking some form of training course. This does not compare particularly favourably with Australia, which has a national average of only 20 per cent of young Australians receiving a vocational education. The only other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) country with a worse record than Australia is Greece. The OECD average is about 50 per cent.

However, the answer does not lie in government interference and more government regulation. These statistics have already shown no improvement since the training guarantee scheme was introduced a year ago, and nothing will change under an interventionist scheme which is the Government's panacea for all of our skilling problems in industry.

The Opposition supports training in Australia, but it must be in the context of open and flexible training. The development of private sector training would have a significant impact on the development of training programs in Australia. The Professor of Adult Education and the Executive Director of Training and Development Services at the University of Technology, Sydney, Professor Rod McDonald, provided some alternative solutions, but they are quite different from the professional trainers, which are so essential to the Government's training guarantee scheme. Professor McDonald says that training is the responsibility of everyone in an organisation. The major trainers are people such as line managers, supervisors and shop floor workers rather than professional full time trainers. He says that what we need is a work force that both is well trained and can train well. All it requires is a little imagination to deliver training when and where it is needed.

The single most important skill for all workers is to learn how to learn. Nothing that they learn will serve them for ever. Workers need to learn to take some responsibility for their own training. The more the worker learns how to train himself or herself, the more that worker can contribute to the company. For example, in major banks a terminal in a branch can deliver a mini-tutorial to a new teller if training assistance is needed. This is something that banks provide but which the workers can use to train themselves. The ICI group has turned routine plant shutdowns into learning opportunities. Other manufacturing industries could follow this example when processing plants have to stop processing for maintenance.

The University of Technology, Sydney and Lend Lease Training have developed a program that develops simple skills such as writing and working in an organisation through to preparing training resources, motivating others and using reflection as an aid to diagnosing their own training needs.

One kind of training exercise which companies do not need is the two weeks on Dunk Island for staff development of senior managers. Training staff to train itself and to assist in the training of others in the organisation is a cost effective solution, unlike calling in a professional trainer who will not be familiar with the particular needs of an organisation.

Unfortunately, this highly regulatory Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) does not believe in imaginative and effective training engendered within an organisation. He defines `training' as `structured learning delivered by a qualified trainer resulting in an assessable outcome' and specifies that training programs which are not designed by a person with appropriate qualifications must be approved by such a person in advance of their delivery. Many businesses are already engaged in training. It should be their responsibility to make the decision on what sort of training they give employees, where they give it and for how long. It should be an individual enterprise decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of matters in relation to this Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill. Do we have a Minister in the chamber?
—He is making a phone call; he will be back in a minute.

—For the life of me, I wonder why I should bother to put my questions briefly instead of waiting for the committee stage if there is no Minister here to answer them. Mr Acting Deputy President, what should I do? I want to speed up the process of these Bills, but talking to thin air because the Minister is outside listening to a phone call seems a bit extraordinary. Perhaps, Mr Acting Deputy President, you could offer some advice or perhaps, by leave, I could sit down and the Whip could offer some advice as to how he chooses to conduct the Government's business without the presence of a Minister. It does seem somewhat extraordinary. Why do we not just post him our speeches so that he can reply as it suits him? If, Mr Acting Deputy President, you wish me to sit down to allow you to ask the Whip what in heaven's name is going on, I will be happy to do that.
—By leave, the Whip may discuss the issue.

—The Minister had an urgent phone call. He asked me could he go out and take it, and I said yes. The Minister's advisers are taking notes and, on his return, they will advise the Minister of any questions so that he can answer them during the debate.

—On a point of order-I heard what Senator Jones said, but I note that this is the second occasion on which Senator Button has left the chamber during this debate. I know that he was absent for most of the contribution by Senator Tierney. I hope that Senator Button comes back to the chamber in the interests of trying to proceed very quickly with this legislation. Owing to time constraints, I did not raise a point of order when I noticed that Senator Button was out of the chamber earlier, but I hope that we will get him back in a hurry.
—I call Senator Vanstone.
—I am grateful to be advised that Senator Watson probably knows all the answers to my questions, perhaps more so than the Minister does. So he might like to answer them.

SPEECH.PARA: What I would like to have done, if the Government had managed its business properly and the Bills had been in time for us to deal with them in a proper order, was to get properly stuck into the training guarantee scheme. It is an outrageous bungle by the Government. It is no better than the Australian traineeship scheme. Some honourable senators will remember that we had the now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promising 75,000 traineeships per annum by the time of our bicentennial year. We never got past 14,000 or 15,000 in total, I think. Let us be gracious and say that we got 15,000 per annum. Whenever the Government touches training, it gets it wrong.

We have only to look at some headlines to see what has happened. If I had more time I would go into this more deeply: `Fun in the sun, and it's tax deductible'; in the Australian Financial Review, `Exotic Locations for Training'; in the Canberra Times, `Warning about confusion in advice on training programs tax claims'. That is, the Public Service had not properly got its act together; the Government has not advised it what to advise people about what to do. So there are tax bungles all over the place because of the inadequacy of the planning for this program.

Another headline reads, `Government trainer out of cruise boat course'. That was nice and embarrassing. I think the relevant Minister had a staffer, or someone in his Department, off on one of these cruise boat training programs. At great embarrassment, presumably at the expense of the taxpayer, he was called back from attendance at that program. There are complaints by the Real Estate Institute of Australia that its matters have not been dealt with because they have not necessarily employees but commissioned sales people. They have a problem with getting up their one per cent since they cannot count training of their commissioned sales people because they are not employees.

The detail has not been attended to, as was the case with the Australian traineeship scheme. Such things do not sound like a bad idea when the Minister is in Cabinet and wants to get away to do something else in his own portfolio. Everyone says, `Yes, that is a good idea'. It is like motherhood-it sounds good. It all goes down quite well, but the detail has not been attended to. It is just blithering incompetence. Staff training is now a lucrative rort. What a disgrace that something we all agree is important to the development of the nation in order to increase the productivity of the nation-that is, better training of our staff-has been so badly bungled by a government that claims to be competent.

In the magazine Training Australia: Incorporating Presentation Technology it is said that if I want to buy something in a resort in Queensland and use it as my training facility, I can do so. Just about the total cost will fall into acceptable training expenditure. I will not hold up the Senate on this. I cannot find the particular advertisement at the moment, but perhaps when I finish, if I have found the advertisement, I will wave it at the Minister and he can say what he thinks about a program that allows for a training deduction to be achieved in that way-that is, not much money is spent on training and a lot of money is spent on capital investment.

This is the Government that says it is looking after the workers and the poor and claims that we are looking after the rich. Yet here we have a training scheme designed so that those companies that can afford it can slip into Mirage resort deals and get a tax break for having done so. It is quite extraordinary. The Minister will have a job answering these matters.

The more technical matter I want to raise relates to penalties and fines and the charging of people. As you would no doubt be well aware, Mr Acting Deputy Chairman, if a company commits an offence under this legislation, there is a set amount, a maximum, of penalty it can go to. That is well and good. It is the same for a small business operator. But what about partnerships? A legal firm such as Corrs may have 120 partners. All of those partners in some way have been a part of the decision to go down a particular training path that may later turn out to be wrong. That would be no surprise, given the extraordinary range of advice being given to people on these matters. In a legal firm with 120 partners every one of them can be individually liable.

The relevant Minister, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), responds by saying that partnerships are not separate entities in the sense of a company and that if these individual people play a part in the decision they should be individually liable. That has extraordinary consequences for partnerships. Lawyers, for example, do not have a choice about how they conduct their business. They can choose to be sole business practitioners, but they cannot incorporate. A lot of the decisions they make are made as a group; the whole partnership takes responsibility for those decisions. So every one of them can be liable under this legislation. It is just ludicrous. It is a penalty for the way people choose to operate. In the case of legal practitioners, it is a penalty for the way they have to operate.

There is a reversal of the onus of proof, which in itself on some occasions has been found acceptable by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Why? Because the matters relating to the prosecution are peculiarly within the knowledge of the person alleged to have committed the crime. In this case that will mean that the Director of Public Prosecutions can launch a prosecution against every partner to save the bother of ascertaining whether certain partners are responsible rather than others. The onus is then on the partners themselves to show that they had nothing to do with this. That is just fundamentally wrong. It is very lazy drafting, because someone could not be bothered figuring out how to handle partnerships. I would appreciate an answer from the Minister as to the detail of this matter, otherwise I will have to take it up in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —About a year ago when I rose to speak on the training guarantee Bills I said that they were quite inefficient. Today's Bill, the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill, while addressing some of the anomalies arising from those Acts, in no way improves efficiency. I am still to be swayed from the opinion that training levy schemes are heavy-handed and that they are not effective means of improving training programs. They are merely another tax, another impost, on industry, another overhead that will make industry more and more uncompetitive as we seek to overcome the problems of recessionary conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: I am surprised that a challenge has not been mounted on constitutional grounds to the validity of this training levy. Perhaps no challenge has been mounted because business believes it to be so unworkable that it is expected to die a natural death. I stand by my statement of last year that this legislation does not fit the norm. It discriminates even within the same group of people. It lays down regulations as to the code of conduct. It has inclusions and exclusions for particular types of activities. The effect of this amendment Bill is to add further to the list of inclusions and exclusions. There will be a grouping entitled `Outstanding Trainers' which will be exempt and there will also be an exemption for particular industries.

The coalition maintains its opposition to the training guarantee scheme because of its arbitrary nature, both in terms of who has to pay and the threshold figure of $200,000. We said 12 months ago that, as a coalition, as a responsible alternative government, we cannot support a levy which is applied carte blanche, irrespective of what the company does, irrespective of whether it provides any one-to-one training, and irrespective of whether the nature of the business requires it to recruit and employ untrained staff and then to train them. There is a whole range of ramifications.

It is indeed a pity that this amendment Bill has come up before the end of the financial year. Had it come up in the Budget session we might have been able to get some idea of how companies are coping with the paperwork and the course approval procedure that they now have to engage in. We could then better appreciate the full ramifications of the training guarantee scheme. I certainly hope that we do not have to wait until the initial review after four years, as promised by the Government. We will be lucky if we have any industry left by then, the way industry is going in these recessionary conditions.

Perhaps there will be another private member's Bill, and I encourage my colleague Senator Reid, in relation to the training guarantee scheme in the next 12 months. We will then get a chance to assess how these companies are coping. We should also be able to get some indication of whether or not the Government has been able to raise enough revenue to cover even its administrative costs, let alone to sponsor other training programs.

My main complaint with the training guarantee scheme is its failure to acknowledge one-to-one, on-the-job training as a legitimate training expense. For the bulk of manufacturing processes and industries, the application of this Bill is perhaps a way out. However, we are not here to discuss this scheme but rather the administration of the Act.

I note that included in the amendments in this Bill is an embellishment of the meaning of the term `eligible training program', which hopefully clarifies the matter for registered industry training agents (RITAs) and users. There was obviously an interpretation problem with the definition, and hopefully this has now been clarified. No doubt registered industry training agents will be pleased to see that this Bill contains a number of amendments that clarify their position in regard to remuneration for training advisory certificates and secrecy provisions.

A substantive amendment within the Bill is that which covers the exclusion of outstanding trainers. As was the situation with the original Bill, now the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Act, we are being required to debate legislation without the accompanying regulations. This is not a very satisfactory situation. The qualifying criteria for RITAs, as regulated, were not available last time. I understand that Minister Dawkins has conducted perfunctory consultations with employer groups which resulted in general support for the idea of outstanding trainers, but there has been disagreement on the criteria for selection and exemption. Once the regulations are tabled, no doubt we will discuss the matter further. It will then be interesting to see what the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures and other such bodies have to say.

The other substantive amendment exempts building and construction employees in Western Australia and Tasmania from the training guarantee scheme, as they are soon to be covered by the State industry training levy arrangements which are very similar to the training guarantee scheme. Regulations are required for this amendment also and, while they have not been put forward with the legislation by the Government, they have at last been given to the Tasmanian building and construction industry. That industry was under the impression that they had already been tabled but, of course, they have not.

The Tasmanian Building and Construction Industry Training Board has raised with me a concern it had in relation to the Bill. Its concern is with proposed new section 4a (2) (e), the effect of which is to allow regulations to address `the charging of fees for applications for approval-in-principle decisions or scheme decisions'.

The proposed regulations which the Tasmanian Building and Construction Industry Training Board has seen make no reference to a fee. However, this does not mean that a fee will not be introduced in the future. The Training Board feels that this is yet another collection mechanism introduced by the Government and is unwarranted. The Board cites section 34(1) of the Act, which says:
Subject to this section, money in the fund may be applied for the purposes of:-
(A) Reimbursing the Commonwealth for: (among other things)
(i) The costs of administering this Act during any period; and
(ii) Costs incurred by the Commonwealth during any period in collecting, compiling, analysing and publishing information about the operations of this Act; . . .

Thus, the argument is that the Government has a way of covering its administrative costs and should not develop further revenue-raising avenues. I will leave this matter up to the Government to sort out with industry. It will also no doubt be a topic for discussion when the regulations are tabled.

The legislation still does not contain a provision under which employers can apply for exemption where their circumstances justify it. It is usual to have an opting out clause in special circumstances, but there is no such provision in this Act.

In support of my raising this defect, I cite instances such as employers who hire out to other employers temporary staff, such as relief secretaries or locums for professional practices. There is also no provision in the Bill for companies with substituted accounting periods. Companies which extract information on a financial year basis will be inconvenienced when their records are maintained for a different year end. This amendment Bill in no way eases the record retention obligations which still remain quite onerous.

However, there is also another serious anomaly which is a direct consequence of this Act and which I believe the Government should address. Senate Vanstone has already raised this matter and I endorse her comments. Under the Act, commissions and the like received by real estate salesmen and other salesmen not on a retainer are clearly included within the definition of `payroll', and must therefore be included in the calculation of employers' liability for training expenditure. However, the Australian Taxation Office has ruled that employers cannot claim against the levy for time spent by staff on commission attending eligible training programs. Furthermore, if retainers are offset against commissions, employers cannot claim a cost for the time of a salesman attending eligible training.

The ruling by the Australian Taxation Office contravenes the intent of the legislation. The explanatory memorandum states that the salary or wages can be claimed for all employees whose remuneration is covered under the definition of `payroll'. The sales side of the real estate industry operates almost entirely on a commission basis and, as such, is at a distinct disadvantage as a result of the Australian Taxation Office's interpretation.

The anomaly can be removed in one of two ways: either, firstly, by excluding commissions from the definition of `payroll' in the Act; or, secondly, including them as salary or wages for the purpose of allowing a deduction for attendance at eligible training programs. Of all the criticism that I have tendered against this Bill, I ask the Government to address specifically the last issue that I have raised. I specifically request the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, to oversee the taxation responsibilities on behalf of the Government. I ask that we get an answer to that matter as soon as possible.

I would also like to draw the Senate's attention to the comments of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in relation to this Bill. I am, of course, referring to the reversal of the onus of proof implied by clauses 5 and 6 of the Bill, for partnerships and companies defending themselves against the charge of non-compliance with the training guarantee scheme. This matter was also raised by my colleague Senator Vanstone.

The Committee made a general comment about the imposition of penalties for partnerships. The Committee sought advice from the Minister as to whether the imposition of, say, a fine on the members of a partnership individually would lead to the imposition, in effect, of a fine equivalent to the total of the fine which would be levied on a sole proprietor or a company but multiplied by the number of partners held liable, thereby subjecting the partnership to a greater penalty than that which would be levied on a sole proprietor or company.

Finally, the Committee noted that this Bill proposes to make what appears to be substantial amendments to a piece of legislation, most of which came into force only 12 months ago. The Committee expresses concern that persons upon whom this legislation imposes significant obligations will already have to refer to at least two separate pieces of legislation if this Bill is enacted in order to understand those obligations.

I take this opportunity to congratulate the Scrutiny of Bills Committee on the diligence it displayed in carrying out its task and for picking up on these unintended consequences which, if not altered now, would require further amendment at a future date.

I still believe that training levies are a mistake. They are an attack on the symptom rather than the cause. It should be the aim of the Government to create a competitive market, because if companies have to compete they will have to recognise that human capital gives them a competitive advantage. We look forward to hearing from the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate. I must say that I did not understand all of Senator Watson's contribution; he reminded me of a very fast train or something. He even turned Senator McMullan and me into a Minotaur, I think it is called.
—You weren't here for my contribution; so you have not heard much of the debate.
—I was here for enough of Senator Vanstone's contribution. But I will certainly read the transcript that Senator Watson referred to.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone, in the course of her remarks, made a couple of points. She particularly referred to treatment of partnerships under the Training Guarantee (Amendment) Bill. The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills did draw the attention of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to some concern about the treatment of partnerships, and he responded to that Committee to its satisfaction. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of the Minister's letter to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The question of partnerships is dealt with at the bottom of page 2 of that letter.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Employment, Education and Training
Parliament House, Canberra, ACT, 2600
Senator B Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator

I refer to the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No 6 of 1991 (17 April) concerning some aspects of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1991, which was referred to my office by Mr Argument on 18 April.
Reversal of onus of proof
The Committee raises questions concerning reversal of the onus of proof under clauses 5 and 6 of the Bill.

Clause 5 proposes the insertion of new Sections 11a and 11b into the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990 governing the treatment of partnerships and unincorporated associations, respectively. The proposed new Sections include provision for the treatment of offences against the Act.

The Committee draws attention to subclauses 11a (5) and 11b (6) which, respectively, provide that a partner or controlling officer (as the case may be) can raise a defence against an alleged offence if the partner or controlling officer proves certain specified matters. The Committee notes that this may be considered a reversal of the onus of proof, as it is ordinarily incumbent on the prosecution to prove all the elements of an offence.

Similarly, clause 6 includes provision for an offence committed by a business group to be an offence by each of the individual members. However, as with the partner or controlling officer under clause 5, the onus of proof is place on the person raising the defence.

The provisions of subclauses 11a (5) and 11b (6) are a statement of the liability of partners or controlling officers of bodies corporate in accordance with the accepted law in the area of partnership and company law respectively. It is necessary, therefore, to provide a statutory defence for the `innocent' partner or officer in order to rebut the presumption. The matters to be proved in the defence, on the balance of probabilities, will be peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant and extremely difficult for the prosecution to negative. The reversed onus is therefore justified and comes within the principles the Committee applies to these matters. (See the Committee's 10th Report of 1987.)

Further, since the Act is taxation legislation, the proposed onus of proof provisions are similar to other taxation laws. In fact similar provisions on onus of proof are also found in taxation legislation as follows:
* Sections 165 and 166 of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986
* Sections 102aazg, 221yhzn, and 468 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936
* Sections 12 and 13 of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987
Penalties relating to partnerships and unincorporated associations

Also your Committee seeks my advice on the effect of proposed new subclauses 11a (3) and 11b (4) in relation to penalties under the Act ranging from imprisonment (for up to 2 years), to fines (of up to $3,000), to the imposition of penalty charges. Subclauses 11a (3) and 11b (4), respectively, provide that partners or members are jointly and severally liable for any amount payable by the partnership or unincorporated association, as the case may be.

The Committee asks whether each partner or controlling officer would be held liable up to a maximum penalty, thus subjecting the partnership or unincorporated association to a greater penalty than would be levied on a sole proprietor or company.
Where criminal proceedings apply, clearly a penalty by way of imprisonment can only be imposed on an individual according to the nature and seriousness of the criminal act.

In case of an offence the liability of each of the partners or controlling officers is up to the maximum penalty because each partner or controlling officer may individually commit an offence. For instance, several partners could each be fined a maximum of $3,000 for committing the same offence. Since an offence may be committed individually, it is appropriate that the individual partner or controlling officer be subject to the maximum penalty. The drafting accords with this intention and the jointly and severally liable provisions under subclauses 11a (3) and 11b (4) are not applicable in regard to fines for offences committed by individual partners or controlling officers.

The provision for each partner or controlling officer to be liable to the maximum penalty for an offence ensures that there is an adequate and appropriate deterrent against offences under the Act. If, for instance, there are many partners involved in an offence, and the courts were only able to fine the partnership a maximum of $3,000 in aggregate, there might be little deterrent. The proposed provisions give the courts the discretion to deal appropriately with each individual according to the seriousness of the offence, with scope to impose the maximum penalty where appropriate. The existence of a number of offenders and the penalties imposed on them would be matters a sentencing court would take into account in determining the appropriate penalty in an individual case.

The provisions of subclauses 11a (3) and 11b (4), concerning the joint and several liability of partners or members, respectively, apply to penalty charges imposed under the Act. In other words, where a partnership or unincorporated association incurs a penalty in respect of a liability arising under the Act, the partners or members, as the case may be, are jointly and severally liable for the penalty charges involved.
Proposed reprint of the Act

I note the Committee's concerns that the enactment of the Bill could give rise to two separate pieces of legislation (the Act and Amendment Act), and this might pose some difficulties for employers understanding their obligations. Arrangements are being made with Attorney-General's Department to have a reprint available of the Act when the Bill is enacted.
Yours sincerely
John Dawkins

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone also drew attention, as did one or two other honourable senators, to the question of what was at one stage described as rorts by one of the speakers. The Minister has issued a media statement warning employers about this issue. But let me say that the Government, through the Minister, will be keeping an eye on that.

SPEECH.PARA: A comment was made about regarding real estate and other commission-based industries. There has been substantial correspondence with the Minister on this and there is no anomaly in the legislation relating to commission. Indeed, if we accepted the industry's request, it would be anomalous and inequitable from the viewpoint of other industries.

Because time is passing, I just want to make one or two general points about the legislation. The burden of the Liberal Party opposition to this legislation is to try to get the best of both worlds, to say, `We believe in more training but we are against this form of encouraging it, and we believe that in the read our lips--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a naughty boy for saying that. That is not right and you know it.

—It is a quotation, Senator. It is a quotation from the Opposition spokesman on industry. He says, `Read my lips to see whether we will deliver on any of these things'. What Senator Watson, as I understood him, seemed to be saying was that, if there were a Liberal government in Australia, competitive conditions would be created where training would automatically take place because firms would have to train people in order to survive.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a beaut little view, having regard to a static model of the Australian economy which was protected in Senator Watson's day from outside competition. It is not a view which is appropriate to current circumstances in Australian industry. It used to be said that investment capital flowed around the world in search of cheap labour and in search of raw materials. Investment capital floats around the world now, more than anything else, in search of skills. Foreign companies come to see me and I sometimes ask them, `Why do you want to come here into a particular industry?' and they say, `Because of the skills'.

Sadly, it cannot be said across the whole range of Australian industry, but it can be said in some industries. Senator Watson, in his more laterally minded condition-which sometimes falls on him by way of accident, perhaps in the darker hours of night-knows that is true. The Government in this country was confronted with a situation where the performance in relation to skills training by industry was just not up to scratch internationally and there was no apparent way in which it could be got up to scratch internationally in a relatively quick and significant way. That was the seed, if you like, of this scheme and of this legislation.

In the dark ages, Senator Watson had some remote industry experience, and he well knows-recalling from the days when he worked in Tasmania's dark satanic mills-that those firms which took the trouble to train people had them pinched all the time by other firms which were too lazy to take on the task. It does Senator Watson no good to wave his arms at me like John the Baptist. That will not make any difference to the argument. The fact of the matter is that this scheme, which was thought about for a long time, was necessary and is embodied in this legislation. That is why it is here.

Preliminary figures suggest that industry, which in the past did not respond to this need, is now responding and employers have increased their training effort significantly over the last 12 months or so. It is all very well to nitpick. Liberal Party oppositions are always good at looking for potential rorts because that is the environment in which they grew up. When in government they created them all. They are still doing this in a nitpicking way. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
