TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It concerns Cambodia. My question is in four parts. Firstly, what is the Australian Government's assessment of the likelihood of a peace settlement in Cambodia occurring, given the apparent failure of the recent Jakarta talks to make any real progress? Secondly, what is the Minister's explanation for the serious leak of Australian diplomatic cables and documents to journalists in Jakarta during the talks regarding Australia's agenda to gain United Nations (UN) Security Council intervention to prevent the Khmer Rouge breaking its word on the transitional arrangements? Thirdly, is the proposed meeting of the Supreme National Council (SNC) on 24 June likely to bring any closer the need for the deployment of Australian forces in a peacekeeping role in Cambodia? Finally, has the Australian Government been urging Japan to take a significant role in a Cambodia settlement, either by taking part in a peacekeeping force, or by providing financial support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the likelihood of a peace settlement after the Jakarta meeting, the situation is extremely active at the moment in this respect, with many more positive signs in the last 24 hours than I have seen in the last nine months. Those signs are occurring in the context of the 24 June meeting of the SNC to which Senator Teague referred. They seem to flow from the rapprochement that has been achieved at Jakarta between the Phnom Penh people under Hun Sen and Prince Sihanouk.

ANSWER.PARA: It is too early yet for me to speculate publicly in any more detail than that as to how things might work out. I simply make the point that what is happening is occurring squarely within the context of the United Nations peace plan rather than involving some fundamental departure from it. I think there are grounds for quite a lot of optimism that we may be, at last, seeing the beginning of a serious end game in this.

We have had high expectations in the past; they have been deflated in the past, but a great deal did happen during 1990 after the initial UN peace plan was floated by Australia. A great deal of progress was made and then it came to a halt around September or October last year. The point that I am simply making is that, despite the apparent failure of the Jakarta talks to advance matters as far as the consideration of those settlement terms are concerned, things have been happening since, in the context of this SNC meeting, which do represent some rapid and lively forward movement.

That answers the honourable senator's third question. As to the second question about the leak of cables in Jakarta, I have been assured, and am confident on the basis of those assurances, the nature of which I cannot reveal, that the source of the leaked material was not the Australian Government but in fact some external source that had access to that material. That represents something of a change, I acknowledge, in terms of a history of leaks in the last few months but, in this particular instance, it is not attributable, I am totally confident, to any official or other Australian Government source.

As to the role to be played by Japan in the Cambodian peace settlement, we have said for a long time that we believe Japan has a significant role to play. In fact, we co-chair with Japan one of the subgroups of the Paris conference which has to do with post-war, post-settlement rehabilitation and reconstruction, and certainly we would hope that Japan would play a major role in that post-settlement rehabilitation process. As to whether Japan may have some role to play in a peacekeeping context in the course of a worked out UN settlement, again, I think it is premature to speculate about that. Given the state of the domestic debate in Japan, it is probably premature to contemplate that as a reality, if the Cambodian settlement does come to fruition in the reasonably near future. But, as I have indicated in this place on other occasions, as far as the Australian Government is concerned, we believe that it would be quite appropriate for Japan to play a role in the future in UN peacekeeping operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his careful answer to all parts of my question. I noticed that he did not refer to the Khmer Rouge at all when he gave, with some guarded optimism, his hopes with regard to the 24 June meeting.
—Order! I ask Senator Teague to ask the supplementary question.
—I ask: was his omission of the Khmer Rouge quite deliberate?

—No. I did say that the developments that were presently occurring in the context of the SNC meeting were within the framework of the UN settlement-that is to say, they involve the Khmer Rouge as an active, participating member of the SNC within the context of a larger settlement. There has been some speculation that the Hun Sen-Sihanouk rapprochement might be signifying the possible emergence of a tripartite solution excluding the Khmer Rouge. What is happening at the moment is not going down that track.

—In view of repeated calls in the car industry for reductions in sales tax in order to encourage people to buy new cars which are both safer and less polluting than older vehicles, I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce: is there any prospect of a reduction in sales tax on cars?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that both the car industry and indeed other groups in the community have, from time to time, raised the question of the issue of sales tax on cars. Some companies and organisations in the industry argue that we should use the sales tax lever to encourage people to buy newer, safer and therefore more environmentally sound motor vehicles. It is a thing which is, in the longer term, devoutly to be wished, I suppose, but I must say that, having had some representations about this issue, I have raised the matter of sales tax on cars with the Treasurer, Mr Kerin. There have been discussions about it, and there is no prospect in this year's Budget of any reduction in sales tax on motor vehicles.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Senate will realise, the Government is confronted with difficult budgetary circumstances this year, first of all in relation to the decline of the surplus-for a variety of reasons which we have discussed here-and also because of the anticipated deficit in next year's Budget. In that environment, and because of the need for tight fiscal policy, there is no prospect of a reduction in sales tax on cars this financial year.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the Australian Government's policy in the Middle East. I ask: what is the Government's evaluation of the recent treaty of cooperation between Lebanon and Syria, and what assessment may be made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A treaty of fraternity, cooperation and coordination was concluded last month between the governments of Lebanon and Syria and has now been ratified by the parliaments of each country. The treaty consists of a six-point plan dealing with cooperation and coordination in education, trade, foreign policy, security arrangements and the economy. The security arrangements are expected to include the establishment of a military coordination committee to decide on a timetable for the redeployment of Syrian troops from Beirut into the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon as provided for in the Taif agreement. The treaty has been concluded by a sovereign Lebanese government which has authority to manage its own affairs and which claims that Lebanon will benefit from the treaty. I am aware that some Lebanese Christian representatives and Israel have claimed that the treaty may be a vehicle for increasing Syrian influence in Lebanon. We are presently seeking evidence of how the treaty will work in practice before we would make such a judgment ourselves.

ANSWER.PARA: As we have made it clear over a number of years now, we oppose activity in Lebanon by Syria or any other country which compromises Lebanese sovereignty. In this context, we continue to oppose the presence of Israeli forces in southern Lebanon which, of course, remain there in defiance of United Nations Security Council resolution 425. The Lebanese-Syrian treaty comes as significant progress has recently been achieved in implementing the Taif accord generally, particularly in relation to the disarming and disbanding of militias, although I would have to express some caution that there is still some way to go before long term peace and stability are restored to Lebanon. Press reports that the Palestine Liberation Organisation has agreed to withdraw from positions in southern Lebanon and to allow the Lebanese Army to deploy in its place are, if confirmed-and they remain to be confirmed-a welcome development and represent a further extension of the Lebanese Government's authority in that country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: is it the case that the United States delegates to the Madrid conference on Antarctica have changed their attitude to the maintenance of a minimum 50-year mining ban in Antarctica? If so, in what way has their position changed and what will be the effect of this change on the long term effectiveness of the mining ban-that is, beyond 50 years? Do any other countries appear to be wavering? What is Australia doing to ensure a strong position on a mining ban from the Madrid conference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The United States has not exactly changed its position on the question of a 50-year mining ban. What has happened is this: at the first Madrid meeting in April, the Antarctic Treaty parties agreed to a comprehensive environment protection regime for Antarctica which would, in effect, prohibit mining there permanently. That followed from the capacity of any existing consultative party, including Australia, to veto the implementation of a future mining regime after 50 years. So, the significance of the original Madrid agreement was that, while it provided for a review conference to be called after 50 years, the outcome of that review conference could be stymied by any country stopping, in effect, mining permanently.

ANSWER.PARA: It was, in a sense, surprising that the United States went along with the particular consensus that was achieved on an ad referendum basis-that is to say, subject to reference back to governments for confirmation-in April, because the United States position up until then had been one of fairly robust enthusiasm for retaining a capacity to engage in mining. That was the position as it stood in April.

What happened at the current Madrid conference-which was called with the hope and expectation that, having been back to home governments, there would be a more or less automatic endorsement and signature of the original agreement-is that there has been some backsliding in the US position. The current proposal that is now the subject of close attention, as the current conference draws to conclusion, is one that pays some regard to that later US position but in fact modifies it. I think that, rather than going through the complications of describing what the US came back to at this conference and what is now the subject of discussion at the moment as the likely outcome-unless consensus is denied-I should simply state what the current proposal is.

The current proposal now being hotly debated is as follows: a conference can still be called after 50 years, so that one has to wait 50 years before anything happens. At that conference, if an amendment is to be adopted allowing for mining, it has to be adopted by a majority of the parties at the conference, including three-quarters of the present consultative parties. That is to say, a quarter of the present 26 consultative parties, if they banded together, could still veto the application of a new mining regime in the future.

There is a further provision, which the United States of America is enthusiastic about, that any party which does not like that situation occurring would have the right to withdraw, on two years notice, from the environment protocol as a whole. It is not a right to withdraw from the mining bit of it; it relates to the environment protocol as a whole, which means that there is a political inhibition on any country choosing to so act, because it would come in for a lot of flak for no longer subjecting itself to an environment regime.

There is also a requirement in the current proposal that there be an explicit acknowledgment of the sovereign claims of claimant nations. So, on the face of it, it means that any country that did choose to withdraw from the protocol and go ahead and mine in 50-plus years time would nonetheless have to respect the claims of sovereignty of countries with claims in the area. For example, if the United States wanted to mine, in the situation in which it had withdrawn from the protocol, in Australian-claimed territory, it would, on this reading, have to get approval from Australia.

That is the proposal that is now there. The difficulty that Australia and New Zealand are facing is that the overwhelming majority of the parties at this conference are, it seems, now getting behind this particular proposal, which is a modification of the absolute veto proposal that previously existed; but it is a proposal which, nonetheless, would prohibit any mining occurring for at least 57 years and which would involve jumping many hurdles before that happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, wind it up and sit down.

—I can understand Senator Patterson's and the Opposition's profound and total indifference to this question, which is about the whole future of the Antarctic mining regime and the environmental protection of that continent. But it is a complex question and it is one that Australia has to decide upon in the next 24 hours, as to whether we endorse this particular consensus or stand out, possibly alone, against the rest of the world and run the risk of the whole thing unravelling. That is the position that we are involved in at the moment. It is one that will be resolved within the next 24 hours. I think it is important that the Senate and the public understand the nature of the immense number of hurdles that have to be jumped before one could mine under the proposal as it has now emerged.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Now that India has a new Prime Minister, is the Australian Government able to comment of the results of the Indian elections? Also, what effect will the outcome of those elections have on relations between Australia and India?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The election process in India is now virtually complete. Only the seats in the Punjab, for which elections are scheduled tomorrow, those seats which have been countermanded because of election irregularities, and a handful of others, remain undecided. It is clear that the Congress (I) Party, led formerly, of course, by Rajiv Gandhi, has won the most seats. It lacks an outright majority, but not by much. It has 222 seats and it needs roughly another 50 seats to form a majority in its own right. The Congress (I) Party is expected to form a government with support from the parties of the National Front, which has 71 seats, and the Left Alliance, which has 55 seats.

ANSWER.PARA: The expectation is that the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), which did increase its numbers to some extent in the Lok Sabha, to become the second largest individual party, but nonetheless with only 124 seats, will become the formal opposition party. There is no evident enthusiasm on the part of anyone else in the chamber to form a coalition with the BJP.

Yesterday, as senators would have seen reported, Congress (I) chose as its parliamentary leader Narasimha Rao, who will be sworn in as the new Prime Minister. I want to take this opportunity to congratulate Narasimha Rao, who is a close personal friend of mine, a former Foreign Minister, on his elevation to that particular task. He has been a very good friend--

TALK.START.PARA: —He will be thrilled to bits with this congratulation.
—Order!

—He will be tickled pink with this particular reference, actually, and I will pass on the honourable senator's congratulations, too. Both Mr Hawke and I have worked with Narasimha Rao when he was Foreign Minister. He is a man of great ability, great dignity-not with enormously obvious charisma in a Western political sense, of the kind with which we are familiar-and is someone who I believe will become a leader of very considerable stature. As to the future, I will not speculate or comment upon the likely course of events--
—You were happy to do it in India.

—In circumstances that should have become very obvious to Senator Hill. Obviously there is an enormous range of political, social and economic problems confronting India at the moment. We expect the new Government to tackle them with capacity and diligence, and we expect the relationship between the new Indian Government and Australia to be very warm indeed.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and it follows on from a question asked earlier this week about McMillan's liquid petroleum gas (LPG) cylinder factory in Echuca. In his response to a question about the checking of imported LPG cylinders, the Minister said that the testing of imported cylinders was the same as for locally produced cylinders. Has the Minister since been advised that his reply was incorrect, in that all Australian-made cylinders are tested, with imported cylinders being only randomly tested? Will the Minister now ensure that imported cylinders are subjected to the same safety testing as Australian cylinders? Will he also investigate whether the dumping of cylinders is occurring?

—The simple answer to that question is no, I have not been advised that my advice was incorrect. I said the other day that there was random testing of imported cylinders. Senator Patterson has asked me whether I will investigate whether LPG cylinders are being dumped in Australia. The answer to that question is no, that is not my function as a Minister. If a manufacturer alleges that imported cylinders are being dumped, there is a mechanism for that manufacturer to take proceedings-which have been debated here in the Senate within the last day or two-through the Australian Customs Service and the Anti-Dumping Authority, to have any such complaint dealt with. It is certainly not my function. I would be even busier than I am if I dealt with all those issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I believe that the Minister said on Tuesday:

QUESTION.PARA: Testing includes a prescribed number from each consignment being selected at random by the testing authority. That is the same as for locally produced cylinders.

What I am saying is that locally produced cylinders are all tested and imported cylinders are tested randomly. Can the Minister explain the difference between the answer that he gave on Tuesday and the answer that he has just given now?

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that imported cylinders are randomly tested. If the point of Senator Patterson's question is to ask me whether I have had any further advice about the testing of local cylinders, as compared with imported cylinders, the answer is no. But I will certainly get that advice. The point of the question probably concerns who does the testing--
—That is not the point of the question. The point of the question is how many are tested, that local cylinders are subjected to more testing.
—No, that is the important point and I will seek to get an answer on that issue.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports of complaints by the New South Wales President of the Australian Small Business Association that the Government is intimidating small businesses because they are not complying with award-based superannuation requirements? Will the Minister say whether these complaints have any foundation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In yesterday's Canberra Times, a Mr Brian Davis, the New South Wales President of the Australian Small Business Association, made allegations, and again in today's Australian, this time by letter, he made allegations, about the Government's campaign to encourage compliance with award-based superannuation. Honourable senators would be well aware of the campaign, because I have answered questions on it for some time. They would know that, on a plain reading of what has been put, many of the allegations are simply hysterical.

ANSWER.PARA: There are four categories of allegation made by Mr Davis, all of which are wrong. The first category goes to credibility, in which he uses phrases such as `the Government stretches the truth', `the Government's letter is intimidating', `the Government's letter is not correct', and that the claims we make as a government are `dishonest and aimed at coercing employers'.

The second group of allegations he makes is that we have suggested that employers return a card to the Department of Industrial Relations or ring, and that if employers do that they will get a visit by a union official or an inspector and will be inspected and put through the wringer; and that in any case DIR advice is confused and that confusion reigns supreme. Thirdly, he said that we intend or try to intimidate employers under obscure legal guises in order to force them to contribute to union-controlled superannuation schemes. Finally, he says that we have embarked on this information campaign in complete disregard for small businesses.

What should be said about all these allegations is that not only are they sad because of the paranoia they display, but also they are totally wrong and mislead. The letter that we have sent as a government to thousands of employers is aimed at informing them of their obligations and rights and the rights of their employees for award-based superannuation. The letter that has been sent out was approved by the Confederation of Australian Industry and by the Australian Council of Trade Unions as to the accuracy of its text. It was based on an impartial survey commissioned by the Department to find out what problems employers had with superannuation. The letter was designed to answer specifically those problems. The tone of the letter is agreeable; it is not in any sense an intimidating letter.

The allegation that we are encouraging contributions to union-controlled funds is a fallacy. Anyone who knows anything about award-based superannuation knows that funds generated as a consequence are controlled by both employers and unions for that particular industry. They are not union funds as such, but are jointly managed.

The allegation that we have shown a complete disregard for small business is wrong. I wrote to the Australian Small Business Association about this campaign before we launched it, inviting the Association to participate and explaining the background of the campaign. It has not favoured the Government with a reply. I can only imagine that our letter is gathering dust somewhere in the archives of that Association.

The letter we have sent advises employers to contact the Department of Industrial Relations if they want information. This is a service that the Government offers employers, to inform them impartially as to the legal obligations. But it suggests that before they do that they contact their own employer organisation and it encourages them to be affiliated to those organisations so that they can obtain the best information from their own representatives rather than draw on the government service that is provided. It suggests that, if they do not wish to do that, we will provide the information. We see it as a service offering help to small business.

What would be offensive, I would think, to a small business person who was obeying the law and paying legal entitlement to superannuation is that a competitive small businessman was disobeying the law, not paying legal entitlement and having a subsidy in terms of profit or company turnover because he or she was acting illegally and therefore enjoying a competitive advantage. The reason why employer organisations support this campaign is that there is a level playing field. They, too, recognise the need for all employers to comply with the law, which is why they have endorsed it.

I conclude by saying that the campaign is going well. There is an estimated superannuation underpayment of $700m. We intend with the social partners, the employers and the unions, to ensure that that is properly paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to-well, I think that I had better ask it of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, after the last episode. When the Prime Minister said, `My message to them is that they will cop every instrument of punishment and retribution and reaction that the operators will bring against them . . . I do like to make it clear that if they refuse to abide by their obligation to the centralised wage-fixing system, the Government will support any move to cancel existing awards and conditions . . . . It's a different game, this time, boys. It's war', could this not be taken as a warning to the waterfront unions in the present situation? If not, why not, when the position fits the situation exactly?
—Mr President--
—Why are you looking mystified?
—I am looking mystified because I have spent a lot of time on the docks and I have yet to see a 737, a 747 or a 727 on the waterfront.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. If that is the reason for totally avoiding the question, may I ask: is it a fact that supervisors on the wharf earn as much as $100,000 a week for a 27-hour week and that the minimum rate for wharfies is $45,000, and that in both cases this is more than comparable to what air pilots make?
—I think strictly that is another question, but I will allow it if the Minister wishes to answer it.
—To the best of my knowledge the only wharfies who would earn $100,000 a week for a 27-hour-week would be those who had fortuitously won Tattslotto for that week.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Has the Minister seen reports that the New South Wales Government has settled ministerial responsibilities following the recent election? Do these reports indicate particularly that ministerial responsibilities have been settled for the Federal-New South Wales Joint Coal Board? If these reports are correct, is the Minister in a position to advise whether both governments are ready to proceed with settling issues raised by the review of the board's operations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen those reports. I must say that the coal industry in Australia is a key industry for this country. In New South Wales it is a $3 billion a year industry. Coal, of course, is the greatest single mineral commodity export earner for this country. New South Wales is a key State and a key exporter as well as an internal supplier for its own market.

ANSWER.PARA: The other significant feature of this industry is that it is regionalised and supports rural centres. It employs thousands of Australians and is becoming more productive as the level of industrial disputation has fallen during our period of office, as has, importantly, the level of industrial accidents, this being a highly accident-prone industry. When accidents occur in the industry they are usually serious.

Both the Commonwealth and the New South Wales Government maintain a Joint Coal Board to oversee the management of the industry, lower accident levels, and handle workers compensation in New South Wales. Both governments are committed to a review of the functions of the Joint Coal Board. Indeed, it was only the New South Wales election that interrupted that process. Since the election it is certainly this Government's intention to get on with the review.

I must say that, while recognising that Mr Greiner has a Harvard MBA in management, when one looks at the way in which he has allocated the ministerial responsibility for this key and fundamental industry, one is a bit confused about the managerial principles that are being employed. I quote from the Telegraph Mirror of 19 June--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. It is for the Minister to answer for things that are pertinent to his own portfolio. It is quite outside his ability to answer and speak on behalf of a Minister in the New South Wales Government. I ask you, Mr President, to rule him out of order and restrict his answers to things that relate to his portfolio only.
—Order! I think that the Minister is now beginning to talk about internal New South Wales arrangements. I would remind him of the point of order that has been taken.

—Thank you, Mr President. May I say that I am speaking here in the representative capacity of the Minister for Resources and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. We maintain, with the New South Wales Government, a Joint Coal Board and the managerial responsibility on the New South Wales side is an important fact. May I proceed to conclude my answer?

ANSWER.PARA: I quote from an article in the Telegraph Mirror of 19 June:
The Government man now in charge of the $3 billion-a-year industry is Natural Resource Minister Ian Causley. Well, he is almost in charge.
He can licence mines and look after other bureaucratic procedures but he's unlikely to ever guide a drill into a seam.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: the Minister is clearly flouting your earlier ruling, and I would ask him to adhere to the ruling you have already made.
—I ask the Minister--
—Order! The Minister is obviously ignoring the point of order. I ask him to conclude his answer.

—Thank you, Mr President. Can I just seek some guidance from you so that I can comply with your ruling. I am talking about a Joint Coal Board that is managed jointly by the Commonwealth and by the New South Wales Government.
—I raise a point of order.
—Order! Senator O'Chee, resume your seat.
—That is a responsibility of the portfolio of Primary Industries and Energy. I am talking about the management of that Board.
—Order! I asked Senator Cook to conclude his answer. I think it would be better if he did not quote from that press report about which the points of order have been taken.

—I conclude my answer by saying that the responsibility for this key national industry in New South Wales, supervised by the Joint Coal Board, has under the ministerial arrangements in New South Wales been divided amongst five different Ministers-Mr Causley, the Resources Minister; Robert Webster, the Minister for Planning and Energy; George Souris, the Minister for Sports, Recreation and Racing--

—On a point of order, Mr President: has the Minister no shame? Will he not be guided by your ruling? You asked him to desist from reading that article. He has been told not to comment on internal New South Wales ministerial responsibilities; his is a Federal responsibility. He is clearly flouting your two rulings.

—On the point of order, Mr President: Senator Bishop makes that point of order in complete ignorance of the basic point that Senator Cook is making, which is that the particular body about whose management he is referring is a jointly administered Commonwealth-State responsibility-the Joint Coal Board of New South Wales. As such, it is a responsibility squarely within the DPIE portfolio, as I well know, having once administered it myself as Minister for Resources and Energy. It is squarely within the Minister's constitutional and ministerial competence, and that is the basis on which he is answering the question. That is the basis on which you should regard the answer as in order.
—I asked Senator Cook to conclude and not to read from the newspaper article. I do not think he was.

—The only other Ministers I have not named are Michael Yabsley, the State Development and Tourism Minister, and John Fahey, the Education Minister. Funnily enough, all five Ministers have the collective responsibility for different parts of this quite key industry. That seems to us in the Commonwealth not to be an ideal model for efficient management of a nationally sensitive industry.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister advise whether there are any private educational tertiary institutions in Australia that have students who receive Austudy payments? If there are any, can the Minister advise what criteria have been required by the Government to enable private educational institutions to receive accreditation so that their students may receive Austudy? Finally, does the Minister intend to extend the criteria to allow Austudy to more Australian students studying at private institutions?
—I will take that question on notice.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of difficulties pensioners are experiencing in complying with the provisions of the Cash Transaction Reports Act, as the deeming of interest on pensioners' accounts resulted in many pensioners opening new accounts and coming within the scope of the points score this legislation produced? How can procedures be simplified for our older citizens?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many honourable senators would be aware that complaints were received from pensioners about not only being faced with deeming but also the introduction of some regulations under the Cash Transaction Reports Act which, unfortunately, came about at the same time. It meant that pensioners, even if they had been operating bank accounts for 50 years, nonetheless were forced to comply with a points system, which many of them found very difficult.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of the complaints I had received, I wrote to the Attorney-General some months ago. He replied favourably to a review, and his Department and mine have been looking at ways and means of sorting out the problem. Amendments to the regulations under that Act are being drafted now, and we hope that new procedures will be in place by 1 July. Under those arrangements, if a DSS form SF104 letter of introduction can be produced, which is available on request to eligible beneficiaries and pensioners, that will be given a weighting of 100 points. That will be sufficient to open a bank account on its own. The new arrangements will mean a great simplification for pensioners and I think will be welcomed by all of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and follows the concerns expressed today by Senator Panizza. I refer to the 1985 Andriessen assurance between Mr Andriessen and Mr Kerin that the European Community (EC) would not grant export restitution for beef exports to Australia's traditional markets and which is now under review. As a consequence, we could see 100,000 tonnes of beef dumped in Asia over the next five years, with a 25 per cent loss of income to Australian beef producers. Can the Minister inform the Senate what action the Government intends to take concerning this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that Senator Boswell is referring to the media reports in the past day or so that EC Agricultural Commissioner MacSharry has recommended ending the Andriessen assurance under which the EC has agreed not to export subsidised beef to Japan and other Asian-Pacific markets. This brief was prepared yesterday; so something may have turned up since, in which case I will amend the answer later, if that is appropriate. As I am advised at the moment, we are unaware of any recent developments in EC Commission policy that would substantiate those reports.

ANSWER.PARA: This issue has been discussed extensively with Commissioner MacSharry, with his colleagues, and indeed with his predecessor, Vice-President Andriessen, by me and successive Trade Ministers and Foreign Affairs Ministers. We do not believe that the answer to the problems currently facing the EC's chaotically organised beef industry can be found in increasing subsidised exports, and we have constantly made that point.

We remain reassured by the commitment given by EC President Delors earlier this year which recognised the fundamental trade policy and political importance of the agreement, and stated that the EC would consult with Australia if it were to consider any changes to it. During his visit a couple of weeks ago, Vice-President Andriessen reiterated that commitment. The agreement was reached in 1985 by the Prime Minister and the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, with Messrs Delors and Andriessen. As Senator Boswell has implied, it does remain essential to the stability and security of the Australian beef industry.

I am also aware of reports that other countries opposed to any extension of the use of export subsidies, as we are, do support Australia's position on the Andriessen assurance. It goes without saying that we welcome such support, and the fact of it is a further basis for supposing that the EC would not act unilaterally on this or in any arbitrary way. If I do receive any further information, I will provide it before the end of Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to a meeting he held with welfare groups in Adelaide on 31 October last year in which he committed his Department to a number of measures, including the provision in every Department of Social Security office information regarding DSS clients' legal rights. The Minister will recall that his commitment came after complaints were received, and acknowledged by him to be legitimate, about the behaviour of some Department of Social Security staff and, in particular, some members of mobile review teams and some field officers. At the time he said that new procedures would be put in place by January 1991. Can the Minister confirm whether pamphlets containing information on DSS clients' legal rights were completed two months ago and were ready to be printed? If the answer is no, why have not such pamphlets yet been completed? If the answer is yes, why have they not been distributed to Social Security offices, as was the commitment on 31 October last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can recall details of the meeting to which Senator Lees has referred, there were complaints about the behaviour of mobile review teams in particular and claims that clients were unaware of their right to refuse an interview at the doorstep when those mobile review team officers arrived. I undertook to have information available by January and to review it later on in the year. I did have information available in January. We have reviewed it. As I understand it, that review was completed a couple of weeks ago. New pamphlets are either in the offices now or on the way there. I will have to check as to whether they are actually there now; my impression was that they were. It would seem from Senator Lees's question that she believes they are not. I will have that checked.

ANSWER.PARA: As well as producing information about the rights of clients in terms of receiving officers and being interviewed, we have certainly since then produced a pamphlet on all appeal rights which is available in the offices and when review team officers visit people. So all of the appeal rights-not just in respect of appeals to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal but also steps that can be taken before then-are now available in pamphlet form and are distributed. I will check on the results of the other pamphlet as soon as Question Time is over.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister make these pamphlets available in Commonwealth Employment Service offices as, after 1 July with the start of the Newstart scheme, they will also be needed there.
—I can certainly undertake to do that.

—I address my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. As the Commonwealth has stated, it is against providing site specific subsidies to attract industries to the multifunction polis (MFP). Does the Government support the use of what the South Australian Government calls `existing government incentives' to supply what are subsidies of direct financial support, cheap land and energy, and concessions and financial assistance for business planning to attract industry to the Gillman MFP site as it will be a joint Commonwealth-State project? Will the Commonwealth funding determined in the Budget context be untied grants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the South Australian Government determines in relation to the Gillman site is very much its business and not a matter with which the Commonwealth would want to interfere. In relation to the MFP, the nine principles established by governments at an early stage set out that the MFP should be private sector led and private sector financed. That does not mean that if the South Australian Government, for example, wants to provide infrastructure of some kind or another which would make the site a more attractive investment destination, it should not do that. The history of this country is cluttered with the provision of infrastructure by governments-whether it be beef, roads, airports or whatever-which make business investment more attractive. That is very much a matter for the South Australian Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked whether there would be any Commonwealth funding in the forthcoming Budget. That will have to be addressed in the Budget context. I cannot make any statement about it at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I recognise that in the Budget context the Minister would not be prepared to give an indication of any specific funding commitments to the multifunction polis. But will the allocation of any funding be based on the principle that the Commonwealth injection of funds will be on the basis of untied grants and commitments?

—I cannot say that at the moment. I think that is likely to be the case. But, of course, the proposal put forward by the management committee for the MFP is that a development corporation be formed. Discussions are taking place as to the membership of the development corporation, and so on. Whether the Commonwealth would be involved directly with a member on the development corporation remains to be seen. But in general principle, any money which is made available by the Commonwealth would be in the nature of an untied grant. It may be that there is an agreement between the State and the Commonwealth Government about the way in which particular funds made available are used. They will not be big.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware of the concern of many disabled people, their families and organisations representing them, that payments currently received by sheltered workshops on behalf of disabled people will be stopped from 1 October? Will disabled people be given a choice as to whether their payments will go to their own accounts or to nominee accounts administered by sheltered workshops?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson and, I think, Senator Harradine raised this problem with me last year. There were some conflicting messages from the disabled community on the question of the disability reform package. As honourable senators would probably be aware, at the moment people in sheltered workshops qualify for the sheltered employment allowance. That is either paid direct to the workshop and then incorporated in the employee's wage packet or it is paid directly into an individual's bank account or into one of the nominee accounts to which Senator Giles referred. At the moment, about 60 per cent of the employees have that payment going into their wage packet-in other words, going via the sheltered workshop itself. About 40 per cent have the allowance paid into a bank account of their own choice.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the new reform package, that allowance will be replaced with a disability support pension. Everyone who is to get that new pension will be transferred to it automatically on 1 October. People who enter sheltered workshops after that will be able to claim that same payment.

There are those in the disabled community who tell me that paying money direct to sheltered workshops is the wrong thing to do. There are others who fairly passionately claim that it is a right that people in sheltered workshops should retain. Over the course of the next couple of months, I will hold some more discussions with sheltered workshops and disabled groups to try to form a definite policy. At the moment, I would lean to the view that those in the disabled community should have the widest choice possible. So I would lean to the view that payments made to sheltered workshops and then passed on to disabled people ought to be an option that is retained.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is addressed to the Minister for Defence. I ask: has the Minister been made fully aware of the catastrophic failure of the Army to cope with the maintenance program of the Blackhawk helicopters? Is the Minister aware that the number of helicopters serviceable on any one day has always been unacceptably low, being as low as 10 per cent on some occasions, with great effects on the training program? Is the Minister aware that the committee set up to look at the transfer of the helicopters from the Air Force to the Army, which was chaired by then Commodore Ian MacDougall, now the Chief of the Naval Staff, in recommending against the transfer to Army noted that the cost would be at least $50m for no benefit? Given the Minister's laudable aim to get the maximum value for the defence dollar and the fact that, at the end of the day, Army's requirements are for an airlift capability when it wants that, not the ownership of the asset, when will the Minister take the appropriate action and transfer the maintenance of the Blackhawks to the Air Force and resolve what is now an intractable problem which is costing us tens of millions of dollars and which is running on just the way the minehunter program ran on for years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would contend there is no analogy between the current Blackhawk situation and the minehunter program. It is true that when any new capital equipment comes into operation there are initial problems. That is especially true of helicopters. The comparisons that we have looked at between the introduction of the Blackhawks here and their introduction in other parts of the world show that over the first 18 months in particular a whole range of maintenance problems have to be dealt with, and it does not compare badly with overseas experience.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked me about Commodore MacDougall's views on the matter. That obviously well and truly predates my entry into the portfolio. But the matter has been looked at. I do not think it is costing us tens of millions of dollars at the moment. The expenditure on these machines is on track but, as I say, the introduction of new capital equipment, especially helicopters, takes a long while to break in. Navy is finding similar problems with the helicopters that it has introduced into service. It takes a long time for them to come up.

The honourable senator mentioned the figure of 10 per cent. Of course, in a previous press release, Senator, you did not say up to 10 per cent; you said 10 per cent, which was of great concern to those people who run these particular helicopters. Ten per cent may be a correct figure on any given day-and you put it correctly here today.

The decision to move the helicopters from Air Force to Army caused some pain through interservice rivalry and everything else. I do not believe, though, I should encourage that sort of narrow view of service rivalry. I am quite convinced that in the next 12 months the problems with the Blackhawks will be overcome. As I say, according to my advice, there were similar problems overseas, and they were anticipated. I do not believe that if the helicopters were in Air Force or in any other maintenance program, the problems would be any less.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the problems are of such a magnitude, why has the Royal Australian Navy achieved a far higher serviceability factor than the Army has, operating the Seahawk helicopter which is, if anything, a slightly more complex airframe and engine installation than the Blackhawk?

—The major comparison I have made is to compare the Blackhawks here with the Blackhawks overseas. The RAN's experience with Seahawk, et cetera, is also comparable with overseas. So, whilst you may regard the Seahawk and the way in which it is used as a more complex thing, both comparisons hold up fairly well with overseas. So I do not really see the point of your question.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs and it concerns high living bankrupts like certain well-known entrepreneurs whose irresponsibility has impacted on the whole community and, in particular, Australia's reputation overseas. I ask the Minister: when big timers hit the wall, how does bankruptcy affect them? Can it be said that bankruptcy is an easy way out for these very affluent people?
—Your Department sponsors some of these people!
—From the reaction of honourable senators, I know that this is a matter of concern--
—It is because you have some of these people as guest speakers. Your Department sponsors them. Ansett!
— . . . not only in this chamber but out in the general Australian community where it is perceived that those who enter the status of bankrupt and get all the protections that that affords--
—Bob Ansett! Look at him. Look at your own house. You sponsored him. Innovative marketing!
—Nevertheless appear to be enjoying a lifestyle of some affluence which is very similar to the lifestyle that they were enjoying before the bankrupt status.
—Unbelievable! Bob Ansett was sponsored by your Department as a guest speaker.
—I think there are certain misgivings and concerns out in the community about that as honourable senators are indicating by their interjections.
—Bob Ansett-innovative marketing! Look to your own house. You had Bob Ansett. That is ridiculous.

—I believe some of this is caused by the fact that even a bankrupt can be fortunate enough to have wealthy relatives, friends or a generous employer who is prepared to make assets available to that person--
—He talked about innovative marketing-Bob Ansett, that is what you had him do.
— . . . from the assets belonging to those relatives or friends or, as I say, by an employer who is prepared to take them on--
—You did this in your Department. Innovative marketing! You sponsored Bob Ansett.
— . . . and provide them with a job which has the trappings which we see displayed on television from time to time.
—You sponsored Bob Ansett. Innovative marketing!
—Mr President, I cannot answer this question. This is incredible. Give it a rest!
—Order! I ask you to ignore the interjections.
—Thank you, Mr President, for protecting me from this tirade.
—But you did it. You sponsored Bob Ansett. He spoke about innovative marketing-a bankrupt!
—He is still going.
—Order! Senator Watson!

—Mr President, it obviously cannot be part of the bankruptcy law to take away the assets of relatives, friends or employers who make these assets available to bankrupts. However, having said that, I point out that it is extremely necessary also that there be no loopholes in the bankruptcy laws which allow people to disguise the fact that they have transferred assets as I say to, perhaps, relatives or friends and are in fact living off those transferred assets. We have to follow that money trail-the term used by Senator Bolkus, which I think will probably catch on-and trace these assets in the hands of those to whom they have been transferred in a way which is designed to defraud the creditors involved. Indeed, Australia, I believe, does lead the world in legislation to ensure that, where the bankrupt has enjoyed assets and disguised those assets in a trust, a company or a partnership which is effectively the alter ego of the bankrupt, those assets can be followed up by the trustee and, of course, they can be claimed for the bankrupt estate and, therefore, be made available to creditors.
—What about proceeds of crime?

—Proceeds of crime is an analogous situation, Senator, but not particularly relevant to this discussion. The fact is that, where assets are disposed of in a way which is designed to defraud creditors, there is legislation which provides that the disposition of assets has no effect against the trustee and the assets become available for distribution to creditors. That is how is should be. I have asked the Inspector General in Bankruptcy, Mr Richard Moss, to look particularly at and to review all those cases of some notoriety which have been very evident in the media over the last several weeks and months and to ensure that creditors are not defrauded by bankrupts continuing to live off assets which they have disposed of and transferred to relatives or friends in a way which is designed to disguise the assets that are truly available to them.
—I ask the Minister a supplementary question. Can he indicate whether the legislation includes assets overseas, in particular property in Spain reputed to worth a great deal?

—The Government has been very concerned to ensure that, in relation to mutual assistance with other jurisdictions, we have arrangements in place to allow for the tracing of assets overseas. In relation to the particular jurisdiction mentioned by Senator Reynolds, I will ensure that she receives an answer as soon as possible.
—I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Earlier today I was asked a question by Senator Foreman regarding the sales tax on motor vehicles. In the concluding part of my answer, I said there is no prospect of a reduction in sales tax on cars this financial year. I just want it to be quite clear that that was said in the context of the preparation of the Budget for the financial year which, in fact, commences on 1 July 1991.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday of this week, Senator Short asked me a question about relative growth rates and unemployment through the 1980s, based on some Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) figures which he got out of the newspapers. At the conclusion of his supplementary question, I invited him to ask me a further question about relative employment growth. Senator Short said, in answer to my invitation, `We will do that later too', and there was great cries of approval from the backbenchers. Rather like Horatio, a poem, those behind cried forward and those in front cried back. I have been waiting breathlessly for the further question all week.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to provide an answer to that question. Senator Short asserted that OECD data, which was reported in the newspapers, showed that Australia's average rate of economic growth was the fifth lowest in the 24 member list of OECD countries between 1980 and 1989. I make the point that that period, 1980-1989, included the 1981, 1982, 1983 recession, and the period of the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there was the drought too.

—Oh, Senator, come on! Let me make a few further observations about this matter. Bureau of Industry Economics calculations using latest published OECD data sources indicate that Australia came sixteenth out of 24 OECD countries on this basis. But population data is not yet available for the final year of the period to which Senator Short referred, namely 1990, in order to update the calculation.

ANSWER.PARA: The question raises a number of issues in relation to the measurement of per capita gross domestic product growth and its use as an indicator of economic performance and productivity. A very important factor to be taken into account in measuring these things is the so-called dependency ratio, that is, what proportion of the population is old, what proportion is young and of school age and, in that sense, dependent on people of working age. An economy with an ageing population or an increasingly large number of school-age people performs less well in those relative figures than an economy where the growth rate reflects the more average age of the population and people involved in the work force. That is the case with Australia.

After adjusting for this factor, Australia's ranking of gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate per person of working age is, in fact, tenth out of the 24 OECD countries. Australia is higher ranked than Italy, France and Germany, for example, for this period. I suggest it is well known that Australia's family migration and refugee programs tend to reduce the current growth rate of GDP per head because older people and currently unproductive children boost that dependency ratio to which I have referred.

During Senator Short's question and my answer, Senator Crichton-Browne interjected that the current Government was a peculiar circumstance pertaining to the Australian economy. However true that might be, that interjection had no relevance to the point of Senator Short's question because Senator Crichton-Browne's interjection does not stand analysis. Per capita GDP grew by 0.7 per cent during the period 1976 to 1983 and between 1983 and 1990 it grew by 3 per cent. I said `about double' in my answer. It is over four times. I got that figure wrong and I apologise for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Hill asked me a question about the extent to which advice might have been received from the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) about various grants made to South African development projects. In the course of that answer, which had a rather spectacularly misplaced beat-up in this morning's press, I did say at one point that I would not be at all surprised if, in that context, there were not some formal recommendations on the books somewhere suggesting as much.

ANSWER.PARA: The context in question was the longstanding Government policy that has hitherto existed that development assistance moneys would not go directly to political movements. The situation so far as that is concerned is that, having checked the records in some detail, there are simply no papers available anywhere that we can find in which AIDAB has ever recommended or advised the Government in those terms not to give money directly to a political movement.

It has been Government policy, which periodically has been referred to as such by way of reference in AIDAB documentation, but there has never been advice from the agency as such; it is simply a judgment that the Government itself has made. As to the specific recent grant that was made to the African National Congress (ANC) of $83,000 for computer equipment, library books and so on to establish a department of economic planning, AIDAB did participate, I am now reminded, in the preparation of the recommendations in question.

Dr Helen Ware, the Assistant Director-General of AIDAB responsible for Asia, Africa and training coordination, was one of the four members of the team headed by Professor Ross Garnaut who drew up the consensus based recommendations for assistance to economic planning for a post-apartheid South Africa. As a member of that team, she represented AIDAB's views on assistance to South Africa. So, to the extent then that AIDAB had any input into the particular decision that was made in relation to the ANC-that particular grant of $83,000-AIDAB was, in fact, supportive of it, and it was for the policy reasons that I spelt out yesterday, which justified a departure from the policy which has been applied in the past because of the particular nature of the grant that was involved.

So it is simply playing with words to suggest that the Government was in breach of some rule. There had been a longstanding Government policy devised by the Government itself, implemented by the Government itself, without advice, recommendation or assistance from anyone else. To the extent that we modified that advice, it was with the active consensus of the AIDAB representative involved. So I hope that clears up that one-but I do not expect to get the same amount of press attention tomorrow.

- Until very recently the South African Government was not prepared to agree to the appointment of an AIDAB officer in Pretoria. Thus the responsibility for monitoring AIDAB funded activities inside South Africa was the responsibility of the Embassy whose staff did not include an AIDAB officer. Following the SAG Agreement to the posting from August 1991 the newly appointed AIDAB officer will be responsible for monitoring the projects inside South Africa.

- AIDAB also has a fraud control plan which has been recently revised and has been approved by the Attorney-General's Department. The revised fraud control plan embraces all AIDAB activities of including NGO funding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I dealt with two of the three Bills in this package yesterday. The third, which remains, is the Courts (Mediation and Arbitration) Bill 1991. I will just make a few comments putting down the Opposition's position in relation to that Bill. We are not opposing the Bill, which amends the Family Law Act and the Federal Court Act to facilitate and encourage alternative dispute resolution in those courts. Pursuant to this Bill, the courts concerned can develop mediation and arbitration programs. The precise nature of these programs and the manner in which they are conducted will be prescribed by changes to the court rules.

SPEECH.PARA: Particularly with respect to the Family Court, the introduction of mediation and arbitration proceedings is a much needed and overdue reform. The Opposition takes the view that the less adversarial mediation process is particularly appropriate to the family law jurisdiction as compared to formal litigation which is likely to be both protracted and expensive. The use of arbitration, while not necessarily having the same cost advantages as mediation, is also likely to lead to faster resolution of disputes.

This Bill represents the third aspect of the coalition's law and justice policy in relation to family law which the Government has most sensibly adopted. The first was the decision in August last year to increase funding for marriage guidance counselling services. The second was the Government's agreement to the coalition's motion to establish an inquiry into certain aspects of the operation and interpretation of the Family Law Act. Now the Government has taken up the coalition's policy that a stronger emphasis should be put on counselling, conciliation and mediation.

The explanatory memorandum states that the measures introduced by this Bill are considered to be revenue neutral because there will be a relocation of resources. We do, however, take the opportunity to make the point that if mediation and arbitration programs are to be successful it is clear that the courts will need additional resources. It is pointless for the Government to introduce new programs unless they are backed up with the necessary financial and administrative commitment. The Opposition, I mention in passing, would prefer to see greater emphasis on the use of mediation and arbitration programs that are separate from the court system.

With respect to mediation, the amendments allow the Court to make rules to provide for the mediation of disputes. Parties may apply for mediation before litigation has commenced on the application to the Court by a parent, child or party to a marriage. Mediation will also be available after proceedings have commenced with the consent of the parties. Approved mediators are to be listed in regulations. Communications made during mediation will not be admissible.

The amendments, in fact, provide for two types of arbitration. The first is that pursuant to proposed section 19D, the Court may make an order referring any proceedings under part VIII of the Act for arbitration. Part VIII proceedings relate to spouse or maintenance or property disputes. Court annexed arbitration may take place with or without the consent of the parties. Secondly, parties may arrange private arbitration of such disputes. The parties must consent to submit their disputes to an arbitrator.

We do have some concerns about the drafting of this part of the Bill. Under proposed section 19a, disputes relating to family law matters will be able to be referred to mediation prior to the commencement of any proceedings. This can be done on the application of a parent, a child or a party to a marriage, but there is no requirement that all parties must consent to such a referral. It is often said that, for a mediation to be successfully conducted, the consent of all parties is necessary.

The issue also arises in relation to the arbitration provision and proposed subsection 19d (2) which provides that the Family Court may refer a matter to arbitration with or without the consent of the parties. Yet it may be that a particular party will have a good reason for insisting that their dispute be dealt with by the Court rather than by an arbitrator. The problem is exacerbated by the provision that court ordered arbitrations are subject to full rights of review by way of complete re-hearing. Thus, when one party is unwilling to go to arbitration but is ordered to do so by the Court, the whole dispute becomes unnecessarily prolonged.

The Opposition also has concerns in relation to proposed section 19c which provides that any communications made in the course of the mediation shall be inadmissible in any court proceedings. While we agree that it is desirable for mediation to be confidential there may be some value in the system in use in other jurisdictions where communications are confidential unless the parties and the mediator agree that they should be admissible in subsequent proceedings. This is useful, for example, where a settlement agreement has been reached during mediation and it will be necessary for the terms of that agreement to be disclosed in order for it to be ascertainable and enforceable.

Clause 7 of the Bill adds a reference to approved mediators or arbitrators to the definition of court personnel in section 60 of the Act. Pursuant to the Family Law Amendment Act passed earlier this year, court personnel are obliged to report any suspicions they may have of child abuse. This would presumably include any suspicion arising in the course of mediation or arbitration. However, pursuant to proposed new section 19c, mediators and arbitrators have an obligation of confidentiality. It is unclear which of the obligations would be the overriding one.

Part 3 of the Bill amends the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 to provide for court ordered referral of existing proceedings for mediation or arbitration with the consent of the parties. This is an extension of the present situation in which arbitrators' awards can be registered. Pursuant to the changes introduced by this Bill, the court will be able to refer matters for arbitration, and awards made in court ordered arbitration will be able to be registered and enforced.

As was pointed out by the shadow Attorney-General during the debate on this Bill in the other place, the effectiveness of mediation and arbitration programs will very much depend on the content of the regulations and the rules of the court, which will need to fill in the many gaps in the proposed legislation.

Given the unsatisfactory nature of some of the Bill's provisions, the Opposition would have considered moving amendments if time permitted. However, taking into account the circumstances of its place in the program, together with the fact that we believe that alternative dispute resolution procedures in family law are long overdue, we will not seek such amendments at this time. However, we will watch with great interest the application of this law in practice .
