TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Control Amendment Bill 1991 amends the Export Control Act 1982 and includes offences in two areas: for falsely stating that necessary conditions have been met for export; and, for inspectors receiving goods or services from establishment owners. It also amends the section under which certificates are issued by the Government which certify the condition of the product as suitable for human consumption, so that these certificates can legally be issued even when importing countries do not require them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Export Control Act sets up a regime for the export inspection of prescribed goods and they include: meat, fish, fresh fruit and vegetables, dairy produce and grains. The purpose of the inspection is to ensure that the goods which are to be exported meet the strict requirements set out in the orders made pursuant to the regulations under the Act. These requirements are aimed at ensuring fitness for human consumption, quality, and accurate trade description of the goods.

Amendments will also ensure that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) can repay any money overpaid, and allow for section 4B of the Crimes Act to set the monetary penalties where prison terms are provided for.

The Bill indicates that the Government is establishing responsibility for much of its own inspection through quality assurance programs. This is to ensure that the number of inspectors-and therefore the costs-are reduced. While there has been some improvement in a small number of establishments, the change to self-regulation seems to be moving slowly.

This legislation will be supported by the Opposition because it recognises that with self-regulation there is a need for exporters to be penalised for making false statements. There is a need for significant penalties so that standards are maintained.

The Bill does a number of things. It makes it an offence for an inspector to receive goods or services from registered establishment owners. The Bill legalises the issue of health certificates, even in cases where the importing country does not insist on them, which are often used then as an aid to trading to prove that products meet the requirements for domestic consumption. The Bill clarifies the ability to remit fees as well as collect them and removes references to monetary penalties for offences where terms of imprisonment are also provided, allowing the Crimes Act to be used to convert the term of imprisonment into a monetary penalty where the court so requires.

There has been a major need for AQIS to be restructured to provide for its two roles, the quarantine role and the departmental responsibility for export inspection. We believe there is good reason for this. The decision of the Government in the last Federal Budget to move to 100 per cent cost recovery on export inspection has changed all the rules. Of AQIS's total budget of approximately $170m, export inspection amounts to around $132m, which is a large cost factor. The $132m in question is being paid for by producers and exporters, but they receive no accountability whatsoever for that expenditure, which is of particular significance at a time when rural incomes are extremely low.

In the other place the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) indicated that, to his knowledge, this system is the most expensive in the world. In some countries-as has been the case in Australia-it has been seen to be a public health responsibility, so the exporter paid nothing; or it has been seen to be of assistance to exporters and therefore there is not a requirement for them to pay. What was in the past cannot be allowed to continue into the future, but there is a great necessity to keep costs down.

What is being said in the industry is that it is necessary to get rid of the middle management and bureaucracy within AQIS so that it concentrates on the real aim of inspection and does it as efficiently as possible. The aim, therefore, should be for abattoirs to employ their own government qualified meat inspectors. I would expect that people already qualified, who work with the Quarantine Service, will become such inspectors. They would then be in a far better position than they are currently and they would get higher salaries than they presently earn in the Department. As a result, the abattoirs and growers will also pay reduced costs, which will undoubtedly result in our being more competitive in overseas markets, a highly desirably outcome.

It will not mean the end of government inspection, which is required for many of our markets, but it would result in the export inspection section of AQIS consisting of a small group of highly qualified inspectors with the rights and responsibility to visit any abattoir at any time and randomly check both the abattoir and the work of the company inspectors. It is the Opposition's view that it is better to move as much as possible of the inspection service out of the government sector into the company self-regulated sector. This will leave AQIS with the responsibility for the overseas market requirements. It is worth repeating the example used by the honourable member for Murray in the other place, which was of particular interest to Senator Tambling, who would himself have liked to speak on this Bill. The example used by the honourable member for Murray comes from the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association, and I will quote from it, if I may:

It reports on the abattoir at Alice Springs, which slaughters 10,000 cattle a year. With a new meat inspection fee from next month, that will cost $67,154, or $6.70 per beast. As the average weight is 190 kilograms, it means an additional cost of three and a half cents per kilogram of carcass weight.
In the letter to the Cattle Council-
which was quoted-
the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association says that two weeks ago the meat inspector told management early in the week that he would be-
and this is his word, not mine-

crook on Friday. He presumably had worked it out in advance when he would be crook. An inspector was flown up to Alice Springs from Adelaide, stayed a few days, and then went home as the local inspector was not crook-
on Friday-

after all. All the cattlemen know is that they are paying for this. But it does not stop other costs or charges for each working inspector to cover the following: field administration at $5,432, training expenses at $101, Superannuation at 15% of base salary, $4,769, Comcare premiums at 5.4% of base salary, $1,833, leave loading at 1.5% of base salary, $477, regional office administrative expenses, $6,421, and central office administrative expenses, $5,065.

It is no wonder we are finding it hard to compete in overseas markets. Australian farmers and export companies deserve and need a better and cheaper service, and it is possible. The best way to achieve this objective is to remove control from the present government structure and get it back to the companies with the overall supervision that I have referred to. This will leave the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to provide the necessary inspection for overseas requirements.

Such a process is certainly not a part of this Bill but those looking at it and listening to it cannot help but be impressed by what it is offering and be thinking that it would be nice if the same standards were applied to products imported into this country. An example I am reminded of arose in the discussion during Question Time today of the gas cylinders. Gas cylinders produced in Australia are each one of them inspected for quality, but imported gas cylinders are only randomly inspected. I believe our inspection services are of a high standard and should be maintained that way, but at a cost which is not prohibitive and an inhibition to our competing in overseas markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to hear Senator Reid conclude on that remark, because that is the point I wish to take up. The Australian Democrats are supporting this legislation because it seeks to help guarantee the high quality of food exports in this country, something we should jealously guard. We have seen that quality damaged in the past by the export of food containing unacceptable levels of organochlorin pesticides.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also seen, as a consequence of contamination of food elsewhere-I am pointing here particularly to the Chernobyl experience-that Australian food obtained a premium following the radioactive contamination of food in Europe. The food from Australia is recognised as food which, generally speaking, is of a high quality and not subject to heavy contamination with either chemicals or radioactive materials. Indeed, one could also observe that the National Farmers Federation has come out opposing the use of radiation as a food sterilant, on the grounds that associating food with radioactive sterilisation could jeopardise the opportunities which Australia might have to sell food, or to sell it at a certain price.

However, in picking up the point that Senator Reid concluded on, it seems to me that the inspection services carried out in Australia with respect to exports are far more stringently applied than those applied to imports. Moreover, when imports are found to have levels of various things which are unacceptable in the Australian market, we have seen those imports nonetheless allowed onto the Australian market without Australian consumers being warned as to exactly what it is they are consuming.

As examples of both those situations, I point again to the situation of the Chernobyl reactor fire which resulted in heavy fallout across Europe of a number of radioactive isotopes-some short and some medium term-such as caesium 137. Following that, and in line with Australia's practice indicated by Senator Reid, shipments of food coming into Australia from those areas were not uniformly tested but only sampled.

As I recall the figures, and they came from the man who was actually doing the food testing at that time, in approximately the six months after Chernobyl some 18 shipments of food had come in and been tested, of which three had been found to be contaminated. But in total some 90 shipments had come in, and the remainder had not been tested. So by extension of that proportion, one might assume that there were some 15 shipments of food which came onto the Australian market, which were contaminated by radioactivity and which remained undetected because of the method of sampling and yet entered the Australian food chain. I think that is unacceptable when we seek to apply high standards with respect to the inspection of food being exported from this country. Quite clearly, we should be applying the same standards of inspection, the same requirements for food quality, as for imported food.

The second example in which food was tested relates to the experience early this year with the importation of seaweed from Japan. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service identified samples containing levels of cadmium and arsenic which, in relation to the Australian allowable levels, were quite unacceptable. In fact, they were very, very high indeed. In that particular case the food was nonetheless allowed onto the Australian market.

That bears very much on the issue that Senator Kernot raised yesterday in relation to the establishment of a food authority in that she successfully moved, with the support of the Opposition, an amendment which would require that standards for imported food not be reduced below the existing standards.

Honourable senators may recall that I asked a series of questions on this matter of cadmium and arsenic. Most of the debate and the documents which were tabled centred on the issue of whether the arsenic in that food was organic or inorganic, and whether one should deal with the organic and inorganic arsenic in the same way and by the same standards. No mention was made of the fact that in many of these samples there were high levels of cadmium, which is a cumulative toxic substance which accumulates in the kidneys and which can cause hypertension and other damage. No mention was made at all as to what arguments were put to allow into this country seaweed with levels of cadmium which were above the levels which would be acceptable in Australia.

Again, I simply make the point that we support this legislation. Food should be adequately and properly inspected. There should be appropriate penalties put in the way of those who would seek to abrogate standards, who would seek, by so doing, to bring Australian food exports into disrepute. But at the same time I make a plea in relation to imports that the same stringent standards that are applied to our exports be applied to our imports.

In closing, I point out that, in relation to cadmium and exports, it is well established that some of the Australian soils are now becoming quite cadmium enriched. In the case of sheep, and specifically sheep kidneys from Western Australia, some of those would be above the allowable level in this country. That is something that would not be permitted to be exported under this sort of regime and yet, in the case of the seaweed, we allowed it to be imported, we allowed it to be introduced onto the Australian market without any warning or any identification to potential consumers that this food did not meet the existing Australian standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, I thank the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for their support of this Bill. It is one of the happy occasions on which there is unanimity in this chamber. I note that the two speakers in this debate have raised a number of matters about the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS). It is not my intention now to go into any detail by way of reply, other than to say that many of the things that have been mentioned underline the importance of the role played by AQIS in ensuring that the proper standards are maintained. It also highlights the difficulties of managing and financing an organisation which is better off not being seen nor heard of, but the role of which is essential to the quality of goods Australia exports out of this country and the protection of the health and well-being of our community. With those words, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING TELECOMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGIES
