SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 seeks to amend five Acts administered within the transport and communications portfolio: the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990, the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983, the Civil Aviation Act 1988, the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 and the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the first three Acts are either consequential on other legislation or are intended to correct problems which have occurred due to drafting errors. Given the way legislation is presented under this Government to the Parliament, where there is never adequate time to discuss and debate it, it is not surprising that we have to involve ourselves for a considerable amount of time in rehashing legislation which should never have got through in the first place. I am not talking about the politics of the legislation here; I am talking about the technicalities of putting Bills into workable form so that they can become Acts for the Australian community. I do not wish to spend very much time on the matter this afternoon because we have a large number of other Bills to consider. I will abridge the usual practice of talking about the generalities of the Bill in the second reading debate and save most of my comments for the committee stage.

I will deal with the first three Acts and then go to the latter two. The amendment to the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983 is contained in part VI of the Bill. The final Act to be amended in the Bill in the consequential category is the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act. The proposed amendment is designed to adopt for Australia three sets of amendments, dated December 1987, March 1989 and October 1989, to the annex of the 1987 protocol to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships in 1973. Other proposed amendments will increase the level of the financial penalties provided in the principal Act for various offences. These amendments are supported by the coalition. There are two main amendments which are, firstly, to provide penalties for proven pollution from ships and, secondly, to ensure that notices against the offences can be issued.

The latter provision is very important because it has been difficult in the past to serve notice on ship owners in some of these cases. Under this amendment, it will be possible to serve notice on a ship's agent and, through the agent, on the owner. That, of course, will not have any effect at all on an overseas ship exercising its right of passage through an international waterway, for example through the Torres Strait, where it is guaranteed free passage. But, if it is calling at an Australian port and it has an agent, there is a vehicle for the notice to be served. Obviously, it is quite important for the Parliament to protect the marine life around the Australian coastline as much as it is possible to do so in a legislative form.

The second of these amendments contained in the Bill relates to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority comes under scrutiny within this Bill, as there are some provisions in relation to leave and termination. The Maritime Safety Authority has been in the news in the last 12 months because of the Rockin' Robin report which, sadly, reflected unfavourably on the administration of the Department. I do not propose to go into that at this time, but at some time in the future I do propose to take the time of the Senate to go through the report, which I think had inadequacies, and to comment on the very excellent report by Mr Gruzman, in one of the recent Sydney bulletins, on the need to improve the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a load of crap.
—(Senator Vanstone)-Order!
—I heard what the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support said.
—It has taken him an awfully long time to respond. The report was tabled six months ago.

—I know that, Minister, but we will get around to it some time-do not worry. I think that the report has been brought back into prominence by Mr Gruzman's comments, which are very pertinent to the situation. Whether Mr Gruzman is right or wrong is not the real point. The real point is whether the Department has learnt and improved from the errors it has obviously made in the past. That is what we are going to consider at some future time.

SPEECH.PARA: Part III of the Bill seeks to amend the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983. This amendment is to cover a drafting error which affected the legal entitlement, but not the actual entitlement, of superannuation benefits to Australian National Railways Commission employees who were employed by Tasmanian State railways before the transfer of the railways to the Commonwealth in 1975. The Opposition will support this move.

The major contentious part of the Bill before us relates to part IV, which deals with changes to the Civil Aviation Act and, to a lesser degree, changes to the Federal Airports Corporation Act. I want to hold most of my comments for the committee stage of this Bill, but I make the general observation that this is not the sort of legislation that should come before the Parliament. It is just not the way to write a Bill. It gives enormous powers to the Government. In fact, it gives all the powers that any operator or agent of the Government would want in carrying out his duty and shows very little, or no concern at all, for the individual rights of an Australian citizen. It really is a stand and deliver piece of legislation- `stand and deliver or I am going to kick the door in'. As I said earlier, there is no necessity to write legislation in that way. The Bill ought to be focused far more carefully on the needs of the Government to ensure compliance with the intent and it ought not take such wide-reaching powers unto itself to pursue its legitimate aims.

We have to remember that people actually implement this legislation. The Civil Aviation Authority, like all other departments, is not immune from having unsuitable people out there in the field and their agents. That is not to say that everyone is unsuitable, but if even one person in 100 or one person in 200 who has an immature personality, or an inadequate personality in some way, has support from legislation which is thoughtlessly put together to give them powers, it can be guaranteed that they will use those powers to the limit of the legislation with great social consequences-consequences that are quite disproportionate, in many cases, to the ends achieved by what they are doing.

In the section that deals with the Civil Aviation Authority there are some points that appear to be redundant, where clauses repeat earlier clauses. I have mentioned the attribution of excessive powers to inspectors under the Civil Aviation Act, and I very much look forward to the Minister's explanations at the committee stage. In light of those explanations, we will have to determine, as Mr Jull foreshadowed in another place when he was speaking to the second reading of this Bill, the need to amend the legislation to guarantee the basic civil rights of Australian citizens under this part of the legislation.

I will also seek some explanation on documentation in relation to manuals and such matters. I think it is a good proposition that, where responsible authorities overseas have approved the certification of aircraft and/or operating procedures and maintenance procedures, we follow them. As honourable senators will know, for many years I was campaigning for the acceptance of certification from authorities such as the American Federal Aviation Authority and the British Civil Aviation Authority. Where they certified aircraft as being suitable and meeting the standards required for regular public transport use, it was a nonsense for this country to be running duplicate inspection procedures and involving airlines in expenses of many millions of dollars in reinventing the wheel when the certification had been done very exhaustively in the country of manufacture. I am pleased that the Government has accepted that it is no longer necessary to do that.

An extension of the same principle is to accept that maintenance practices and procedures for aircraft, as laid down by the manufacturer, are acceptable within Australia. The only caveat I would put to that is that there has been a disproportionate impact as a consequence of product liability legislation in the United States of America, particularly in the general aviation sector, so much so that the former giants of the light aircraft field-companies such as Piper and Cessna, which manufactured hundreds if not thousands of aircraft a year-have virtually closed their single engine production lines. I can remember some years ago, in the recent past, Beechcraft being reported as saying that 25 per cent of the price of a new single engine Beechcraft aircraft, somewhere between $200,000 and $250,000 in the United States, was made up of insurance premiums for product liability. That is really a measure of the extraordinary effect of the legal profession in the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —They no longer manufacture them as a result; isn't that correct?

—I think the Beechcraft line is still going but at a very slow rate. The Minister would be aware that the Piper and the Cessna single engine line has stopped and started, and it is just a trickle compared with the river that it was before. This is a consequence of the product liability. The flow-on from that can be seen in the maintenance and support side. The American manufacturers Piper, Cessna, Mooney, Beech and other companies, are recommending maintenance procedures which are taken to extremes to cover themselves against any product liability charges. Instead of using `on condition', or letting some component run for five or 10 years, or 1,000 hours or 2,000 hours, they are recommending changes after a very short period, which imposes an enormous cost penalty on an operator of the particular air frame or engine. The manufacturers make no secret of the fact that it is purely to avoid product liability.

SPEECH.PARA: Lest the Minister thinks I am exaggerating, I would inform him that there have been numerous actions where a manufacturer, such as Cessna or Piper, having produced an aircraft in 1950 or the early 1960s and then never having seen the aircraft again-it having been sold through maybe 10 or 20 owners and subjected to all sorts of treatment and finally being involved in a fatal accident-has had American courts award damages against it for a product that it last saw go through its factory door maybe 25 or 30 years ago.

So product liability is a very serious business, and that is what has driven American maintenance procedures-in some cases, not all-to quite uneconomic lengths for a private operator. I hope that the Civil Aviation Authority in Australia will take a reasonable view of maintenance procedures with respect to general aviation aircraft.

My understanding of the legislation as I have seen it-and I say that with caution, because every time I open the mail I get a different proposal from the CAA on airspace legislation and maintenance; it is changing the whole time and it is very hard to know where we stand on it-is that it provides for the owner of an aircraft or the operator of a fleet of aircraft to come up with a proposal of its own for approval by the Authority. That would obviate this need.

The amendments in respect of the Federal Airports Commission relate to airport security. The Minister mentions a saving of $15m if the amended provisions are implemented, and I hope we do see a saving in those operations. Like the CAA, the unfortunate thing about the FAC is that there is no brake on its expenditure. It decides what it will spend on various occasions and then tries to recover the cost from a very small taxation base.

While no-one would argue that security is not terribly important at the major capital city airports and the international terminals, in country areas and at secondary airports it is really a very different matter. I think the secondary airports of the capital cities of Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth have got to be viewed in their own light. There are different environments in Bankstown from those at Parafield or Archerfield, for example.
I have a letter here from the Federal Airports Corporation, sent to me by an enraged client, which reads: `Circular to all Tenants'. This letter was promulgated in the last month. It reads:
Over the past few months, we have attempted to initiate a 2 man, on base, after hours Mobile Security System. To date, the response has been `lukewarm', but encouraging!!
I do not know how there can be a lukewarm approach that is encouraging. But the next sentence is a very interesting one, because it says:
The Federal Airports Corporation will be persevering with the concept until `Bludgeoned to Death'.
The FAC is obviously closely in touch with its clients if it is volunteering that it will persevere with it until it is `bludgeoned to death'. The letter goes on:
In the interim, a `Security Forum' is to be held on Tuesday June 25, and the enclosure gives full details.

There is only a short sentence to end the letter. What is happening there is that the FAC is putting a two-man security force after dark onto an airfield where, apart from the theft of aviation gasoline from fuel tanks, there has been no theft at all and no security problem.

The FAC is going to attempt to recover the quite high cost of two people on duty in the hours of darkness in a 365-day year from a very small taxation base. What is even worse, it is going to try to recover that cost from people who have already invested tens of thousands of dollars in building hangars which have to comply with wind strength requirements of up to about 140 or 150 knots in cyclonic conditions, and they are absolutely secure against theft, short of theft committed by someone breaking in with an oxyacetylene torch.

If some owner invests tens of thousands of dollars in his own security by building a hangar, it is hardly reasonable to then impose a security charge on him to cover people who do not expend such sums of money and want to park their aircraft out on the grass, particularly when the problem itself is really of quite low incidence. It is sad that this reflects one of the unfortunate tendencies within the FAC, and that is to empire build.

I very much welcome the reduction in staff numbers that is promulgated for the Civil Aviation Authority because, compared with the figures for civil aviation authorities in other countries, the Australian figure is quite disproportionate. What I look forward to with great interest, though, is finding out where those reductions are going to take place-whether they come out of head office and people on salaries of $100,000 and $150,000 a year or out of the surveyors and people who are actually in the line trying to maintain standards. I rather suspect that the surveyors are going to come out of this worse than people in air-conditioned offices. But that is not a matter for the Bill before us today. With those few words, I wish the Bill a speedy passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats find no difficulty with the amendments to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990, the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 and the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983. In fact, we take the opportunity to praise the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) for adopting the recent amendments to the International Convention for Prevention of Pollution from Ships 1973. Even one of the Government's most vocal critics-Greenpeace-is impressed with the new penalties for ships disgorging chemicals.

SPEECH.PARA: I was going to seek clarification on the issues raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I have since received a copy of a letter from the Minister and I seek leave to incorporate it, because I do not think we actually have it on the record in any other way at the moment.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Transport and Communications
Minister for Land Transport
The Hon. Bob Brown MP...Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
20 JUNE 1991
Senator B Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee for the
Scrutiny of Bills
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator

I refer to the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 10 of 1991 (5 June) concerning some aspects of the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, which was referred to my Office for comment by Mr Argument on 6 June 1991.
Monitoring warrants
Clause 12-proposed new section 32ad
The Committee questioned both the need for the warrants and also why they should be valid for one month.

The Air Safety Regulation Review Task Force in its second report, when noting the Civil Aviation Authority's responsibility for air navigation safety, voiced its concern over the lack of clearly defined legislative powers residing with the Authority to meet this responsibility. The amendments currently proposed to the Civil Aviation Act 1988 are an attempt to fill this perceived need.

Compliance with statutory safety requirements ensures that aircraft operators, by adopting required operating and maintenance practice, realise an acceptable level of safety for their aircraft. The Authority's responsibility for maintaining safe air navigation can only be achieved, however, if there is some assurance that these statutory requirements are being complied with by aircraft operators. The Authority, therefore, has an over-riding obligation to see that operators discharge their responsibilities adequately. This duty is discharged through the Authority's surveillance activities and day-to-day interaction with the aviation industry.

In practice, the extent of compliance with the statutory safety requirements by aircraft operators is influenced by the effectiveness of the Authority to monitor and guide the industry through its policies, guidelines and procedures, through education programs and in the power vested with the Authority to take effective remedial action when an operator is found not to be complying with legislative safety standards.
The statutory air safety requirements are numerous; a broad sample includes the following:

* commercial aircraft operators must have an adequate organisation, including trained staff, together with workshop and other equipment and facilities in order to ensure that airframes, engines, propellers, instruments, equipment and accessories are properly maintained at all times when they are in use;

* an aircraft operator must ensure that provision is made for the proper and periodic instruction of all maintenance personnel and must provide a training and checking organisation to ensure that members of the operator's operating crews maintain their competency. The training programs, the training and checking organisation and the tests and checks provided by the organisation are all subject to the approval of the Authority; and

* aircraft maintenance can only be undertaken by persons who are licensed by the Authority. Such maintenance can usually only be carried out in premises that have been approved as being adequate for the purpose by the Authority.

In order to ensure compliance with such requirements, the Authority needs to be able to carry out quality assurance audits of aircraft operators, their facilities and authorised maintenance workshops. These audits are absolutely necessary to ensure that statutory requirements are being maintained and that the Australian public thereby continues to enjoy the highest level of aviation safety.

Normally, aircraft operators co-operate with the auditing process voluntarily. It is essential, however, that the Authority have some mechanism whereby it can carry out an audit when an operator refuses to cooperate and denies the Authority entry to premises. Clearly, if the Authority was not allowed entry, then it would be unable to carry out its statutory function to `conduct safety regulation of civil aviation operations in Australia'.

The purpose of the monitoring provisions, and in particular the provisions relating to obtaining a warrant for the purposes of monitoring compliance with the Civil Aviation Act and subordinate legislation, is to enable the Authority to establish that the statutory safety requirements are being met by an aircraft operator and thereby avoiding potential air disasters.

The duration of one month for the warrant is not considered to be overly long owing to the considerable number of tasks and the time-consuming nature of the work associated with the auditing process. Another relevant factor is that the auditing process periodically has to be carried out at maintenance premises situated in remote areas.
Abrogation of privilege against self-incrimination
Clause 12-proposed new section 32aj

The Committee notes that proposed section 32aj is drafted in a form which it has previously been prepared to accept, but has requested my advice as to the kind of information that might be sought pursuant to this provision.

The inclusion of such a provision into the Civil Aviation Act was also recommended by the Air Safety Regulation Review Task Force in its second report. In reviewing the shortcomings in the investigative powers of the Authority, the Task Force noted that there was no obligation on persons to assist investigators or to answer their questions. The Task Force thus recommended that `subject to the protections suggested regarding self incrimination and inadmissibility of evidence, persons should be required to provide answers to authorized officers who are investigating breaches of air safety requirements'.

Proposed section 32aj provides that a person is obliged to answer an authorised investigator's questions and produce any books, records or documents requested by the investigator. If the person objects to doing so on the grounds of self-incrimination, and the investigator informs him/her of the obligation to answer the questions/produce the material, that person cannot refuse, without reasonable excuse, to answer the questions/produce the material, but the answer/material is essentially not admissible in proceedings against him/her.

Such a power is appropriate for Authority investigators and is a provision commonly found in other legislation. For example, Bureau of Air Safety Investigation investigators have similar powers provided to them under the Air Navigation Regulations.

The information which would be sought by investigators pursuant to this provision would relate to the maintenance and operation of aircraft. Such data, obtained from, for example, maintenance schedules, work sheets and oral statements from pilots and aircraft personnel, would be used by investigators to establish whether the appropriate maintenance has been carried out on an aircraft, whether maintenance operations were performed in a suitable manner, whether proper checks were carried out on an aircraft at the required times, etc.

Unequivocal access to all information relating to the maintenance and operation of aircraft is an essential part of the surveillance and enforcement function of the Authority. It is, therefore, fundamental to the fulfilment of the Authority's statutory functions that persons be required to answer questions and produce documents relating to the maintenance and operation of aircraft. The Authority would, otherwise, be hampered in the performance of its quality assurance audit and investigative roles to the detriment of air navigation safety in Australia.
Adoption of extrinsic material by regulation
Clause 15-proposed new subsection 98(3a)

The Committee, whilst acknowledging that this provision will allow Australia to meet its international obligations in relation to the safety of air navigation, expressed concern that it would allow matter to be incorporated into regulations without being subject to Parliamentary scrutiny.

The necessity for this amendment stems from recent advice received from the Attorney-General's Department that section 49a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 effectively prevents the Authority from requiring operators to comply with amendments to, amongst other similar technical documents, flight and operation manuals. The Civil Aviation Regulations currently empower the Authority to make necessary alterations to flight manuals, etc. and for persons to comply with such alterations.

The flight manual is a basic technical, operational document required for all aircraft. It is also one of the Authority's primary regulatory tools and alterations to it are often required directly as the result of the discovery of defects in an aircraft affecting its safe operation.

The manuals, being technical documents, are administrative rather than legislative in nature. Any alterations required to be made to them are generally changes to mechanical or operational requirements involving a high level of technical complexity.

Once alterations are made to these documents, the Authority notifies all relevant aircraft operators of the changes. This it generally does either by directly notifying operators and sending them a copy of the alteration or, when a broad class of aircraft is affected, through issuing a Civil Aviation Order setting out the amendment.

Importantly, alterations to these documents are the means by which the Authority provides the most up-to-the-minute safety requirements for aircraft. The only practical mechanism to maintain Australia's foremost safety standards is via a mechanism which provides that amendments to the manuals have force of law once they are adopted. That is, via the mechanism proposed by new subsection 98(3a).

The Authority (and previously, my Department) has been requiring aircraft operators and pilots to comply with flight and operation manuals (and subsequent amendments to such manuals) since the commencement of the regulation of air navigation in Australia in the 1920s. This is also standard practice in all leading overseas aviation countries and is well understood and accepted by the aviation industry. As a contracting state to the Convention on International Civil Aviation, Australia has an international obligation to provide for such manuals under Annexes 6 and 8 to the Convention. It is essential that there be no legal doubt about the Authority's power in this area. The purpose of this proposed amendment is to put beyond doubt the Authority's power to require aircraft operators to comply with amendments to technical aircraft manuals, such as flight manuals, in order to ensure that Australia continues to meet its international obligations in relation to the safety of air navigation.
I trust these comments satisfactorily address the Committee's concerns.
Yours sincerely
BOB BROWN

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not need to proceed with my amendment dealing with the issue raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, clause 15, proposed new subsection 98 (3a).

SPEECH.PARA: Having made those comments about the first few Bills, I want to indicate that the Democrats are not comfortable though with the amendments to the Federal Airports Corporation Act, specifically the provision to rationalise the responsibilities for airport security by making airport operators, including the Federal Airports Corporation, responsible for the counterterrorist presence, overall access control and security of the air side areas of airports.

I do not mean to be a worrywart; I just want to place on the record some of my concerns. It is a little worrying to me, based on observation of similar rationalisations overseas, that we have profit oriented commercial airport operators with a main duty to shareholders. They are now responsible for the safety of the travelling public within one-ninth of the world's airspace. We fear that Australia's safety record does not provide incentive to commercial concerns to offer the highest possible standard of security and safety.

Ironically, this is an area where our unblemished record could act as a sort of disincentive in that a commercial operation might be able in the first few years to cut corners or perform to minimum standards without noticeable difference until something serious happens. I think it is true, and the Minister might like to comment on this, that in the United States, maybe not constantly but often, airport operators are fined for not taking adequate security measures. Often, the choice between paying the fine and providing high standards of security is an easy one. It is easier to pay the fine than to pay the increased costs-especially if that country has no history of terrorism.

An investigation into the Lockerbie tragedy revealed that it may have been prevented if security measures had been adequately maintained and the company had not been cutting corners to save costs. Security is always `adequate' until it is breached or until something serious happens and we have another look at it. Our international marketing edge is that Australia is a safe haven, with its second to none air safety and security record. Tourists are known to shun countries where there is danger.

I do not want Australia to risk losing that image or tourists on the grounds of cost discipline, as pointed out in the Bill's explanatory memorandum. I do not want us to pay a high price in another form for this cost efficiency. When it comes down to the question of security, I ask: what constitutes a minimum standard as outlined in the second reading speech of the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) in the other place? The standard we have now exists because of the achievement of the whole community. I intend to ask for more details on this in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their support for the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill. As Senator Kernot said, there are a number of aspects that are extremely welcome. I join with Senator Kernot, from a personal point of view, in saying that I am particularly pleased, as Minister responsible for the administration of this Act, to see the amendments directed to tightening up the very difficult problem of pollution at sea and avoiding in Australia the catastrophic consequences for the environment that, regrettably, have occurred elsewhere in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of what we have in front of us today and the time constraints, I shall address briefly the comments of Senator MacGibbon. I thank Senator MacGibbon, who has an expert knowledge of this industry and a direct involvement in it, for his positive comments about the changes that are being made by the Government in this area. However, I would like to comment on Senator MacGibbon's reference to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) and the Rockin Robin incident and to what he referred to as `the excellent report' by Mr Gruzman in the Bulletin about that incident; although he then went on to make what I thought was rather a strange statement. In respect of that `excellent report', he went on to say that whether it was right or wrong was neither here nor there. I do not think he can have it both ways. An article that got such prominence in the Bulletin being right or wrong I think is certainly here and there in respect of the criticisms it made.

I wrote a detailed rebuttal of that article to the Bulletin, and at this time it has not been published. Rather than delay the Senate for one unnecessary minute by reading even a paragraph from it, I seek leave of the Senate to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MINISTER FOR SHIPPING AND
AVIATION SUPPORT
Senator The Honourable. Bob Collins
Senator for the Northern Territory
Darwin Office, Parliament House
7th Floor, Mitchell Street, Canberra ACT 2600
Darwin NT 0800 Australia
The Editor
The Bulletin
GPO Box 3957
SYDNEY NSW 2001
Dear Sir,
I wish to take this opportunity to respond to an article (Bulletin, June 11) written by Laurence Gruzman Q.C. concerning the search for the yacht Rockin Robin 8-11 June 1990.

Mr Gruzman's article is a major distortion of the facts. Not only does he misrepresent what happened he also indulges in pure conjecture as to the fate of the missing men in a way which is completely contrary to eye witness accounts. He further asserts that ``nobody is interested and nobody will be interested until the next tragedy occurs'' and also ``we have learned a few things, but in many respects it is unfortunately business as before''.
Nothing could be further from the truth.

All those involved in search and rescue operations care deeply about any loss of life and are committed to improving systems, procedures and equipment. Often, as was the case in this tragic incident aircraft crews put their own lives at risk whilst attempting to save others.
It is perhaps worth recounting the actual facts of the Rockin Robin incident as detailed in the report of the official investigation and what has been done since.

The weather conditions on 8 June 1990 at the scene of the distress were very severe. Early in the afternoon the pilot of the RAAF Orion aircraft reported zero forward visibility, cloud base down to 100 metres, with hurricane force winds of 65 knots and wave heights in excess of 14 metres.

The RAAF aircrew, far from being inaccurate with the drop as Mr Gruzman asserts, displayed considerable skill in deploying the two life-raft Air Sea Rescue Kit in the correct position relative to the target. This was made more difficult by the severe weather conditions, and because the yacht was still sailing across the wind at approximately six knots.

Despite instructions to remain with the yacht, the crew chose, prematurely, to abandon it and take to one of the life-rafts which had been dropped. Reports and photographs indicate that the yacht was still afloat some two hours after the abandonment and even then apparently not in a sinking condition.

The multi-unit Air Sea Rescue Kit dropped to the yacht was of a type that has been in service for many years and has proven to be extremely successful both in Australia and world wide. In the extreme weather conditions, the multi-unit kit had a far better chance of success than the single unit kit proposed by Mr Gruzman.

At 1015 on 8 June, some two hours after the abandonment the French military aircraft overhead, was about to drop a radio and another life-raft to the yacht's crew but was unable to, due to the severity of the weather and sea conditions.
In order to fully understand what happened on the 8 June it is necessary to be aware of the eye witness accounts provided by the pilots of the various search aircraft.
We know from pilots' reports that the occupied life-raft was observed to overturn on at least two occasions, spilling all four persons into the sea.

Following the second occasion on which the life-raft overturned one person was seen on the raft trying to right it, the three others were in the sea holding onto the life-raft sides. Aircraft continuously flew above and at 1343 only one person could be seen lying across a badly deflated life-raft reportedly in a sinking condition. This was the last definitive sighting. Taking into consideration the severe weather conditions, the heavy balance of probabilities suggests that the three were unable to regain the liferaft and succumbed in the water. Survival time would not have been long.

Aircrew observing the tragic scene knew at the time that in the prevailing conditions there was little hope for the person lying across the raft and that they were powerless to assist. It has to be assumed that this liferaft soon deflated to the extent that it no longer could provide adequate support.

Given all of the above, Mr Gruzman's assertion in the article that the crew lived in the life-raft for a further two weeks can only be described as fanciful. It is highly unlikely that the crew managed to get back into the life-raft. Continuing searches for the life-raft failed to locate it. The search did, however, locate the other unoccupied life-raft, which provided a clear datum for the continuing search.

Mr Gruzman's conclusions in the section of the article headed `Why did it happen?' are particularly suspect. His analysis is not supported by the evidence. To suggest that the RAAF, who first located the Rockin Robin in hazardous conditions, were primarily responsible for the loss of the men in dropping a life-raft with no means of communication, no EPIRB, no food, water or signalling equipment is a gross misrepresentation of the facts.
Following the loss of the yacht, I directed that the Department of Transport and Communications undertake an investigation into the search and rescue aspects of the incident.

The comprehensive investigation report highlighted some deficiencies in search and rescue procedures. It concluded, however, that those deficiencies had no effect on the outcome of that particular incident. I tabled the report of the investigation in the Senate on 18 October 1991.

All nine recommendations made in the report have now been implemented. There are new procedures for passing information, several droppable pumps have been purchased and strategically placed round Australia. The Civil Aviation Authority has ordered 200 radio beacons for installation into life-rafts as well as twenty life-rafts with increased stability and which are already fitted with radio beacons. In short, there have been significant changes since this incident occurred.

The incident was tragic, as is any incident involving loss of life. However, I am satisfied that everything possible was done to rescue the four persons from the situation they found themselves in. I am also satisfied there has been significant improvements in systems and procedures, and search and rescue equipment.

Mr Gruzman's article is misleading and inaccurate. It contributed little to improving search and rescue operations and it very likely caused further anguish to the relatives of the Rockin Robin crew. I again extend my sympathy to them.
(Bob Collins)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like also to touch briefly on some comments Senator MacGibbon made in respect of the amendments empowering civil aviation inspectors in the performance of their duties, which he referred to as stand and deliver legislation. It is not at all. I am quite happy to expand on it again briefly in the committee stage. The wording of this legislation is wording with which I am very familiar. These are standard provisions that occur not just in numerous Acts of parliament-I am happy to give a brief resume-but in the Acts of all State and Territory legislatures.

SPEECH.PARA: When I first got this clarified-I must say this was for the protection of the operator, not the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA)-in relation to what had to be done so that people would not be able to bang down doors, as has been alleged, I asked whether the standard provision empowering people to look for things and seize them was there, and it was. So this is very familiar legislation indeed. We will find it not in dozens but in scores of Acts of parliaments around Australia; not just in the Federal legislature but in State and Territory legislatures as well.

Senator MacGibbon said, in respect of the changes that are being made within the CAA, that `I get a different proposal from CAA every time I open my mail.' I can understand the very legitimate concern of people in the aviation industry, such as Senator MacGibbon, with these changes; but I point out the reason for them. I am sure he would acknowledge that this is correct. I am pleased that this is what is happening because the changes are a result of positive responses the organisation is making to representations it is getting on these proposals from the industry.

In respect of the air space management proposals, it is a matter of fact that the CAA has agreed, I am pleased to say because of my own concerns about the original proposals, with the changes brought about as a direct result of a very successful input by pilots and pilot organisations around Australia as to the concerns they had about the original proposals. I also thank Senator MacGibbon for the positive statements he made about the difficult changes that are being accomplished currently in the CAA. In response to Senator MacGibbon's inquiry as to where the cuts are coming from, the CAA has prepared a resource document which gives detailed information-it is an inch thick-on precisely where the cuts are coming from. On a confidential basis, because it is a matter that is being currently negotiated, as I am sure Senator MacGibbon is aware, with the staff and the unions, I would be perfectly happy to allow Senator MacGibbon to scrutinise that document so that he can see, down to the last individual, precisely where those cuts are proposed to take place. So he can have access to that document.

I also thank Senator Kernot for the support she gave to what are positive amendments in respect of pollution control. She raised the question of security and expressed concerns, which I think I can put to rest substantially, about these minimum requirements that are going to be laid down. They will be laid down in the form of regulation and, because of that, they will be subject to the scrutiny of this House.

Senator Kernot said, quite rightly, that security is a worry and a concern for everyone, and overseas there have been some well-publicised breaches of airport security. She did make the point that she was concerned that privately run security is a difficulty because of the fact that companies tend to be more worried about responsibilities to their shareholders.

In the case of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC)-and this has been a matter of deliberate policy of the Government; the Opposition does differ from us to some extent in this area-I would point out what Senator Kernot knows to be the case, and that is that in this case the only shareholder is the Government. Might I say to Senator Kernot that the fact that the senior Minister in this portfolio, Mr Beazley, despite the fact that I am responsible for the FAC, has deliberately retained the area of airport security, is an indication of just how important the Government does take this question. I do not want to delay the Senate any longer, bearing in mind what we have in front of us. I once again thank the two senators who spoke in this debate for the contribution that they made and for their support for the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer to part III, investigation powers. Would the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) define what qualifications and what experience an investigator has to have for the purposes of this part?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers concerned in these investigations have to be duly authorised officers of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). It is, indeed, the Authority that, in the first instance, determines the qualifications of these officers. Of course, for obvious reasons it does not appoint to these positions people who are not suitably qualified. For the advice of Senator MacGibbon, might I say that with the exception of one officer who, of course, is competent in his area, all of the officers that are authorised by the Civil Aviation Authority to carry out these roles are in the main either former officers of either State or Federal police forces or have been fully trained in police procedures in terms of investigation and prosecution.

—I find it surprising that people are not being appointed to look at technical breaches in respect of maintenance or anything like that. The Department is looking at people who really are trained to investigate criminal offences?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No. That is not the case. I am simply pointing out to Senator MacGibbon that they are investigating breaches of civil aviation regulations and, therefore, they are expert in the aviation field. But they have an additional role and that additional role requires them to act on behalf of the Authority. I have no doubt that Senator MacGibbon would be the first one to support that there is very little point at all in having regulations if there is not some effective way of policing them to ensure that, for the safety of others in the air, operators comply with them.

SPEECH.PARA: These people are expert in the areas that they have to implement. But it is as unnecessary in this legislation to spell out the qualifications of inspectors as it would be in a police Act to spell out the personal qualifications for officers who act as police officers with the same powers. I just said that the Authority looks for people who do have skills in investigation, because those investigations could, of course, lead to subsequent court action and prosecution. People have to be particularly trained in that. But, of course, fundamentally they are people who are expert in ensuring that the CAA's regulations are policed properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from that that the Authority therefore has a list of approved personnel who can be investigators. It may not be a public list but it is within the Authority's own administrative procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: I will move on to my next question. Why is a fine of only $100 imposed on a member or a former member of the Authority who presents as an inspector when he no longer has the right to do so conferred on him by the Authority? This society takes very strong exception to misrepresentation. If con men get before the courts, they are rather heavily dealt with. The courts take a particularly dim view of someone who presents himself as a policeman but is not a policeman.

The imposition of a fine of only $100, which in today's devalued currency is really just pin money-a night out on the town or something like that-is quite disproportionate compared with the $3,000 fine which is imposed on ordinary citizens under later clauses of the Bill. This really leads to the assumption that the drafters of this Bill have a them-and-us mentality. Members of the CAA will just be tapped lightly across the wrist if they commit what I think is rather a serious breach of conduct by presenting themselves as an inspector or an investigator when they are not. Yet, under a provision later on in the Bill, if a person refuses to answer a question, he will be down the tube for $3,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Frankly, I think Senator MacGibbon's point is well taken. Can I just say that I do not believe at all that the penalty for failing to answer questions is at all too severe because it is, of course, the failure to answer questions that in effect means that the inspectors simply cannot carry out their role.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that the $100 fine is a standard provision in other Acts. But can I say to Senator MacGibbon: I agree with him. I do not think that is sufficient. I am sure that Senator MacGibbon would agree with this suggestion: rather than amend this on the run, as it were, in here now-I would like to refer to other Acts where perhaps similar penalties do apply; perhaps they could also be looked at-could I give Senator MacGibbon an undertaking in committee now that we will examine the level of that penalty, which I do not think is sufficient; that, in consultation with Senator MacGibbon, we will re-examine for potential future amendment an increase in that penalty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us move to proposed section 32a. What happens in the situation where the owner-occupier, or whoever is responsible for the premises, is not available to give consent? Will access to the premises take place in the absence of consent from the owner-occupier in those circumstances?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator MacGibbon's question is categorically, no.

—Could I ask a general question as to why proposed section 32a is written in and followed by proposed section 32a when, in a very real sense, both clauses provide for the same situation? Why was there a need to have both ad and af in the first instance?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very simply, for the protection of the operator in the aviation sector. We could have provided for one section, allowing an inspector to come into a premises and do what he liked if he had reasonable grounds for thinking an actual offence had taken place. We could have taken what would be a first step, and indeed a step that is exercised and must be exercised more often than the second step, of simply ensuring that an operator, where some concern exists, is complying with the regulation. But, for the protection of the operator, we wanted to lay out very clearly that that first step involved a very specific role, a far less intrusive role, of simply gaining access to monitor whether the operator had in fact committed an offence rather than simply move to assuming that the operator had. The reason they have been deliberately separated is in fact for the protection of the operator in the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that was the basis for it, I presume it could be argued that under the provisions of proposed new section 32ad it would be justified in granting the warrant for one month rather than the shorter period of one week in the other case.
—That is correct.
—Proposed new section 32ad (1) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: An investigator may apply to a magistrate for a warrant under this section in relation to particular prescribed premises.
Yet, proposed new section 32af (1) provides:
An investigator may apply to a magistrate for a warrant under this section in relation to particular premises.
Why has the word `prescribed' been inserted in proposed new section 32ad (1) and not in proposed new section 32af (1)?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is because of the very specific difference between the provisions of a monitoring warrant and a warrant relating to an offence. Again, this relates to protection of the operator. The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) may have some concern that an operator is not complying. Senator MacGibbon would be well aware of how those concerns can arise quite often, and I am well aware of this through the work done by my office. Sometimes complaints can come from passengers. Sometimes they ring up and describe what happened on a particular flight and raise their concerns. In 99 per cent of the cases that are brought to me, and this occurs regularly, we find out that the concerned passenger might have had a bit of a fright, that something might have happened but they have no real cause for concern. That is how these things come about. That would apply to a particular prescribed premises.

SPEECH.PARA: If the CAA wanted to monitor the operations of an organisation, which would involve some degree of time to do, hopefully in as unobtrusive a way as possible, it is reasonable to require that it relate not just to particular premises but to particular prescribed premises. They must be nailed down exactly. It cannot simply be a general aviation operator. The actual address of the person has to be nailed right down. In the case of an offence being committed, it could well be that it might apply to a general class of operators; in other words, particular premises, where a number of operators might be involved in the matter and where there would be no requirement to actually prescribe each individual address of the operators. Once again, in the case of the monitoring warrants, it is simply an additional built-in protection for the operator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from what the Minister has been telling me that proposed new section 32ad is referring to a less intrusive warrant than is proposed new section 32af. If that is so, why does proposed new section 32ad (4) (b) refer to authorised entry being made at any time of the day or night or during specified hours of the day or night? I would assume that going into someone's premises at 2 o'clock in the morning would be far more intrusive than at 2 o'clock in the afternoon.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct, and that is why it is spelt out. Can I say, from personal experience in the Northern Territory, that magistrates, and indeed in some cases Supreme Courts, on occasions have been scathing in their criticism of these warrants being executed where officers have not complied with provisions like this. The reason why this has been stated quite specifically is that that is the requirement placed on the officer when applying for the warrant. In other words, the onus is on the operator and he has to actually satisfy the magistrate as to when the intrusion into a person's premises will occur. That has to be stated on the warrant. It is there to provide an additional protection for the operator. If it is a monitoring warrant, for example, relating to a company whose operations are normally conducted during daylight hours and very rarely at night, a magistrate may well say that it is not convenient or reasonable to go in at 2 o'clock in the morning. If that is stated clearly on the warrant but the officers go in outside the hours stipulated that would almost inevitably render any prosecution ineffective. Again, it is a protection for the operator.

—When the Authority makes application for a warrant and states the reason, is there any obligation on the authority to advise the suspect or client, or whoever is the subject of the investigation, that a warrant has been granted and that a visitation is likely to ensue?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the case of the original monitoring powers, the provision is there in the case of proposed new section 32ac for them to be exercised with consent. The answer to Senator MacGibbon's question is, technically, no. Such a requirement would in fact defeat the purpose of the exercise. What is clearly laid out in proper form in the Act is that a prior step must be taken before seeking a warrant. What the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) would do, under proposed new section 32ac, if it wished to monitor the operations of an organisation, would be to approach the operator and ask, by consent, for that operation to be carried out. It would only be where an operator refused to give that consent that the CAA would have to go to the next step of applying for a warrant. Of course, through the absolutely explicit advice to the operator, by that stage the operator would be well aware of what the next step would be if the operator refused to give the CAA access to the operation.
—Where is it provided in the Act that the Authority has to apply for consent for a visit before applying for the warrant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed new section 32ad (2) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to subsection (3), the magistrate may issue the warrant if satisfied, by information on oath, that it is reasonably necessary that the investigator should have access to the premises for the purpose of finding out whether the relevant legislation is being complied with.

That has been deliberately put in there. I am happy to say, categorically, that there would not be a magistrate in Australia who, when an application was made for a warrant under proposed new section 32ad, would not inquire as to whether the first step under proposed new section 32ac had been taken, and, of course, the magistrate would need to be satisfied totally of what extraordinary circumstances might have applied that required a warrant without any initial permission being sought-otherwise the warrant would not be granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed new section 32ad (4) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) authorise an investigator named in the warrant, with such assistance and by such force as is necessary and reasonable, to enter, and exercise inspection powers on, the premises;

Can the Minister delineate the premise on which such reasonable force is based? What is `reasonable force'? Is it using an oxyacetylene torch to gain entry to a steel hangar? Is it kicking in the front door of a flight office? Does it relate to the involvement of other people? Can an investigator turn up with a team of strong-arm operators and move into premises? Who is liable for restitution if property damage occurs? Will it be the lot of the citizen who has been investigated to sue the Commonwealth through the courts for restitution for property damage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator MacGibbon's question, I would point out that these are very standard provisions indeed. The legislative provision calling for reasonable force probably has as much case law attached to it as anything one finds in legislation. It is a very well known provision to which courts routinely apply themselves. The word `reasonable' in that case, I assure Senator MacGibbon, has been tested on many occasions before Australian courts. Indeed, it is the magistrate or judge on each occasion who would determine what reasonable force is required.

SPEECH.PARA: The picture painted by Senator MacGibbon is extreme. I am not suggesting that it could never occur, but it would occur so infrequently that it is not the norm. The other persons who could well be required to attend would in the majority of cases most likely be police officers in whichever jurisdiction the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) was operating at that time. I assure Senator MacGibbon that there is a very onerous requirement on officers of the law when executing these warrants to prove that the onus is on them and that whatever they do is reasonable in the circumstances. If they failed to do that, courts here have consistently dealt with those departments that exercise unreasonable behaviour with the standard provisions in a very direct way. What normally happens in such cases, apart from anything else, is that the prosecutions fail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister deal with the matter of compensation for damage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter for the normal provisions of the law. It would depend entirely on the circumstances of each case as to whether a person could sue for damages. All I am saying is that these are absolutely standard provisions which Senator MacGibbon will find in hundreds of Acts of Parliament in the Federal, State and Territory jurisdictions. The requirements as to reasonable force contained in these Acts apply to Acts all over Australia, and there are some peculiar requirements indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall one very well that occurred in Queensland under the Bjelke-Petersen Government relating to cattle inspectors and inspections for artificial insemination. Substantial amounts of money are involved in the property-in other words, in the bull's semen-which is extremely expensive. I recall the provisions of that Act because the wording is quite strange. The words are to the effect that at any time of the day or night in Queensland-the provision still exists-an inspector can knock on the door at two o'clock in the morning and demand production of the animal's semen at the inspector's request. That is what the Act says. I can assure Senator MacGibbon that these are standard provisions. Certainly the provisions of 32ae are very familiar, under which an inspector can `enter the premises, search the premises for the thing, and, if the thing is found, seize it'. I am sure that it would be very disconcerting if a thing were seized at two o'clock in the morning under this Act or any other. These are standard provisions and, if inspectors under all these myriad Acts exercise these powers unreasonably, those matters are dealt with very firmly indeed by the courts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept what the Minister says about this being one among a number of Acts around the country. Out of sensibility for the presence of Senator Bjelke-Petersen, I did not say when I was speaking that I recognised that State parliaments are far greater offenders, not only in any one State but right around the country, in terms of intrusive legislation. The difficulty for us is that we find we are in a position where we are getting more and more intrusive legislation. I do not doubt that there are hundreds of Acts on the statute book, but we are in a position that every time a piece of legislation comes before the Senate the Minister presenting it says, `There is a precedent here, the Senate agreed to it without comment in this or that Bill, so why cannot you pass the clause in this Bill?'. Cumulatively the rights of the individual and society are being restricted and denied. If the Parliament does not take a stand on this, there is no-one else in the community who can. I make no apology for speaking out about the use of intrusive legislation. I view this provision as highly intrusive.

SPEECH.PARA: To move on to the clauses themselves, I presume in the light of the Minister's explanation on 32ad and 32af that the same applies to 32ae and 32ac, but that they are different in extent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct. In terms of the rights of individuals about which Senator MacGibbon is concerned, I understand his concern. I know, as does every senator, Senator MacGibbon's extensive personal involvement in the aviation industry. I am also unblushing about defending these provisions. They are there to protect the rights of the individuals who fly in aircraft and who share airspace with other individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon is aware that the majority of the industry is honest and competent. The difficulty is that there are sections of the industry that are dishonest and incompetent. Again, in the Northern Territory one very well known case involved a major commuter operator carrying thousands of innocent people, such as myself, in light aircraft every week. That operator was caught out not so long ago in the Northern Territory in having a stack of pre-signed engineering clearances for its aircraft. It was outrageous. It was only through the diligence of the CAA that it was found out. There was a drawerful of pre-signed engineering checks which meant that the aircraft could continue to fly with no maintenance and no checks at all, simply by filling in the blank spaces that a company engineer had been happy enough to put his name to in advance to keep the aircraft in the air.

One has to strike a balance between the rights of the individuals who operate in those circumstances and the rights of the poor innocents who pay for the seats in the aircraft. I notice Senator Bjelke-Petersen nodding in assent. No doubt she has been in light aircraft as often as I have. It is a fact that the majority of operators are honest, but the legislation is useless if it has no powers to require operators in the industry which often carry fare paying passengers to comply with regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take up the time of the Committee but, in the case of those persons with a drawerful of release notes and maintenance releases, I would have locked them up and never let them out.
—You couldn't if you couldn't go in in the first place.

—It will take up a lot of time if we go down that path. But if the surveyors are on the job, they tend to know because people talk. The aviation community is very small and one usually knows what is going on without having to kick in somebody's door to find out.
—I am sure that is how they found out in the first place. Someone told them.

—That is probably why warrants would be issued in the first place. I think that there is an enormous difference between people who fly for hire and reward and people who fly privately. The private operators are the largest number in the aviation spectrum. But anyone who does fly for hire and reward and who holds themselves out to offer a service to the public must be subjected to the most stringent regulation. There is no argument from me about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to clause 32ah. Why was it necessary for the evidence to be held for 60 days or the qualification to be put on it? It seems that a reasonable case can be made that financial penalties and considerable financial losses could accrue to a commercial operator in this circumstance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The actual 60-day period is a standard provision that would apply. These provisions are not just included by rote because they are standard provisions. They become standard provisions because, by experience, both the courts and the organisations that are required to implement this legislation find that this period is the optimum period necessary both for the purposes of collecting the evidence and conducting successful prosecutions, and balancing the rights of the individuals that own that evidence as to how long it can be kept. The 60 days is a standard provision found in other Acts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed new section 32ah (2) (a) (ii) states:

SPEECH.PARA: a thing that will afford evidence of the commission of another offence against this Act or the regulations...

That is a very wide-ranging power granted to the investigator. It virtually enables him to do a fishing expedition to see whether any offence has been committed in the past or might even be committed in the future. Given the fact that the warrant is issued on the basis of a specific purpose, namely that an offence has been committed or is suspected to have been committed, would the Minister justify the inclusion of those very wide powers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, these are standard provisions and, frankly, sensible provisions that apply in other Acts. If a Civil Aviation Authority operator entered the premises of an aircraft operator that was carrying out a suspect operation-and usually that involves cutting corners on maintenance or flying pilots far beyond their proper hours of safe flying, and so on-and found in the course of that investigation evidence indicating that some other serious offence had been committed and was prevented by the legislation or by any specific provision to take that evidence, naturally the operator would have to cop the penalty for the offence for which the operator entered in the first place but would take the first opportunity to dump whatever else was lying around the place that indicated perhaps other and even more serious offences existed.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extremely sensitive industry in terms of safety and these requirements have to be introduced. If there is a problem with a bus or a car that does not involve running head first into another bus or car-that is, a mechanical problem because of failure of maintenance-the usual penalty is that the driver gets stuck between here and a service station and has to get out and walk. It is a bit hard to do that at 10,000 feet. With respect to the private pilots about whom Senator MacGibbon is talking, the difficulty with applying one set of measures to regular public transport commuter services and another set to private pilots is that private pilots share the same airspace as everyone else. If their aircraft are poorly maintained, they fall down on top of someone else with the same catastrophic results as a commercial operator. In other words, the same stringent requirements on maintenance and competence should apply to both private pilots and commercial operators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to argue that case by moving into the motor field where we kill probably 3,000 a year or something-the magnitude beyond what we ever kill in the air. Referring now to proposed new section 32aj, subsection (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . under a warrant under this Part may require anyone on or in the premises to . . .

It seems quite extraordinary to me that an innocent bystander could literally be on the premises and be required by an investigator to produce evidence which may be used against him. I do not see why there should not be a restriction stating, `may require any relevant person'-the owner, the operator, an employee, or someone who is germane to the investigation-and that it not be as wide as presently provided.

The other difficulty I have with proposed new section 32aj relates to the fact that people are required to answer questions under pain of a penalty of $3,000. Again, there is no definition of what they are to say. It just says they are required to answer questions. Could they be untruthful, for example? Could they just say, `It is a nice day.'? If they were asked, `Were you here on Tuesday?', could they say, `No, I am here on Wednesday.'? I find it extraordinary that it is so tight in one dimension and so loose in another.

Then we get to the fact that the evidence cannot be used in criminal proceedings. I can see that there might be a way of getting evidence that leads to further investigations but, by and large, it seems to inhibit the value of asking the questions by providing in the Bill that the evidence cannot be used. When I say that, I am also bound to say that it is part of our legal system that people cannot be forced to incriminate themselves by inquiry without the protection of a lawyer and all that sort of thing.

Finally, to tie up this area, what is a criminal offence? Is a criminal offence a breach of a civil aviation order or a civil aviation regulation, or will people be able to be grilled on their compliance with CAOs and CARs and then go to court, where they are interrogated without the right of legal defence, or will that be classified as a criminal activity?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly taken aback by the suggestion that they could go to court without any right of legal defence. People in this country are always--
—I am sorry, I did not mean that.

—They are always entitled to legal defence in our courts. Referring to proposed new section 32aj (2), again, these are standard and sensible requirements. It is not reasonable for an inspector going into premises investigating a breach of an Act and, on finding people there, to have to grill people as he necessarily would have to do to identify who they were before he asked questions. There is a qualifier, and a good one, in proposed new subsection (2):

SPEECH.PARA: A person must not, without reasonable excuse, fail to comply with a requirement . . .

If I were standing in the hangar of Arnhem Air Charter in Darwin, waiting to board a chartered aircraft-and I often do stand in the hangar and talk to the mechanics-and an inspector came through the doorway, he would not necessarily know who was who, so he must ask people questions. If that inspector said to me, `Can I ask you to produce your maintenance records?' and I said, `Sorry, but I am simply a passenger, just waiting to get on a plane', the obvious result would be that the inspector would say, `Fine, I am looking for the engineer'. Clearly, under those circumstances, that is a reasonable excuse not to answer questions about maintenance. What I am saying with respect to this and every other issue raised by Senator MacGibbon is that these are reasonable and sensible provisions found in all legislation of a similar nature. The courts are quite comfortable with the provisions that apply in legislation such as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, in relation to clause 15, which amends section 98 of the principal Act, subparagraph (kb) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: the approval by the Authority of such manuals, systems and documents and of alterations of them;

My understanding from the numerous papers that I have received was that the Authority no longer required manuals such as operations manuals to be approved. Is this provision at variance with my understanding?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —These manuals are in fact vitally important, and they do have the force of law and must be kept in accordance with the regulations requiring their upkeep. For obvious reasons, systems and maintenance manuals are official records that indicate whether or not the operator is complying with the standards required for the safe operation of an aircraft. If an operator cannot be required to comply with the correct keeping of these manuals, the entire system of checking as to whether or not an operator is doing so falls down.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the absolute work face, if you like, of the implementation of the proper policing of this Act. Operators are required by force of law to keep these manuals in accordance with the way in which the CAA requires people to keep them, and they will be prosecuted if they do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that, but a circular came around some time ago which made the point that while people were required to have a maintenance manual or procedure for a workshop, that procedure did not have to be approved by the Authority. My understanding of this clause is that there is provision for the Authority to approve the maintenance system, which is quite a different topic.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I did misunderstand Senator MacGibbon. That is correct. The Act does require the CAA to specify what manuals are affected by this law. There is no question at all-Senator MacGibbon is correct-that the CAA is moving to make far more flexible this system. This Bill is not in any conflict with that move by the CAA.
—I have just a couple of brief questions. The commencement date for this Bill is the date of royal assent. Is it to have a start-up date of 1 July?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The royal assent provisions are standard provisions, but it is the intention of the Government to fit this in with the promulgation of the regulations. The start-up date is proposed to be 1 July.
—The Senate will not be sitting between now and then. What can the Minister tell me about these minimum security standard regulations that I referred to in my speech at the second reading stage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —They are in the process of being prepared at the moment. As I said to Senator Kernot, they will be promulgated by regulation. So they will be back in the Senate and they will be subject to the normal provisions for disallowance.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
