SPEECH.PARA: I would appreciate some time to seek this advice. That would then put the question beyond doubt. In the circumstances, I feel compelled to say that I do not see any alternative. However, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy might have another view and I think it reasonable to allow an opportunity for that view to be expressed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Had the committee debates actually finished? Perhaps I will defer to the Whip, who wishes to speak.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I apologise to the Senate. The instructions keep changing from moment to moment. I advise the Senate that, if I can seek the cooperation of honourable senators in negativing this motion, I will move for the suspension of the Senate for 10 minutes, at the conclusion of which time we will try to make a definitive report to the Senate. I apologise for the procedural chaos, Mr Acting Deputy President, but you understand the cause. We seek to do that, with the cooperation of the Senate.

—by leave-Mr Acting Deputy President, could I suggest that we take the unusual course of proceeding with two or three speakers on the adjournment debate at this point. At the expiration of that time, we can perhaps adjourn for 10 minutes if necessary.

—The situation is that the Senate has before it the adjournment motion. Honourable senators may speak to that motion and if at the end of that time it is the wish of the Senate to do so it has a perfect right to negate the adjournment motion, following which further business may be transacted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I gave notice of a motion relating to the disastrous situation on the Forgacs floating dock at Newcastle. Among other ship repair work, Forgacs was handling the refit of HMAS Tobruk. Two unions are involved in the work-the Metal and Engineering Workers Union and the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Both unions signed an agreement not to strike while the dockyard was refitting HMAS Tobruk. This undertaking was broken when Forgacs rejected an accord mark VI pay claim by the unions. Later, Forgacs agreed to pay the metal workers a wage rise of $12 a week, but not the painters and dockers. As a result, the strike continued until Forgacs gave in and extended the increases to all workers. The company had three vessels delayed as a result of this strike and the delays were costing up to $15,000 per vessel per day. That is how it began.

SPEECH.PARA: The end of the story is that the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union has been picketing the dockyard for the last week so that no further work could be carried out. The Federal Industrial Relations Commission failed to convince the union members to return to work immediately and, consequently, Commissioner Peterson granted an historic order to exempt Forgacs from clause 15 of the painters and dockers award, the pick-up clause that forces a company to accept labour from a roster operated by the union. The unions disagreed with the company over the interpretation of the ruling and disagreed that the company could draw up a list of those workers on the list who were required to work at the dockyard.

Yesterday, Commissioner Peterson confirmed his ruling, termination notices were sent to those painters and dockers whom the Forgacs company no longer wished to employ, and permanent jobs were offered to about 28 men. Today the union has still not accepted the ruling by Commissioner Peterson. It has not removed the picket and its members have not returned to work.

I now want to tell the Senate of the latest developments. The Federal Council of the Metal and Engineering Workers Union has directed its members to cross the picket line of the painters and dockers and return to work. This morning the picket line turned away civilian trucks loaded with equipment to support the work at the dockyard. Newcastle Trades Hall issued a directive for the picket to let those trucks in. Two Royal Australian Navy trucks with civilian drivers were then turned away. The Navy took one of its forklift trucks, manned by Army personnel, outside the gates of Forgacs and began to forklift goods and equipment over the fence. A Newcastle television station crew arrived and the picket broke up for a short time. However, the picket line is now back in place because the union is still meeting. That is how the situation stands at the moment.

I raise this matter in the Senate because the actions of one union have contributed to a situation where the Royal Australian Navy is considering taking the multimillion dollar refit of HMAS Tobruk away from the Forgacs dockyard. If that happens, there is little chance that the Navy will again trust a ship repair job to the port of Newcastle. Such a development would be tragic for Forgacs and for Newcastle. But it is also a tragedy for Australia that, with so little progress on waterfront reform, restrictive trade practices and unwarranted strike action are allowed to interrupt work on the wharves and put the Australian economy in peril.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A politician should never miss the opportunity to speak; actually, I did not anticipate that I would have the chance to contribute to this debate this afternoon. The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) came to my office this morning because he had an issue that concerned him but had no opportunity to raise it in the House of Representatives. He sought my assistance in raising the matter here. Since I had already planned to ask a question about a firm in Echuca, I was not able to help the honourable member and said that I did not think I would be popular if I spoke in the adjournment debate this afternoon. However, I now seize the moment, although the papers are packed in my suitcase for the `end of school term' and I could not find them. But I will put the matter anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: The lifts in this building were installed and have been serviced by an Australian company. Recently a contract was let for the servicing of the lifts in this place. The Australian company that had the service contract advertised widely internationally, saying that it was important to maintain the lifts in this building in order to ensure that senators and members arrived at divisions on time. Those of us who have not made it here in time-not the fault of the lifts-know how important it is that the lifts are serviced properly and that we do get here on time for divisions.

The company used that as a selling point for its product, to sell its product overseas-an Australian product. A tender was put out for the service contract for the lifts and another firm, an overseas firm, won that contract because it had offered a lower price. I have been led to believe that part of the contract stated that, on the day the contract was let, the successful company was to start servicing the lifts. I now understand that that is not the case and that the Australian company has continued to service the lifts.

I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to direct my concerns to the President and ask whether the contract has been breached. If that contract has been breached, will the tender be re-let? Also, was consideration given to the fact that one of the companies was an Australian company. It has been suggested that the successful company cannot provide parts for the lift motors for some 20 weeks? I think that issue needs to be clarified; it is one of great concern, especially for the honourable member for Isaacs. The company is in his electorate and there are 350 people in that firm whose jobs are at risk. I think it behoves this Parliament to ensure that that contract has been dealt with properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson, I will draw your concerns to the attention of the President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer briefly to a matter that I would like to have raised at Question Time but, unfortunately, was unable to do so because of the volume and quality of questions that then came from this side of the chamber. The matter I want to refer to relates to the responses made during the week by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). I regret to say that I have not advised him of my intention to raise this matter now, for reasons that may well be understood.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister defended the Government's unprecedented financial aid to a South African political party, the African National Congress, and to a range of urban black organisations closely associated with the ANC, on the grounds that an opinion poll that he quoted showed that 70 per cent of urban blacks support the ANC. His inference that seemed to stem from that was that the ANC is therefore representative of the black community and is the proper organisation for the Australian Government to support and finance in seeking to assist South African blacks to a fair and reasonable role in their country's future with the destruction of apartheid.

I do not wish to criticise the public opinion poll. I understand that the people who undertook the poll are reputable and that the poll results are reasonable. The fact is that the people who were polled are not representative of the black population of South Africa. The people polled were limited to the urban black population, which makes up around 40 per cent of the population of South Africa. The great bulk of black people in South Africa live in non-urban areas and indeed in conditions which roughly equate to the sorts of living conditions that exist in the rest of Africa in non-urban areas, and they are very unattractive. Senator Schacht has been to Africa and knows perfectly well what the standard of living of non-urban black people throughout the whole of that continent is. He knows also that it is particularly bad in white South Africa, which is not a matter that the white South Africans can feel pleased about, but it is simply a matter of fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disgrace. Why don't you say it is a disgrace?
—If Senator Schacht will hold his excitement for a moment, he might be in a position to benefit from what I say.
—Order! If you will speak through me, Senator Baume, you will probably not attract as many interjections.
—I thank you for your wise advice.
—In fact, you may even cajole Senator Schacht into speaking on the adjournment, and this House would welcome it.
—I have every feeling that he may take part in this debate, depending on how long it takes various people to pull the wool over various other people's eyes on another matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I was trying to make was that that public opinion poll does not defend or support the unprecedented decision by Senator Evans and by the Government to assist a political party which happens to be popular among urban blacks. Even Senator Schacht's mathematics would be good enough to recognise that 70 per cent of 40 per cent is only 28 per cent. In other words, all that this public opinion poll showed was that some 28 per cent of South Africa's blacks-that is, 70 per cent of the 40 per cent who live in urban areas-would support the ANC in an election.

It may well be that among the non-urban blacks there are a considerable numbers of ANC supporters, but we cannot tell the volume because no poll has been taken. To my knowledge, Senator Evans has no evidence, otherwise he would have presented it to us with the same verve and enthusiasm that he presented this urban blacks poll, as if somehow it was relevant to the total population of South Africa.

The fact is that the great bulk of rural blacks appear to support other leaders like Chief Buthelezi, who certainly has enormous popularity among the six million Zulus. There is also the leader of the two million Tswanas, for example, where I understand that the ANC-and I may be corrected-is not a strong political organisation. What is the evidence that the Minister has that the ANC represents the majority of black opinion in South Africa? Certainly it is the most up-front, certainly it has the greatest international standing and status, and this Government has taken the view that the way for the Hawke Government to achieve standing and status among Commonwealth countries and other countries that support the ANC is for itself to support the ANC. In other words, the Hawke Government appears to have another agenda-its own popularity and its own attempts to achieve various other objectives in other international forums rather than the merits of the case.

I believe that, after Senator Evans's curious performance this week, the Senate has the right to know what elements of the Australian aid program to black South Africans is designated to ANC-dominated urban areas as against rural areas. Why is comparable aid not provided to the great majority of blacks who live in non-urban areas-in fact, where 60 per cent of South African blacks live-in conditions that the people who live in these non-urban areas consider so unsatisfactory that hundreds of thousands of them choose to move into urban slums each year? Is it not incredible that apparently the only assistance we are giving is to the urban areas which, judging by people voting with their feet, are less worse than the rural areas? Yet we do not give assistance in any sorts of volumes to non-urban areas.

What is Senator Evans up to with these large amounts of money which have not gone through the normal process, despite his curious wandering around about it today? And why are these people, who simply happen not to be ANC supporters, not getting our funding? Until Senator Evans answers that question properly, we in the Opposition have every justification to be very suspicious of Senator Evans's motives.

If need is therefore not the main criteria for such aid-and if need were the criteria, the aid would be going to the rural areas-what is the criteria, other than the political expediency that appears to limit such aid to ANC-dominated urban areas? The Government should come clean on this matter. I get the impression that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) may be ready to proceed with the next matter. I simply urge the Foreign Minister to answer these questions that have remained unresolved as a result of his pathetic performance in the Parliament this week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity to talk about a trip hosted by the United Kingdom branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) on which I recently had the honour to represent this Parliament. Each year one or two members of the Federal Parliament join with a number of delegates from a significant number of countries, counties, States and provinces within the Commonwealth of Nations. On this occasion there were 24 delegates from 19 countries. I was the only female, and I found that a little disappointing.

SPEECH.PARA: I also found the level of involvement of women in politics in other countries, including Britain, to be very much the same as here. Everywhere we are still fighting to increase the numbers and participation of women within the parliamentary process.

Caribbean delegates came from the Cayman Islands, Turks and Caicos Islands, Barbados, Bermuda, and Saint Lucia. Delegates from the African countries, including Botswana, Zimbabwe, Tanzania, Zambia and Sierra Leone, would have been very interested to have heard Senator Baume's contribution today, because one issue that was of great concern to them was the fact that their fellow brothers in South Africa are still being persecuted and are still having problems. We learnt a great number of things from them.

Part of the conference involved a session at which we were able to discuss issues of great concern to everyone. They were issues with which people can identify. One such issue was the one-party state. It was very interesting to learn that Tanzania actually is a one-party state which allows for a participatory role in the preselection of candidates at the grassroots level. It was interesting also to learn that Zambia and another state are moving away from a one-party system back to a true democracy, and I welcome that.

Apart from their general economy, delegates from the Caribbean were concerned about the drug issue. Drug barons are able to come into low socioeconomic areas and offer farmers what seem to be huge amounts of money to grow and produce drugs instead of subsistence crops. It was a little difficult for those of us from developed countries to understand why these peasant farmers would in fact choose to go down this path of growing a crop that will only cause a great deal of heartache, sorrow, suffering and trauma in other countries. I guess we were not able to understand fully just how difficult it is to farm in those countries.

We met a number of people from the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association secretariat and we also had a session at the Commonwealth secretariat. We were addressed by Chief Anyaoku. What he said proved to be very enlightening and certainly indicated to me what a very intelligent and innovative Secretary-General of the secretariat he is.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a lovely man.

—Yes, a lovely man, as Senator Giles says. It was interesting that only three of the delegates were members of upper Houses. One of those was a colleague from New South Wales; the other was from Barbados. From speaking to many of the parliamentarians, including the British, it would appear that it is very rare for members of upper Houses to be democratically elected like we are in the Federal Parliament and in New South Wales. We were asked many questions about how we managed to go about the election process and what were our roles and rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The English wanted to know the difference between the powers that we had and the powers held by members of the House of Lords. As one of the three members of the upper Houses, I was very privileged to be taken by Baroness Strange on a tour through some of the more private areas of the House of Lords. She then took us to tea in the guests dining room in the House of Lords. I shall always remember the beauty and ornateness of the rooms, including the Prince's chamber, the royal chambers and the robing room for the Queen. The workmanship and antiquity associated with the whole of the Westminster Palace is quite mind-boggling.

We were privileged to be able to spend some time in her company and to learn more about how things worked and the problems experienced by members of the House of Lords, particularly by those members who come down for the sittings and always participate, not those who are there just because of their title. Whilst we were of differing political opinions, we certainly found that we had a lot in common, and I place on record my gratitude for her hospitality.

Also in terms of hospitality and gratitude, I must thank the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association in Great Britain, led by the Secretary, Peter Cobb, and the Acting Chair at the time, Sir Anthony Durant, who is a long time friend of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and of Australia. We all look forward to being able to meet one another again.

It is interesting to note that this trip took place during the New South Wales election period. As a person from New South Wales who was not able to return to New South Wales by 6 p.m. on the polling day, I found it necessary to vote in London. This turned out to be rather an interesting experience. People may not know that the New South Wales Greiner Government is in the process of selling off New South Wales House on The Strand, which is shopfront area. The New South Wales Agent-General is moving to King William Street and therefore his offices will not be easily accessible to the public. Where will people vote when there is a future general election in New South Wales?

It was assumed that people would vote at Australia House. Of course, this was not correct. What was even worse, I do not think the New South Wales Agent General's office, the Electoral Commission or whoever was conducting the ballot in London, even had the decency to contact Australia House and discuss the possibility of using that venue. Even after several days of discussion-and this was four days after the writs had been issued-I was not able to be told when and where people could vote. It was about five days before they were told precisely where the ballot would be conducted. I thought that was a rather sloppy exercise.

I wonder how many people in fact became totally confused and gave up in frustration at not being able to find out where and when they could vote. I have been very critical of the New South Wales Government and the Electoral Commission in this respect. I have raised the issue with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). It is important that he be aware that there may well be assumptions made by the New South Wales Government that in future Australia House may have to be the venue for the balloting. This is something that the New South Wales Government should have thought of before it actually had the temerity to move from this excellent shopfront area, where people were able to see and observe and be enticed, excited and stimulated to go and find out more about New South Wales and Australia.

Instead, now all we have on The Strand-a superb location, as I am sure most honourable senators know, between South Australia House and Western Australia House-are tired, dirty, tacky, old, New South Wales Tourist Commission posters on windows. They are faded, fly-spotted and in a fairly disgraceful state of repair.

It was not a good image for Australia and it was certainly a shocking image for New South Wales. It annoyed and frustrated me. If it had that effect on me, I wonder what it did to other New South Wales voters who were discouraged-not helped-from exercising their democratic process.

All in all, the trip was a very exciting and rewarding experience. It is something that I would recommend to anyone to attempt. It has highlighted just how important contact with overseas parliamentarians is to learn about other forms of democracy and governing. I say to those honourable senators who are in the chamber that it was a very great privilege and honour for me to have represented the Australian Parliament in the United Kingdom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had a whingeing performance from Senator Baume this afternoon about the interpretation of the methodology of a poll taken in South Africa. His remarks about South Africa cannot go without challenge.
—I did not complain about the methodology of the poll.

—The honourable senator did. Senator Baume complained about the size of the sample vis-a-vis how many urban people had been sampled, how many country people had not been sampled, and so on. I find it extraordinary that in my time in the Senate I have never heard Senator Baume get up and complain about the electoral system in South Africa that disenfranchises some 20 million black people. I would have listened with more interest to his remarks if he had been willing to concede that the real obscenity in South Africa was not that in a particular survey not enough non-urban blacks had been surveyed but that no black has ever had a vote in South Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume's approach reflects the views of those on his side of politics. For a week they have been harping about the visit of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to South Africa. How those opposite have acted has shown that they have more sympathy for the security forces of South Africa than for the position of the Australian Government in opposing apartheid.

I listened with considerable interest all week to Senator Baume's whingeing and whining about whether the Minister swore at a South African security policeman. Compared with what the South African security police have been doing to the majority of the black population of South Africa for the last 40 years, a bit of swearing in retribution is a very mild rebuke. There is no doubt that in the last 40 years the South African police, the security forces, have not been noted as being the great defenders of human rights or for having any sensitivity about how they--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you just discovered that?

—The point is that Senator Baume has not discovered it because in all his remarks here, particularly over the last week, he has been more concerned that someone swore at a South African security policeman in a private conversation. I did not see him jumping up and down in this place moving motions when the South African security forces shot children dead in the streets in various black townships over the last decade. I never saw him moving notices of motion--
—Have you objected to necklacing?
—Order! Senator Schacht, it would help if you directed your remarks through the Chair.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy President. I will certainly direct them through you. But I must say that, even through you, it is a bit difficult to get them to sink into the skull of Senator Baume who has a particularly large blind spot with respect to adjusting his views to what is occurring in South Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume asks whether I have ever opposed necklacing. I certainly have. It is an abominable activity. I oppose violence in South Africa by whoever commits it. I have always opposed necklacing and the violence between various black groups and between blacks and whites, and so on. We on this side of the Senate would give more weight to Senator Baume's remarks if just occasionally he did not allow his obsession against the African National Congress (ANC) to colour all his remarks and views about South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about yours about Inkatha?

—I have made no remarks about Inkatha in this place. When I was in South Africa, I met a representative of Inkatha and had quite a lengthy discussion with that person. I make no bones about the fact that of all the black organisations in South Africa, I believe the ANC clearly overwhelmingly represents the black people. Inkatha does have support. I am not going to argue whether it is 3 per cent, 6 per cent, 15 per cent or whatever.

SPEECH.PARA: By any objective measurement there is no doubt that the ANC overwhelmingly represents the political aspirations of the black population because it is a very broad based organisation. That was clear from my brief visit to South Africa. It would be clear to any person who has visited South Africa and spent any time there making an assessment.

It is also quite clear that the white Government of South Africa concedes that the ANC represents most of the black people because it is the body it negotiates with; it is the body it is trying to reach agreement with on constitutional change. If the ANC did not represent the overwhelming views of the black population, it would not be invited by the white Government into negotiations. Senator Baume has allowed his emotion to run away with him in his vitriolic attacks on the ANC.

I now turn to the issue of the granting of funds. Senator Baume has tied himself in knots because the Australian Government has made a grant of some $60,000 to the ANC to enable it to have a unit which provides decent technical advice on economic matters. Some time ago, the conservatives in this country used to jump up and down about the fact that the ANC was committed to rabid socialism, communist views and nationalising everything in sight. That was one of the attacks the conservatives used against the ANC. The Australian Government has provided a very modest amount of money to a body that is more than a political party-it represents a whole range of views of the broadest cross-section of black people in South Africa-so that it can understand and get technical advice about how to run a mixed economy and the Opposition jumps up and down as though this is a terrible development.

I find it extraordinary that the conservatives, who several years ago accused the ANC of being a communist front are now accusing us of enabling the ANC to receive technical advice to run a decent mixed economy, and showing political partisanship. I would have thought that even those opposite supported a mixed economy. The National Party of Australia believed, as far as the rural sector is concerned, in utter socialist policies about a subsidy for everybody. By and large, members of the Opposition believe in a mixed economy. I do not see why they would object so much to that sort of advice being made available to the ANC.

I hope that, when the Senate comes back in the second half of this year, further progress will have been made towards the ending of apartheid in South Africa and the development of a democratic non-racial constitution, and that some of the petty-mindedness of some members of the Opposition will have disappeared and they will have recognised that people of goodwill in both the ANC and the present national Government of South Africa, including President de Klerk, have achieved the end of the most abysmal and obscene system of government in the modern period.

This Australian Government has helped to achieve this by providing assistance to the ANC. I do not find anyone from the South African Government criticising this. People are not jumping up and down about this modest piece of assistance provided to the ANC because they know that they are going to have to work with the ANC. They know that the ANC, in one form or another, will be part of the government of South Africa in the near future. When I visited South Africa, there were plenty of people in the white community who were more than willing to say that the best thing one could do for the ANC was to assist it to come to terms with a mixed economy.

Perhaps Senator Baume has joined the list of anarchists who believe that the best result for South Africa is to have an ANC not with the technical capability of running a mixed economy but with the ability to fall into the spiral of a system where the ANC is not able to participate in government in a mature way. I believe that the Government's policy of providing this modest piece of assistance is the correct one and I hope that in the second half of this year when the Senate comes back those opposite will recognise the error of their ways.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask: what on earth is going on in the Department of Administrative Services (DAS)? Answers to questions that I have asked not only in this chamber but also in an Estimates committee reveal a Minister and a department whose purchasing reforms are too hard to handle. We all followed, particularly those on this side of the chamber, the famous Nashua case with amazement. The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) intervened in the process when he found out that that company would be happy to offer a lower price than it had put in its tender and, effectively, he told the Department to accept the new bid. When the Department resisted, the Minister directed it to do what he wanted. There were some post-offer negotiations and a compromise was found. Three relatively junior officers were sent to re-examine the process which their senior officer had said was satisfactory. Their findings came as no surprise to anyone in this place. They found that there had been some deficiencies in the process, after all. The Department took in the Minister's washing and returned it to him nicely ironed and folded.

SPEECH.PARA: This incident has not escaped the notice of the business community. I have received a letter from a supplier of office chairs who wants to know why the principles adopted by the Minister in the Nashua case were not applied to his company. This was utterly inevitable. It is a good question and I hope that the Minister can find a convincing answer. The circumstances in this case are set out in a letter that I received recently from Sturdy Components Pty Ltd, a small Australian-owned company in Sydney which has a subsidiary in my State of Queensland. In fact, it is just the kind of company this country needs to encourage if Australia is to get out of its current economic problems. I ask leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard the letter from Sturdy Components Pty Ltd.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
STURDY COMPONENTS PTY. LIMITED
Furniture Manufacturers
Specialists in Office Chairs
(Incorporated in New South Wales)
Office &Factory: 95 Gow Street
PADSTOW, N.S.W. 2211
Postal Address: P.O. Box 310
PADSTOW, N.S.W. 2211
Telephone: 790 3500
Senator Warwick Parer
Shadow Minister to Department of
Administrative Services
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600 .
Dear Senator Parer,

Sturdy Components, and our Queensland subsidiary, Tube Art, make office chairs. We bid last year for inclusion on the Commonwealth Common User Contract for office chairs. Even though our prices were among the lowest, even though Worksafe Australia passed our samples, even though our chairs have more Australian content than most, we were passed over on a technicality.

In spite of the Government's support for what they call ``post offer negotiation'', when a technical omission in our samples was noticed, no-one said a word to us. When we found out-too late what the problem was, we fixed it up in a day's work and at a cost of 20c a chair.

What was this technicality which the Department used to rule out our products? It concerns the housing for the gas spring. The specification said the housing should be solid metal. Our samples were made from extruded metal.
I do not deny that our sample should have conformed to what the customer wanted. What I do complain of is that no-one saw fit to give us the opportunity to correct the error.

But there is another question. Why was the specification written the way it was? Our sample met with all British and US Standards in this respect. But the standard used is a German draft-not even in force in Germany! We want to know why this Standard was chosen. It was not for safety reasons, because, as I have said, Worksafe found that our chairs met their requirements.

Why was a draft German Standard used? Who persuaded the Department to adopt that standard? Which of our competitors benefited from that decision? And why was there no ``post offer negotiation'' on this point? These are all questions which Senator Bolkus has not answered. He said recently that he saw no justification for our claim to have been unfairly dealt with. Yet, in the Nashua case, the Minister was prepared to intervene personally, because he was concerned ``that an established and satisfactory supplier to the government can be put off the contract without the Department wanting to satisfy itself that it has not unfairly treated the company.'' He went on:
``Indeed, we should be making every effort to satisfy ourselves that Australian suppliers have put forward their best offers.''

Far from making ``every effort'' in our case, the Department kept completely quiet about the technical omission they had picked up in our samples. Why? A phone call to us, and a chance to submit new samples, would have improved the range of choice for the Commonwealth customers.
But nothing was done. And, when we have complained to the Minister, nothing has changed.

In the last year, however, we have continued to sell chairs to Commonwealth Departments off-contract. This year, we have made over S2m. worth of sales. The reason is simple: value for money. Our Departmental customers prefer our chairs to those ``evaluated''-for a 4 per cent fee by DAS. Our quality is good, we deliver on time and our prices are well below many of those offered from the approved panel of suppliers.

In the Senate recently, you asked a DAS officer whether Departments are obliged to buy on contract. The officer told you that it would be ``somewhat surprising'' for the tender process not to have chosen a ``value for money'' panel of suppliers. However, he added that ``were it able to be demonstrated, then I am sure an exemption could be found to permit that to happen.'' Surely, our $2m. sales are demonstration enough but if the Minister cares to investigate he will find plenty more evidence in his Department's files.

Our Commonwealth customers are voting with their feet. They are buying chairs from us. They must be doing this because they believe our product truly represents value for money. Naturally, we corrected the minor deficiency that led to the earlier arbitrary and secretive rejection during the ``evaluation'' stage.

We ask to be put on the contract; but we don't ask that anyone else be taken off. All we want is a fair chance for our product to compete in the market. ln the light of the DAS official's remarks in the Senate, we ask, at the very least, that the Department make it absolutely clear to Departments that, if they can get value for money with our chairs, they are not required to pass us by.

Above all, we ask that the Senate use its powers to investigate the whole circumstances surrounding the drawing up of specifications, the tender evaluation process and the decisions to award the contract to others whose prices were well above ours, but whose products are not preferred to ours by the actual users.
Your sincerely,
Don Denny
MANAGING DIRECTOR.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me describe very briefly what this letter alleges. The company makes office chairs. It tendered for the three-year common user contract when it was announced a year ago. The samples it submitted, although passed by Worksafe Australia, were rejected for an obscure technicality by DAS officers. Unlike the Nashua case, however, no-one intervened to give the company a chance to correct a slight omission. There was no Minister waiting to intervene. It was a small omission-certainly nothing as serious as a price revision-and, as the company says, a telephone call and a day's work could have fixed up the problem. There were no post-offer negotiations in this case; in fact, the cost of rectifying the anomaly would have cost the company 20c.

SPEECH.PARA: This letter raises serious questions about what is going on with the tendering process these days. Why were the specifications written in the curious way this letter alleges? Who stood to benefit, and did they benefit? What the Department did was use an obscure German standard that is not used even by the Germans.

We certainly do not approve of what the Minister did in the Nashua case, as has been made very clear in this place. But this case was somewhat different. The omission was slight and could have been easily corrected. Why was the opportunity to do so never taken? The Department itself says that post-offer negotiations are a legitimate technique for obtaining value for money. Why did no-one contact this company? This letter raises a wider issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is in the hot seat.

—I have to acknowledge Senator Baume's interjection. I have received complaints from all sorts of people that the Minister and his Department are forcing departments to buy on-contract where a common user contract has been awarded; yet, the special three-person committee of review, in its report on the Nashua case, made it quite clear that there is absolutely no legal compulsion on departments to do so. In the same spirit, evidence before the Estimates committee made it clear that if departments can get value for money off-contract there is nothing to stop them from doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask again: what on earth is going on in the Department of Administrative Services? Surely, it is time for the Parliament to have a long, close look at these cases-and there are certainly more. The Nashua case and the letter that I have just incorporated raise questions that must be answered. Perhaps the appropriate forum is the Joint Committee of Public Accounts or a committee of the Senate. In any case, I inform the Minister that we will continue to ask questions about these anomalies within his Department.

Following receipt of the letter which I have tabled, I subsequently received a further letter. I was somewhat surprised at the readiness with which this company was prepared to come out into the open because, in most cases when companies report to me on problems they are having with a Minister or a department, they tend to take the view `Let's not make waves on this because it may affect future tenders'. I am advised by this company that it could not care less; it has had enough and it wants the matter brought out into the open.
On 13 June, I received another letter from the Managing Director of Sturdy Components in which he said:

You will remember that we were denied access to the common user contract for office chairs on a technicality, even though our product was offered at a more competitive price and is in fact the preferred brand for many Commonwealth departments and agencies.
I do hope that you will be able to agree that the whole issue of DAS tendering deserves to be examined very closely by the Parliament.

We feel this all the more now, because we have just had word that our associated company in Brisbane- Tube Art-has been successful in its tender to supply office chairs to the Queensland Government. These chairs will be made to the same high standards we observe in all our products and will of course, meet the specifications the Commonwealth has set for this kind of chair. We will naturally include the minor technical adjustment-
the one to which I referred earlier which cost 20c-
on which DAS ruled us out without consultation.

I am sure it will be good news to you as a Senator from Queensland to hear of our latest success. More important from our viewpoint, however, is the fact that this success only serves to lay more emphasis on our discontent with the treatment we have had at Commonwealth level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to add to the very thoughtful and kind words of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in response to a question from me earlier this week in relation to the appointment of Sir Ninian Stephen as the chairperson of the Northern Ireland peace talks. Sir Ninian has taken on a very arduous task-I think this issue will unite all parties in this chamber-in presiding over a successful resolution to the conflict that has been taking place in that part of the world for many hundreds of years.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Ninian has had a very distinguished career in Australia up until the present time-indeed, a career that continues. Bringing four political parties together is not going to be an easy task.
(Quorum formed)
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Cook)-by leave-agreed to:
That message No. 337 from the House of Representatives be recommitted forthwith to the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate does not further press its request for an amendment to each of the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1991, to which the House of Representatives has again not made, and agrees to the amendment made to each bill by the House of Representatives in place thereof.

There have been some discussions and I can say that, subject to the passage of the package of wool Bills through both chambers, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) will take steps to have 12 per cent set by regulation to apply from 1 July 1991. On the basis of that undertaking, I commend the message to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again we are playing semantics with arithmetic. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is insulting not only the chamber but also the constituency in the broader community. Let me quickly read a letter that I have just received that, I think, is most important to this issue. It is from the President of the New South Wales Farmers Association, Mr Peter Taylor, and is addressed to Mr Tim Fischer, the Leader of the National Party of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate you on the stand you have taken over wool tax. The political events that occurred around the wool industry in recent months had caused our farmers to believe that under any government their future livelihood was bleak. You have given them hope that there can be a worthwhile future for those who survive the trying time ahead.
Irrespective of the level of wool tax determined by the Government, your action will dispel the despondency out there in the bush far more than you can imagine.

It is hard for a woolgrower to keep going when he feels nobody is on his side. I believe you have largely restored our faith that there can be some parties, and individual politicians, who do have the resolve to offer better alternative government in the future.
On behalf of the farmers in New South Wales I thank you for your effort and determination.

The letter is signed by Peter Taylor. I think that letter is indicative of what we on this side, and I hope the Australian Democrats, are standing for in this important debate. We have gone through all the economics; we have gone through all the other issues. They are quite clear. The Government obviously has something to hide in the actions it has taken today in that it is not prepared to accept the will of the chamber when it was so clear on 10 per cent.
Senator Walsh interjecting-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to speak from a blank page, for the information of Senator Walsh. The only figure that has ever been put on that blank page by the Australian Democrats, in moving the Government to some form of compromise to see that it takes into account the very things the wool industry was trying to give it and the very things the wool industry was trying to convince the Government needed to be taken into account, is the figure of 12 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently in this chamber I accused the Government of not having accepted the responsibility to bring to the industry a package which could work, a package which could be grasped with sufficient enthusiasm by the industry to take it into the next century. I know that the Opposition will not like to hear this, but it is hearing an indication of how to represent a position and stick to it until that position is agreed to. The tactics which were necessary to bring this position about are tactics which could be well taken up by people who purport to represent the rural industry of Australia.

I mentioned the word `pain' the other night. There has been pain felt by those who thought that the Government could not move. There has also been quite an amount of misunderstanding of the figures that were necessary. I have argued in this place many times over the past couple of days that it is not just a matter of figures, and I am pleased to say that the package of Bills which is to be used to administer the wool industry has the endorsement and the understanding of those involved in the wool industry. It is as much because that package will not be compromised that we see a reason for supporting the Government in this move today.

The package is crucial to the level of confidence that I was seeking. It is something on which I was ready to challenge the Government. When we recently heard that there was a threat to regulate all levels of tax-25 per cent was the threat which offended me first-I was ready to challenge the Government merely to regulate the figure that it thought best. But, of course, I had forgotten that the industry, on the other hand, required the package to operate in the best manner for the next decade. So it is with pleasure that I see that the Government is reminding us of the need to have that package in place.

I must comment on the annoying strategy that had to be adopted to get this legislation through to this place. If this is the position which is most suitable, I cannot understand why we had the charade that we saw earlier and why we had to subject so many people to inconvenience in respect of travel arrangements or whatever. It certainly was not inconvenient to me but I know that members of both the coalition and the Government were subjected to inconvenience and I really do wonder about the sincerity with which this debate is being conducted.

I know that there are some, even in our Party, who were unable to understand what the Government was offering at various stages. I had said that I wanted to see the complete answer. I know that Senator Kernot and Senator Spindler in particular were subjected to a great deal of difficulty because they had trusted my judgment when I said that the Government is not offering what we have asked for. Now that I have to say that the Government is offering what we asked for, their question is: why did the Government not offer it before? I am unable to give them an answer to that.

Mr Chairman, we have the offer, we have the package, we have the explanation, and we have the commitment from the Minister to the very large question I asked, which was: has the Government given a commitment to the industry to make this number work; it is not just a matter of saying, `Oh, well, any number will do.'? We do have a firm number. We have the number of the Democrats, the Vines committee, the Wool Council of Australia and the first ACIL Australia Pty Ltd report-the number which first appeared and was endorsed by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin.

Minister Kerin endorsed the 12 per cent when it was first proposed by the Vines committee. The changes which have occurred in the industry since that period in April are changes which I believe no longer make necessary the second part of the Vines committee report. Those changes are probably worth $500m to the industry. I am unable to calculate that but the Vines committee was able to say that the only way that 12 per cent would work would be if $250m of capital injection were provided.

I believe that the very favourable changes that have occurred, which were listed by Opposition speakers such as Senator Crane and Senator Panizza, have enabled us to reach the situation now where 12 per cent can be sustained without the necessity for $250m to be injected each year for two years. So we have reached that position and we are able now to support the Government in its move towards the Democrats' original position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to stand here and criticise the Australian Democrats' decision. I will let the woolgrowers judge them for what they have done. They held out for far longer than I had ever expected. However, I want to mention the members of the Wool Council of Australia. They are the ones who, today and for a mighty long time, have let the woolgrowers of Australia down. They are not democratically elected and I hope that in time the industry will get around to democratically electing its peak body. All along they gave no indication that they support the growers in terms of 10 per cent. They went for 12 per cent and even fed the Government figures that made it easy to justify 15 per cent. So much for the Wool Council!

SPEECH.PARA: I will now move on to the Wool Corporation. At 9 o'clock this morning I tried to find out exactly what the total bill was for the 400 or 500 people it employed, what they did, and whether they even saw a bale of wool. I rang back every hour, and each time I was told, `We'll get back to you in a quarter of an hour'. That went on until it was time to come in here. So it is more interested in keeping its 400 or 500 people employed than keeping farmers on their places. The Nationals and the Liberals can look any woolgrower in the face from this day onward. That is more than the Wool Corporation and the Wool Council of Australia can do.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put one or two things on the record so that when people receive the Hansard-as some do in the bush-and try to follow this debate they will realise that 20 minutes ago the Democrats said that they would stick with the Opposition on 10 per cent but now, 20 minutes later, they have changed their position and gone to 12 per cent. I am not going to criticise the Democrats. I am not criticising the Wool Council or the Australian Wool Corporation. That is not up to me. But that point cannot be denied. It is on the record.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: — If we look at the record of this debate we can start in April with the Vines report; with the Wool Council's figure of 12 per cent; and with Senator Bell, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, endorsing a 12 per cent figure and staying with it to this very moment. The Leader of the National Party in this place has misinterpreted and misstated what Senator Bell said just 20 minutes ago. Senator Bell said, `Our figure is 12 per cent. We have not got it; therefore we stay where we are, at 10 per cent'. We did not have 12 per cent. Earlier this week in the vote we put up 12 per cent, but we did not get it from the Government or the Opposition. That was the same 12 per cent recommended in the Vines report and by the Wool Council, and the same 12 per cent that we have sought throughout April and since.
—It is now only for one year.

—Now that my attention has been drawn to the National Party, I remind honourable senators that on 1 May Bruce Lloyd, speaking on behalf of the Opposition as its primary industry spokesperson, made a categorical press release stating, `We cannot amend tax Bills'. The consistent position is here before us today. The figure we sought was 12 per cent. We did not get it, so then we had to choose either a hurdle of 15 per cent, which is too high for the industry or, reluctantly, 10 per cent. The Hansard will show that that is what Senator Bell said. That is where we went. Again today he said, `We have not got 12 per cent; we have 12.5 per cent. That is not our 12 per cent. We will not take it; we will stay where we are'. I just repeat the point Senator Bell made before. The way this has happened has not been satisfactory to us or to anybody else in this place. If the Minister knew he was prepared to go to 12 per cent, he could have gone to it days ago, and should have gone to it at least hours ago. But 12 per cent was our figure if the Government was prepared to give it to us. It has been the industry's figure since April, and that is where we have stayed. That is where we are now. Let us remember that this is a figure which is attached to a package; a package which will now be available to the wool industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to Senator Bell that this position is not what the Australian Democrats had originally sought. They originally sought 12 per cent. What they have is 12 per cent for one year.
—That is a ceiling and it is regulated.
—I am well aware of that. The Government has made this idiotic promise that, by way of regulation, it will bring in the 12 per cent for one year.
—It is still 15 per cent in the Bill.

—We do not know what the Government will bring in next year, Senator Bell. There is no guarantee of what it will bring in for next year. We have no idea, nor has Senator Bell, that the Government will not go to 15 per cent, or even back to 25 per cent next year-it so vindictive against the woolgrowers. We have no idea what the Government proposes. It does not have any figures. We have the figures. We said it could be done at 10 per cent. The Wool Council supported our figure of 10 per cent. The Government said it could not be done under 15 per cent under any circumstances, but then it moved to 13 per cent. It then moved to 12 1/2 per cent and said it could not go one single point below 12 1/2 per cent. But as soon as the Government was pushed far enough, it caved in, and now we have 12 per cent. If the Australian Democrats had stuck to 10 per cent, the Government would have accepted 10 per cent. It knows our figures are correct and it would have accepted 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said to Senator Bell, I think he has done more for the Democrats than any other member has done in the past. He has stuck at this longer than anyone else has. I hope the woolgrowers accept that and understand that he has wonderful potential. But eventually he caved in. I do not really blame him. Senator Bell was in the room with Senator Cook and we know how Senator Cook can bully and intimidate. Then Senator Bell was in the room with Mr Crean, and we all know Mr Crean's tactics. This lot has been taught from birth how to deal with someone who is not going their way. Their bullying, intimidation and vitriol--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you checked his kneecaps?

—I have not checked his kneecaps, but I can assure Senator Cook that if I had been there he would not have got one inch. Unfortunately, Senator Bell was pressured enough by Senator Powell to give way. While it is a tragedy, I am still wondering whether Senator Bell and the Democrats are willing to come across and give us some information on this 12-month commitment. Were they aware of that 12-month commitment? Are they willing to stick by that 12-month commitment, or are they willing to come a bit further our way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to set the record straight on a couple of matters. Firstly, in terms of this legislation, we are not voting for a 12 per cent tax; we are voting for a 15 per cent tax with a promise from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy for 12 per cent by way of regulation in the first year. That is what we are voting for. Everybody should remember that. For Senator Powell to stand up and say--
—We are not voting for it.

—No. That is what is being voted for in this chamber. We are not voting for it. For Senator Powell to stand up and say that the Australian Democrats have not shifted their position is blatantly wrong. I want to say something about the Government's performance on this matter. Over the last week it has been playing darts or poker, or dice, with the wool industry. It started off with 15 per cent, then it made an offer of 14 per cent, then 13 per cent was talked about, and then it became 12 1/2 per cent. That is not how government is run. That is not how industry is run. We on this side of the chamber have consistently asked the Government to put its figures on the table so they can be examined and scrutinised. Where are they? The Government will not put them on the table.

SPEECH.PARA: Our figures are on the table and I would like somebody to show us where they are wrong. It has not been demonstrated to us that they are wrong. I think it is very important to note that particular fact. We have seen the wool industry being played with politically and we have seen the Australian Democrats being conned in terms of what we are voting for in this place today. I just want to emphasise that it is not a 12 per cent tax rate, it is 15 per cent with a promise of 12 per cent at the end of the day.

I also want to make a point with regard to the Vines inquiry. We keep on getting the Vines inquiry thrown up at us. The Vines report was a good document on the day and it gave a lot of information to this industry, but it is out of date today. There are so many things that have changed. The wool industry is a dynamic industry; it is operating in a dynamic market. I want to emphasise, as I did last night, that it is appalling to me that the Government cannot show the same confidence in the wool industry as is being indicated through the futures market. The figures which I tabled last night indicate very clearly how the world is looking at our wool industry today, and the sorts of prices that people are prepared to pay for wool into the next 18 months.

I will close my comments by repeating that not only am I disappointed with the position that the Democrats have adopted, but also it is substantially different from the position they were at the other night. They are not going to pull the wool over our eyes on this side of the chamber, nor are they going to pull the wool over the eyes of the woolgrowers of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the long hours, days, weeks and months of this debate on the wool tax, woolgrowers have indicated that they want a 10 per cent levy only. The representative groups of woolgrowers have indicated that. My colleagues thought that the Australian Democrats would go along with them. They did hold for a while, but I predicted yesterday that they would cave in, like they do, not because I do not think that Senator Bell is genuine-maybe he is-but because I knew that Senator Powell is only in it for the cheap political points. She is very anti-farmer and antirural. The Democrats do it all the time-they go around pretending that they want to support rural industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of my colleagues tried to tell me yesterday that the Democrats would stick, but in the tariff debate yesterday I told them they would not stick. I predicted that they would crawl back to the Government like they always do, and that is exactly what has happened. The sooner my colleagues realise that we can never trust them, the better off we will be. I was very disappointed yesterday when some of my colleagues followed them on a rural Bill. They cannot be trusted in rural matters-they are anti-farmer and anti-rural, and it should be made known to everyone that that is the way they are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to this debate on the Wool Tax (Nos. 1 to 5) Amendment Bills, and I am concerned about the unusual situation that we have got into. A statement was made to the chamber by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) which indicated that there would be an undertaking by the Government that there would be a rate of 12 per cent tax for the next year in lieu of the 15 per cent contained in the legislation, but that 15 per cent will be in the legislation when it is passed by the Parliament. I would like to make the point that the Government still has not convinced the Senate-and I mean the majority of the Senate-that the 15 per cent rate is required in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: A vast range of factors have been alluded to in the debate by Senator Tambling and other Opposition senators, Senator Bell on behalf of the Democrats and Senator Boswell. There has been a range of factors, all of which are very changeable. The Government itself has admitted that the 12 per cent rate, given the current circumstances, is too high. I will give an example. The wool sales yesterday and today in Launceston cleared the floor. That is one of the factors which suggest that there should be an even lower rate than the Vines suggestion. What I am proposing to the Committee is that, if the Government is now saying 12 per cent, then we should have that not only as an assurance from the Minister, but also as part of the motion, and that it should be 12 per cent in lieu of 15 per cent in the legislation.
I am inclined to move an amendment to the motion to that effect. The motion would read:

That the Senate does not further press its request for an amendment to each of the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1991 to which the House of Representatives has again not made, and agrees to the amendment made to each bill by the House of Representatives in place thereof provided that a ceiling rate of tax of 12% is fixed by regulation in lieu of the 15% contained in the legislation.

That situation surely must commend itself to the whole of the Senate. I say `ceiling' because as factors are developing now, we may have a situation where that ceiling is too high and we may have to come down, or the Government may see its way clear to reducing that to 10 per cent, 8 per cent or whatever. I move:
At the end of the motion add ``provided that a ceiling rate of tax of 12% is fixed by regulation in lieu of the 15% contained in the legislation.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the issues that have been raised by Senator Harradine regarding the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1991, let me say that I can understand the tenet of what he is trying to achieve and the principles he is trying to get at. Unfortunately, we have the situation where Senator Harradine has had to adopt the traditional role that has been taken by the Australian Democrats, that is, to keep the bastards honest. Therefore, one can understand the expression that Senator Harradine is making.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, I cannot support the amendment that Senator Harradine is putting forward because that still means that the level of tax would be 12 per cent. We have argued and will continue to argue that the ceiling figure should be 10 per cent and the Democrats know that full well. They have done this conniving deal with the Government. They have not even got the original deal that they said they were going to do of putting in a ceiling figure of 12 per cent. They have walked right away from that. They have let the Government leave the 15 per cent rate in the Bill and give a commitment that it will regulate for 12 per cent in the first year, but no commitment whatsoever for the second, the third or whatever years after that. The Democrats have been conned. They have been sold down the river and Senator Harradine is, in some way, trying to patch up the problem.

I respect Senator Harradine for what he is doing, but I indicate that the fundamental issue is: what is in the interests of the woolgrowers? What is in the interests of the thousands of farmers and small towns? The Democrats have shown that they are again prepared to be chameleons in this Parliament and agents of the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —A rose by any other name be still a rose, and a sham by any other name be still a sham. What the Government is doing through the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills is attempting to pull a sham-to bring in a sham wool tax and, unfortunately, the Australian Democrats have connived with the Government in this conspiracy. Contrary to what Senator Bell and Senator Powell have argued, what we are seeing is not the Democrats getting what they originally wanted. If the Democrats were getting what they originally wanted, the Government would have come into this chamber and said, `We are going to amend the Bill to 12 per cent'. But the Government has not said it is going to do that. The Government has said, `We will make you a promise to regulate the tax to 12 per cent'. There is a grave difference between 12 per cent by legislation and 12 per cent by regulation. The point that we on this side of the chamber make is that the Government cannot be trusted, and we are gravely disappointed that the Democrats did not hold the line.
—All of them might not. Only some of them might. Some may change their minds.

—I hope some of them choose to stay, but it seems very dubious to me that we will get the wholehearted commitment that I had hoped for. I hope that Senator Harradine and any of the Democrats who are still considering their position will remember that this is not what the Democrats wanted. The Democrats are not even getting their original position. Any Democrat or honourable senator from the crossbenches who agrees to these Bills this afternoon will not be getting what the Democrats originally wanted. They are backing down in the face of the high-handed tactics of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and we on this side of the chamber will not live with that. We believe in sticking by our position, sticking by the woolgrowers of this country and sticking by principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to reply to many of the views expressed in this debate on the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills. However, in view of what has now occurred with the intervention of Senator Harradine with an amendment, and in view of the speech just delivered and some of the others, an explanation is required and, probably, encouragement to those speakers to become more familiar with the precise terms of the legislation before the chamber. If they had been so familiar, they would not have made the observations that they did make.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills, as drafted now, give the Minister power to set a rate below 15 per cent for the year 1991-92 only. After that, a consultative mechanism checks in which provides a way for industry opinion to be gauged and advice offered to the Minister about the appropriate level of rate. That means that the Wool Council of Australia and the Wool Research and Development Corporation will be required to consult; annual general meetings of woolgrowers will make recommendations to the Minister; and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission also must consult with the Wool Council in recommending a tax rate. So there is a process as to how any other rates should be set which involves extensive consultation with the industry and enables the industry's view to be articulated properly in advice to the Minister so that the Minister can then set the rate.

In view of that, I think it would be inappropriate to proceed with an amendment-even if it had standing, and I am advised that, in the form in which it is put, it has not-in the form in which Senator Harradine has moved. I think that a clear explanation, which I hope I have just given, answers those honourable senators opposite who have raised this question and, in particular, the last speaker, Senator O'Chee, who seems to have a defective understanding of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the reason I moved my amendment was not that I have shifted in my conviction that the rate should be no higher than 10 per cent but my recognition of the fact that the rate is going to be fixed by regulation at 12 per cent. I understand what the Minister is saying about the question of consultation because it is in the legislation. My amendment says `a ceiling of 12 per cent'. The ceiling in the legislation at present is 15 per cent. What is the difference between having a ceiling per an undertaking by the Minister and a ceiling in the legislation, whether or not consultation takes place? In view of the fact that it is obvious that my amendment is not going to hit the deck, I will seek the leave of the chamber to withdraw it. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Community Services and Health: Direct Marketing

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 19 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department considered the effectiveness of direct marketing; if so, please provide details of: (a) the areas in which the department believes direct marketing will be of most use to it; (b) the results it would hope to achieve from direct marketing; and (c) the types of direct marketing methods considered most relevant and effective for the department's purposes, for example, direct mail, telephone canvassing or other forms of direct marketing.

(2) Has the department separated direct marketing as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms; if so, please provide details of the level of funds spent since 1 July 1990, the anticipated level to 30 June 1991 and the purposes for which the direct marketing will be used; if not, does the department anticipate separating direct marketing as a budget item in its expenditure details; if not, why not.
(3) Does the department have, or is it in the process of developing, a database from which it can operate its own direct mailing or telephone canvassing projects; if so, please provide details.
(4) Has the department undertaken any direct mailing activities for this financial year; if so, please include details of the subject of the project, timing and to whom it was directed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Many program areas of the Department have given varying degrees of consideration to employing some form of direct marketing.

(b) Direct marketing should achieve better targeting of information and provide greater access to the department's programs and services. Direct marketing also provides information which is used to design better information campaigns.
(c) Direct mail, telephone canvassing and advertisements requiring a response are the main forms of direct marketing.

(2) No. Funds for direct marketing are provided as part of both general running costs and program specific appropriations and are not separately identifiable as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms. Procedures for separately reporting expenditure on direct marketing would add to the complexity of the Department's financial management systems. This would be difficult to justify given the emphasis under the current financial reforms on outcomes rather than inputs and the fact that there is no requirement to report separately on marketing related expenditure.

(3) The Department maintains a number of mailing lists which are used to send relevant information to interested groups, companies, individuals and organisations (many of which are recipients of Commonwealth funding). These lists are updated and amended periodically.
(4) Material relevant to the portfolio has been distributed through mailing lists held by the Department over the financial year. Examples include:

* `New Times for Older Australians' is a newsletter for older people which covers a variety of issues of concern to older people. It is prepared four times a year and distributed through a variety of mailing lists including nursing homes, hostels, hospitals, Department of Social Security offices, Home and Community Care providers, Geriatric Assessment Teams, Migrant Resource Centres and Senior Citizens Centres;

* an `Employer Information Kit-Child Care for the l990s, Meeting the Need Together' was distributed in November 1990 to agencies on a mailing list developed by Child Care Division. The mailing list included companies with more than 500 employees, child care consultancies and peak organisations with an interest in child care;

* an information package was sent to all University careers centres and student organisations in March outlining career opportunities for graduates in the Department. Packages contained a brochure on the Department's functions and a pamphlet on graduate opportunities;
* a Child Care newsletter `Minor Matters' was distributed in May 1991 with a mailing list comprising service providers and peak organisations with an interest in child care issues.
