QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 7 May 1991: With reference to the Federal Government's pre-1990 election commitment `to provide 28 000 more child care places in employer and commercial centres over the next 5 years':

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many of these places are to be provided at the workplace.
(2) What progress has been made towards fulfilling the Government's commitments since March 1990.
(3) Since March 1990, which companies have provided work-based child care and what level of care has been provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Improvements to the fee relief system introduced in community based centres on 1 October 1990 and extended to commercial and employer sponsored child care centres on 1 January 1990, were estimated to increase the number of places in employer and commercial centres by 28 000 over the next five years.
The increase is estimated for the sector and no estimates have been made of what proportion might be located at the workplace.

(2) The Australian Bureau of Statistics Census of Commercial Long Day Child Care in November 1988 indicated that there were some 23 000 full time child care places provided by commercial operators. It was estimated that in March 1990, there would be a further 5 000 full time places available through new services and through shorter hours services extending their hours of operation to offer full time care.

All child care services participating in the fee relief scheme agree to take part in the annual Child Care Census. The first census of commercial and employer provided care is planned to take place in August 1991. The information collected in this census will give a clearer picture of the number and type of new services which have commenced operation since March 1990.

(3) The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services is aware of six companies which have, since March 1990, commenced providing a total of six long day services and one vacation care service for the use of children of their employees. These companies are listed below. It should be noted that only those companies which contact the Department for advice and/or access to fee relief are known. Other companies may set up service provision independently.
St Patrick's College Ltd, Campbelltown, NSW
St George Building Society, Kogarah, NSW
Department of School Education, Minto and Mt Druitt,
* Number of places: Two 33 place centres
* Number of places: reserving 20 places out of 80 place centre for 21 years
The following company is intending to provide work-based child care within the next six weeks:

In addition, the ABC is providing significant support to a community based child care centre located in the ABC's new Ultimo headquarters. This centre will open in June 1991 and will provide 44 places.
* Number of places: 30 places for 4-11 yr olds

Smaller employers who wish to provide child care facilities for their employees are able to enter into joint arrangements with child care centres. To provide an incentive to employers considering this option, changes were made recently to the Fringe Benefits Tax Act to exempt from fringe benefits tax the amount of the contribution made to reserve places in an eligible child care facility. An example of the above is IBM, an information technology firm based in Baulkham Hills, Sydney, which has reserved 10 places for 8 years in a 40 place long day care community based service located close to their headquarters.

Forward-looking employers are increasingly recognising the importance of child care to a more flexible, productive workforce at the enterprise level. Government is keen to support employer sponsored child care to further its social justice and labour market objectives and to address the issues of supply and affordability of child care services.

The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services has produced some key resources to promote interest in employer sponsored child care, including an employer information kit and a booklet ``Tax Concessions for Employer Sponsored Child Care''. In addition, the Department of Employment, Education and Training has recently released a study on employer attitudes to the provision of child care services, ``Corporate Child Care: Management's View''.

The Department is currently developing two publications for distribution to employers within the next few months covering child care service options available to employers and Australian examples of employer sponsored child care. It is anticipated that these resources will further boost employer provision of child care services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) As stated in the 1991 Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for Forestry Operations in the Eden Management Area by the Forestry Commission of New South Wales (FCNSW), the timber resource loss arising from the October 1990 Commonwealth/NSW agreement on the South East Forests is approximately:
As the sawlog loss and pulpwood loss are calculated from different bases, it is inappropriate to combine the resource loss of these two products into one aggregate figure.

(5) Whilst the Commonwealth has been involved in consideration of resource data for the purpose of export licensing and examination of reservation proposals, it is the responsibility of the State Government to manage detailed resource data and to decide on public access to it. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the estimated value of Australian defence industry output expressed on an annual basis from 1983-84 to the present.
(2) What: (a) value; and (b) percentage of the value of Australian defence industry output has been exported on an annual basis from 1983-84 to the present.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no clearly defined defence industry sector in Australia for which the information sought is available. While Defence work represents a substantial share of business for some producers, most suppliers of Defence goods and services provide for a number of markets. Defence procurement is believed to account for about 1% of the value of manufacturing industry's output.

The estimated value of Australian defence industry output expressed on an annual basis from 1983-84 to the present can only be approximated from Department of Defence outlays. The main elements of Department of Defence outlays on defence related materiel are shown in the following table.
DEFENCE INDUSTRY RELATED EXPENDITURE IN AUSTRALIA (IN MILLIONS OF DOLLARS)

(2) There are a number of practical difficulties associated with estimating defence related exports. While the Department of Defence keeps records of permits issued for defence related and dual use exports, year on year comparisons are complicated as the coverage for dual use items has changed with COCOM guidelines through the years. Prior to May 1989, the controls were limited to the 13 COCOM-proscribed countries (Warsaw Pact plus China, Vietnam and North Korea). Since then, the export controls cover exports to all destinations. For dual use exports under the COCOM regime, the interpretation of future series of annual permit values will be complicated further by the November 1990 agreement to free up trade for a wide range of dual use goods among COCOM members. Formal application for permits is no longer required across this range of products for COCOM destinations.

As for realised exports, there is no formal requirement for industry to report back on actual exports made in relation to permits granted. For defence related exports, some information on actual exports has been collected over the past two years.
Accordingly, it is not feasible to provide a meaningful estimate of the percentage of the value of Australian defence industry output.
The following two tables provide the values of approved export applications.
VALUE OF EXPORT APPLICATIONS FOR DEFENCE RELATED GOODS APPROVED
(a) This includes application values relating to temporary ``exports'' such as returns sent to Australia for repair, goods returned for warranty reasons or goods exported for demonstration reasons.
(b) This excludes ``temporary'' exports. Such applications will add another $81m to the 1989-90 total and $62m to the 1990-91 total to date (30 May 1991).
(c) Statistics on actual exports were not kept in the Department of Defence for these years.
(d) Due to lags between the issue of permits and actual exports, these figures could be expected to increase.
VALUE OF EXPORT APPLICATIONS FOR DUAL-USE PRODUCTS APPROVED
(a) Prior to 1984-85, export controls on dual-use technology had not been formalised, so no value of goods was centrally recorded.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Following the aborted landing of an Australian Airlines flight on 22 May 1991 at Townsville Airport, can the Minister detail all air traffic control procedures at this joint facility.
(2) Which takes precedence at this facility in peacetime, civilian or defence aircraft.
(3) Why are RAAF training flights scheduled for landing during the period of regular commercial flights.
(4) At what height was the Australian Airlines flight when it was diverted from landing.
(5) What risk factor is involved in aborting a landing at that height.
(6) Will the Minister ensure that RAAF training flights are scheduled at times that do not jeopardise the safety and regularity of domestic air services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Air Traffic Control procedures in use at Townsville Airport, common both to the RAAF and CAA, are detailed in the Manual of Air Traffic Services. This manual is used by military and civilian air traffic controllers throughout Australia.
(2) At Townsville, civil and military aircraft operate with equal priority and are sequenced accordingly.

(3) The aircraft involved in the alleged incident at Townsville were not on a RAAF training flight. In fact they were a pair of RNZAF A4 Skyhawk aircraft in transit from Darwin. The fact that they arrived at Townsville at about the same time as a scheduled airline flight was a coincidence.

(4) The pilot in command of the Australian Airlines flight elected to carry out a missed approach, which is a published standard procedure, when advised that the runway was not clear for a landing. The height to initiate the missed approach is 600 feet.

(5) A missed approach is a procedure which is trained for and entails no risk to the aircraft and passengers. An aircraft can abort a landing sequence at any point including just after touch-down without risk.

(6) The military aircraft involved in this incident were not on a training flight. There was no risk to the safety of the Australian Airlines flight. This flight suffered a delay to its arrival because of a combination of adverse weather and the last minute unserviceability of ground navigation equipment which also caused the RNZAF A4 aircraft to be delayed in their landing.

The common air traffic procedures which are applied to both military and civil aircraft at Townsville ensure that the mix of civil and military aircraft operating there do so in a safe and expeditious manner. Delays to operations are, at times, unavoidable and may be caused equally by both civil and military aircraft. Changes to existing procedures are not required.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 May 1991, (Hansard, page 3375) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that the Commissioner of Taxation is denying primary producers the right to change the basis of valuation of livestock in these recessed conditions from cost to market price under a section 33 discretion of the Income Tax Assessment Act? This refusal is based on the grounds that a general fluctuation in livestock prices, where the market movement is one occasioned by widely prevailing economic circumstances, is not sufficient to warrant a change in the manner in which taxation on livestock is assessed. Is not such a decision uncaring, unreasonable and destructive? Will not such decisions cause unwanted financial hardship to primary producers caused by a collapse in sheep livestock market prices?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation has, wherever possible, adopted a sympathetic approach in exercising his discretion under section 33 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. However, the Commissioner as a matter of public duty must take into account all considerations relevant to the intent of that section in order to exercise his discretion.

Until 1936, a primary producer's election to adopt either cost or market value for stock on hand was irrevocable. This was changed with the enactment of section 33. Section 33 provides that a taxpayer shall not, except without the leave of the Commissioner, adopt a basis of valuation of his live stock taken into account at the end of the year of income different from the basis on which the valuation of his livestock was made when it was last taken into account at the end of a previous year.

The Explanatory Memorandum accompanying the amendment stated that the election to change may be made, for instance, where a partnership is created and the various members desire a common basis for bringing the value of the livestock of the partnership to account.

The Commissioner takes the view that the enactment of section 33 was made to apply in very narrow circumstances, such as where there was a change in the business arrangements, and that it was not enacted so as to allow primary producers to change the basis of valuation of stock on hand because of mere price fluctuations.

If a primary producer was able to change the basis of valuation because of changes in seasonal or economic conditions the Commissioner could be placed in the situation of never being able to arrive at the true profit of the primary producer. This state of affairs could be maintained on an indefinite basis, due to the rise or fall in prices in the rural sector. A consistent method of valuation is needed for the Commissioner to make a proper assessment of a taxpayer's income.

Moreover, few primary producers if any, would be able to ascertain accurately the cost price of their live-stock after having adopted market value for one or more years. This would be a particular problem in relation to live stock acquired by natural increase in the year following acquisition.

Primary producers are entitled to average their incomes over five years and can also participate in the Income Equalisation Deposit Scheme. It is these provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act which have been designed to compensate farmers for the fluctuations in their incomes. Few other taxpayers have these or similar entitlements.
